PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Sir Condor Laucke) took the chair at 9 a.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COLLARD

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-On behalf of Senator Bjelke-Petersen I present the following petition, which is not in conformity with the Standing Orders, from 57 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: We hereby petition the Government, through Senator Flo Bjelke-Petersen, to allow a substantial increase in the allowable amount of earnings before pension payments are affected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate:

(a) Expresses its concern at the statements made by the Liberal Premier of South Australia claiming that the sale of the South Australian Country Rail Services to the Commonwealth was the main reason for the Grants Commission allocating less money to South Australia under the tax-sharing agreement; and

(b) Reminds Mr Tonkin that he has deprived his State Treasury of approximately $20m since taking office due to the abolition of succession duties and gift duties and that he is now trying to recoup this lost revenue by levying higher State charges on those who can least afford to pay.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs. It emanates from a conference held in New Delhi some months ago which was aimed at restricting or curbing the illegal, black market export of ivory tusks from various African countries. One of the recommendations appeared to be measures taken to ban this illegal traffic. Applying it to the Australian scene, what instructions, if any, have been given to our Customs authorities to check for illegal tusks? Alternatively, what role are we playing at the United Nations? I think the former area is where the responsibility of Customs officers of the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs lies. Has any illegal traffic been detected and have any prosecutions been launched?

—I have no particular information with regard to Senator Mulvihill's question. I acknowledge the very real interest that he has in the subject. I will seek to get information regarding the conference which he mentioned which was held last year in Delhi. More particularly I will find out what measures are being undertaken by Customs officials at airports and other areas to ensure proper surveillance of this black market trade. In relation to the other matter that he mentioned, that is, what representations are being made at the United Nations, I need to refer that through the appropriate Minister in this chamber to the Foreign Minister to obtain a reply for him.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I preface my question by indicating that, on 29 May 1981, I asked the Attorney-General a question without notice concerning the initiation of a class action in the United States of America against Alcoa and Reynolds by the Conservation Council of Western Australia. I now ask: Is the Treasurer aware that the magazine Habitat is calling for donations which can be used to assist in the initiation of a class action in the United States of America by the Conservation Council of Western Australia against Alcoa and Reynolds? Is the Minister aware that the magazine is saying that any donations made are tax deductible? Is it a fact that these donations are tax deductible? If so, what is the rationale behind the donations being tax deductible particularly as the Government and the Opposition in this Parliament and in the Parli- ament of Western Australia have condemned this action? Will the Minister undertake to review this tax deductibility aspect? If the donations are not tax deductible, what action might the Treasurer be contemplating to alert both the magazine and its subscribers to the facts as they stand about the tax deductibility of donations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer is aware of the information that has been provided through the article that was mentioned by the honourable senator in his question. Gifts to organisations or funds conducting environmental campaigns do not generally qualify for deductions in terms of the specific provisions of the income tax law relating to gifts. However, the Australian Conservation Foundation is specifically named in the Income Tax Assessment Act as an organisation to which donations to the value of $2 and upwards may be made which can qualify as income tax deductions for the donors. The position is that, provided a gift is made to the Foundation, it is immaterial how the Council or the Foundation chooses to use the gift having regard to the objects and powers expressed in the Foundation's constitution. I understand that the terms of the constitution empower the Council to provide any kind of assistance to or to co-operate with, by any means, organisations for a purpose considered to further the objectives of the Foundation.

ANSWER.PARA: The question central to the issue for tax purposes is whether the gifts in question are made to the Australian Conservation Foundation in its own right or to another organisation with the Foundation merely acting as trustee or in a fiduciary capacity in respect of the donation. If the latter were the case, the donations would not qualify for deductions as the law now stands. This is a matter which will, as necessary, be kept under review by the Commissioner of Taxation in his administration of the income tax law.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ABORIGINAL COMMUNITIES: COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT EMPLOYMENT PROJECTS

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. How many Aboriginal communities in the Northern Territory are operating Community Development Employment Project programs? Are any of these communities experiencing the same sorts of difficulties which caused problems at Bamyili recently? Are any homeland centres involved in the CDEP programs?

—The Senate will be aware that the CDEP scheme is a pilot program which has been instituted over the past few years only in a number of selected areas. Several communities in the Torres Strait, as the honourable senator will know, and some in the Northern Territory are involved as well as a couple of communities in the north west of Western Australia. I will obtain for the honourable senator the exact number of communities involved in the Northern Territory. I am not aware that any of the other communities are experiencing the same problems as those which were brought to our notice in the last week or so in relation to Bamyili and which we have been able to resolve. As to the other details which the honourable senator has sought, I will obtain them for him. I may have them by the end of Question Time and I will particularly include the question whether any homeland areas are involved in the program.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. I must say that I apologise for giving it to him at 10 past nine this morning after a day was spent yesterday worrying in Cabinet about this problem. In the light of the facts surrounding--
—It is supposed to be without notice.
—I am giving the Minister notice while I am on my feet.
—You do not need to apologise.

—Why don't you fellows listen to what I am saying? In the light of the facts surrounding the Telecom Australia dispute, the potential wages boom and the consequent inflation problems which may flow from the resolution of that dispute, does the Government accept that the wage fixing process of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission has been proved a failure and should now be scrapped in favour of collective bargaining so that the resources of the nation can be properly allocated?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I start my answer by saying that I do not accept the apology of the honourable senator for putting the question at 10 past nine in the morning. The matters which he raised in the question-the possibility of a wages boom and the difficulties which would flow from that-are matters which are, of course, of concern to the Government. I do not think, however, that the agreement which was entered into and the decision of yesterday can be seen as failures of the wage fixing process. I think, rather, one might regret that the wage fixing process was not applied to the problems faced by Telecom. The fact is that an agreement was made without its being subject to the processes of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission-processes which have been designed by the Commission after a great deal of argument by the various parties in an attempt to find a fair method of fixing wages for the whole community. It is a problem which needs to be faced in a community in which there are not equal opportunities for bargaining, in which different groups do not have the same strength and in which there is a lot to be said for some uniformity of treatment of wage and salary earners in Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact is that the settlement which was entered into by Telecom was a direct agreement between Telecom and the union. It was not made subject to the approval of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and that, I think, is a matter which we might regret. For that reason I do not believe it can be held up as being something which proves that the wage fixing process is a failure. Rather, it points to a failure to use existing mechanisms, a failure which is regretted by the Government, and which the Government does not intend to have occur again with respect to its instrumentalities.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate and refers to the algebraic formulas contained in the report on tax sharing entitlements by the Commonwealth Grants Commission. Has he noted that the tariff protection factor is not included in the equations contained in the report? Is it a fact that Victoria and New South Wales receive per head of population almost twice as much money in tariff protection as Western Australia and Tasmania? Is it also a fact that this money which is paid to Victoria and New South Wales in part comes from revenue generated by the resources activities in the States of Western Australia, Tasmania and Queensland? How can this factor be incorporated in the equations for the purpose of revenue sharing?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is certainly a fact that the Commonwealth Grants Commission report on relativities does not take into account the matter that Senator Harradine has raised in relation to the varying effects or the importance that the tariff obviously has in different States. The reason that does not appear in this report is that that question is not one which is within the Commission's powers or the matters that the Commission is asked to consider in a relativities report or indeed if it were considering an ordinary report by a claimant. That is why it is not there. It is not because this question is not a very important one.

ANSWER.PARA: I accept the matters Senator Harradine raised in relation to the effect of the tariff as being broadly the situation that presents itself. As I said yesterday, the Government has yet to give consideration to this report. It is a recommendation only, albeit a recommendation from a very distinguished body. The members of the Commission recognise, of course, that the implementation of the report is one for governments, not for them. It is a matter to which the Government will have to give very serious and deep consideration in the coming months, and in particular it will be a matter for discussion when the Premiers meet next Friday. An enormous number of problems arise in relation to the report, and in answer to questions yesterday I made some reference to them. I believe that the questions Senator Harradine raised and other questions that will be raised are all matters that will have to be considered by the respective governments in coming to final decisions in this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Having in mind that Australian motorists already are contributing in excess of $3.5 billion to the Federal Government in excise and crude oil levy payments, in addition to the fuel taxes and fixed motoring charges such as registration and licence fees imposed by State governments, is it a fact that the Federal Government is proposing to impose upon Australian motorists further increases in motor fuel excise when it brings down its next Budget? If so, could this not be interpreted as a move by the Federal Government to make the already overtaxed motorists pay far beyond their economic circumstances?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — Senator Bjelke-Petersen has raised a matter that deals with policies that may or may not be involved in the preparation of the Budget to be presented later this year. I am not in a position to make any comment on them or to speculate in any way about what might be the provisions of the forthcoming Budget. I can say at this stage only that there will probably be many cases where suggestions will be included or excluded from the Budget. I think people would be well advised to wait for the presentation of the Budget and not add to speculation when they have no knowledge of these things.

—Will the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs tell the Senate what new commitments or undertakings were made by the Prime Minister and by himself to Professor Fred Hollows and Gordon Briscoe to persuade them to return to the national trachoma program?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —No new commitments or new undertakings were given to Professor Hollows or to Mr Briscoe. I repeat what I think I told the Senate last week, that although Professor Hollows had said he would resign I understand there was never a resignation. It was nothing more than a stated intention. There was in fact no resignation to withdraw as the Professor had not offered any resignation to the Royal Australian College of Ophthalmologists.
—All right; he withdrew his intention.

—Nevertheless, the fact is that there was no resignation and what was withdrawn was his intention. At the meeting which took place with the Prime Minister a number of points of clarification were sought. These included clarification of the fact that direct funding of Aboriginal medical services by the Commonwealth Government-that is direct funding from the Commonwealth Government to organisations and not through the States-would continue. This was a point on which there had been some unnecessary confusion and on which the two gentlemen wanted to have some confirmation. There was agreement that we would pursue further avenues for training of Aboriginal health workers in view of the need for more trained personnel in order to implement our policy. There was a request-I do not have the list in Bront of me-that the name of the environmental health program should be changed, that we should use a different form of words, since some Aboriginal people do not comprehend what the words 'environmental health program' mean. I think, from memory, the request was that we should use the term 'Aboriginal public health program'. We readily agreed to that.

ANSWER.PARA: There was a request concerning the use of the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation as a resource organisation. On that point I made it clear that we had decided that the National Aboriginal Conference should be our adviser, but that it could turn to anyone it wished. It could turn to NAIHO for advice if it so wished. There was a request that the trachoma program be followed up. We had given that commitment, and arrangements were made for us to have discussions on bringing forward a conference to advance the trachoma program. That, of course, is a matter which involved my colleague, the Minister for Health.

I must say that subsequent to that meeting I had a further meeting with Professor Hollows, Mr Briscoe and my officers. At that stage an offer was made to Mr Briscoe that he might well join the Department of Aboriginal Affairs on a consultancy basis-the details to be worked out later- to examine some of the implementation aspects. I subsequently received a letter from Mr Briscoe indicating that he would not accept such a position as he thought that it would not be in the best interests of Aboriginal people if he took it. The letter dated 9 June 1981 which indicated that Mr Briscoe did not wish to be associated with the program which we had offered him is brief. I just read the relevant part of it. The letter states:

I met with both Mr Perkins and Mr Brownbil on Friday 5 June and I felt that the proposal, as a consultant, would not only render the tasks set down by myself and Professor Hollows unachievable but would also jeopardise the 'vigorous' pursuit of the Government's five-year program to improve Aboriginal health.

On that basis he turned down our offer, and we have accepted that he has the right so to do. It is not our job to press him to take a course of action which he does not wish. If Mr Briscoe does not join the Department, it is because he has decided not to do so. It might be appropriate to have incorporated in Hansard the text of Mr Briscoe's letter. I seek leave to do so.
Please find enclosed a proposal for the establishment of a Ministerial Task Force.

I met with both Mr Perkins and Mr Brownbil on Friday 5th June and I felt that the proposal, as a consultant, would not only render the tasks set down by myself and Professor Hollows unachievable but would also jeopardise the 'vigorous' pursuit of the Government's five-year program to improve Aboriginal Health.
Since Friday's meeting, I have mentioned that I supported the Task Force proposal to both Mr Brownbil and Mr Perkins. Mr Brownbil seemed to have been thinking along these lines as well.
I have taken the liberty of putting forward the proposal which I hope you will seriously consider.
I look forward to further elaboration when we meet.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs indicate whether many applications have been lodged through the Program of Assistance to Youth Organisations-PAYO-for the period 1981-82? What types of activities and services of national youth organisations are to be assisted by the PAYO grants?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I would need to seek information from the Minister on that matter. I have no information before me, but I will see that Senator Neal is advised in response to his question.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I have received a complaint from members of the Bellwood Aboriginal housing estate at Nambucca Heads that mail deliveries are being made to houses occupied by white people in the area but that no deliveries, including urgent telegrams, are being made to houses occupied by Aboriginals. Apparently Aboriginals have to travel 1 1/2 miles to the post office and ask whether there is any mail to be collected. I ask: Will the Minister take urgent action to remedy this disgraceful situation?

—I am not certain whether this question is addressed to me as Minister for Aboriginal Affairs or as Minister representing the Minister for Communications. It does not really matter. Australia Post may well be involved in determining the facts. If, as the honourable senator suggests, people in equivalent situations were receiving differential treatment, I would agree that that is inappropriate and improper. I suggest to the honourable senator that the correct course for me is to set in train urgent investigations of the specific facts of the matter he set out. I think he mentioned Bellwood, near Nambucca Heads. I will undertake to have those investigations put in train, and if there is differential--
—They are even in the same street.

—If, as the honourable senator says, people in the same street are receiving differential treatment, I will undertake to make the strongest possible representations to find why that should be so, and if there is no good reason for it, I will endeavour to have it corrected as a matter of urgency.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. How does the Government intend to prevent the flow-on into other awards and into over-award payments of yesterday's announced pay rise for Telecom Australia's employees? Further, is not the Government naive in believing that the effects of this settlement can be regarded as isolated and restricted to Telecom?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I do not agree with the propositions put forward by the honourable senator in that question. It is a matter of some difficulty and one which did go before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. It is interesting to note that the Australian Council of Trade Unions put forward a proposition to the Arbitration Commission. This was put by Mr Kelty and was quoted in the judgment of the Full Bench. Mr Kelty said:

ANSWER.PARA: I make clear from the ACTU's position that it is not an agreement which, by itself, represents a reason for general award increases in the community. I also make it clear from the ACTU's position that we do not see it as a ground for increases in the public sector rates generally, and, except insofar as technical and related grades within Australia Post are concerned, we also make it clear that no union should be able to make it a claim for the restoration of their relative position with respect to the agreement.

That is the position as put forward by the ACTU. It suggests a clear corralling of the arrangement to the particular people who are involved. Clearly it is a matter of concern to the Government that whatever is said by the ACTU might be regarded by individual trade unions in a rather different light. I concede that this is a possibility and, therefore, that the fears expressed by the honourable senator are fears which are also of concern to the Government.

In the statement which was issued by Mr Ian Sinclair and Mr Wal Fife on behalf of the Government it was made clear that these are matters to which the Commonwealth did propose to give attention. I will quote briefly from parts of that statement. It reads:

Apart from the small number of technical and related grades in Australia Post, the Commonwealth will oppose any application to extend the agreement in other areas of Telecom, Australia Post, or other Commonwealth instrumentalities.

Of course, that is quite consistent with the view which was put forward on behalf of the ACTU by Mr Kelty. One might think, with the combination of both the Government and the ACTU singing the same song on this occasion, we might have some prospects of success. I think it is also important to draw the attention of the Senate to this fact which was mentioned in the statement by the Ministers on behalf of the Government:

In negotiating the Agreement, Telecom has acted contrary to standing Government instructions that where any Commonwealth authority is involved in the negotiation or settlement of significant industrial disputes, the terms of settlement should be fully consistent with the wage fixing principles of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and the Government's wages policy.
In this respect, the actions by Telecom in completing the agreement cannot be condoned.
Those who have negotiated on its behalf have done so contrary to the instructions of the Minister for Communications as conveyed to the Acting Chairman of Telecom in his letter of 25 May.

The completion of the agreement was also contrary to a specific Cabinet instruction of 28 March, 1979, that the authority should consult with the Department of Industrial Relations, and the terms of settlement be subject to the agreement of the Department of Industrial Relations, and where appropriate, its Minister.

It is quite clear from the quotations which I have read to the Senate that Telecom was outside the authority which has been delegated to it and that this is a matter of great concern to the Government. It is a situation which the Government does not intend to see happen again. The Government's ensuring that it does not happen again will do much to limit the sort of flow-on which is of concern to the honourable senator.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a supplementary question, Mr President. If the Government cannot ensure that its own employees operate within the guidelines, how can it expect private industries and their employees to make sure that they operate within the guidelines?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The 'own employees' referred to by the honourable senator are the employees of statutory corporations established by this Parliament, and they have a degree of independence. If the honourable senator spends the rest of the morning reading the legislation which was passed by this place at the time of the previous Government he will see that in fact there is a fair degree of independence vested in those commissions. That is certainly a fact.

ANSWER.PARA: It is nonetheless true that the Government has established rules within which it expects to operate the statutory corporations which have such a major role in the Australian economy and which have such a substantial influence on services provided to the public. It does expect them to operate within the guidelines which are established by government in this area. The fact that Telecom has not is viewed with great concern. The Government will examine whether there is a need to take any further action of a legislative kind to ensure that there is not room for the sort of slippage which has occurred in this case.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate and to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. In view of the questions from Government senators and Senator Chaney's responses to those questions about the Telecom Australia dispute-I am sure they have created in the minds of many honourable senators uncertainty as to whether the Government now agrees to settle the dispute-is the Minister in a position to tell the Senate the official point of view of the Government as to whether it has agreed to the settlement as reported in the Press? Are there some reservations which the Government now has up its sleeve to stop the Telecom workers from getting the payments that they deserve for their skills?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the position is quite clear. I would certainly regret it if anything I have said in response to the concerns expressed by honourable senators in questions has muddied the position. I should like again to quote from the statement made by my colleague on behalf of the Government. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: In these circumstances, the Government believes it has no alternative but to allow Telecom to honour its agreement, subject to all union bans being lifted and normal work resuming.

I think that is quite clear. On the other hand, I suppose those honourable senators who were up early enough either to listen to the radio news or indeed to read the newspapers-I must confess that I have seen very little of the newspapers myself but I know there have been some Press reports-would know that concern has been expressed about this settlement for the simple reason that it potentially affects the guidelines which I referred to in my first answer on this subject this morning. That is a matter which ought to be of concern to all honourable senators.

For that reason the Australian Council of Trade Unions saw fit to corral this in the statement of Mr Kelty which I referred to also in answer to a question this morning. I think the sorts of concerns about the wage fixing system are concerns which go to the position of all workers in Australia as well as to the general economic implications of the guidelines being generally breached.

The expressions of concern which have been evident in the questions asked-I think they have been evident in my reply-are based on the very real need to maintain a situation in Australia where we do not go through a repeat of what occurred in 1974 when there were massive rises in money wages which were not reflected in long term economic benefits but rather in a dislocation of the economy from which we have suffered for many years.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Treasurer: In view of a reply given to me recently in which the Treasurer stated that to reduce the maximum personal tax rate to 50c in the dollar would cost the Treasury only $125m which is less than 1 per cent of the total personal income tax receipts, will the Government consider joining the 50c club and limit the maximum tax rate payable in Australia by individuals to 50c in the dollar? Can the Minister say why a flat tax rate for personal taxation is not acceptable to the Government when taxes such as sales tax, excise tax, payroll tax and most other taxes are indeed flat taxes? Finally, is the Minister aware that many honourable senators, including a couple in this corner, would serve on a committee to look at the whole matter of sensible flat tax rates for Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — As the honourable senator has suggested, I think it must be the flat tax corner up there. I am just a little worried that Senator Withers might join the group, although I think he would rather get the axe out than talk about tax at all. The matter raised by Senator Townley is obviously one that would become a matter of policy if there were any thought in the mind of the Government to move to a flat rate of tax. Although it is said that it would cost $125m to move to a 50c flat rate, that would also need to be looked at in the context of what people who now pay less than the 50c rate would then pay-whether there would be any movement in that regard. The majority of taxpayers are presently at that lower level. I undertake to refer the question to the Treasurer and to ensure that Senator Townley's proposition is considered in the context of the forthcoming Budget. I have noted his suggestion with regard to a committee and will refer that also to the Treasurer for consideration.

—My question, which is addressed to the Acting Leader of the Government, relates to the fear within the community that in the next few months the Government may contribute members of the Australian armed forces to a multinational Sinai force, designed in the first instance to supervise the Israeli withdrawal from that area, and possibly to install United States forces in an advantageous situation for the launching of a rapid deployment force. I ask: Will the Minister give an assurance that no Australian troops will be sent abroad during the winter recess of the Parliament to participate in any force in the Middle East, under whatever auspices, without Parliament being recalled?

—That the Government has not made any decision in relation to this matter has been made perfectly clear. Of course, it is one which gives very great concern to all Australians; therefore earnest consideration would be given to it. One does not know what events may occur in a period of some eight or nine weeks. Therefore I cannot give in very specific or general terms the assurance that Senator Tate seeks. Certainly the Government will note the matter that he has raised. In whatever circumstances might arise-I am not suggesting that they will-I do not believe that it would be responsible of a government to give such an assurance in absolute terms. Certainly the concern that would be felt in the Parliament is well known to the Government and it would have that clearly in mind.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Defence whether it is a fact that the internal and external reviews of the Defence Science and Technology Organisation have been completed? In view of the fact that uncertainty about the future structure of that organisation is affecting staff morale, will the Minister arrange for early release of these reports, so that there can be informed public discussion?

—Following a review of the Defence Science and Technology Organisation, two reports have been received and are under consideration by the Government. No final decision upon them has yet been made. When it is, no doubt it will be announced and the reports will be made available also. I will refer to the Minister for Defence the honourable senator's question as to when the reports may be made available.

—I preface my question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, by stating that twice in recent weeks I have tried to establish whether the Australian Government is supporting current initiatives by the Portuguese Government and the United Nations for a process of self-determination in East Timor. To put it mildly, the replies that I have had from the Foreign Minister have been equivocal. I now ask whether the Government still supports in principle a process of self-determination for East Timor. Further, is it a fact that strong covert and apparently successful pressure has recently been brought to bear on the Australian media by the Government to keep the Australian people in ignorance of this latest, and probably last, hope for self-determination in East Timor and our own Government's apparent lack of support for it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I am not aware of what response the Foreign Minister has made to the questions referred to by the honourable senator today. I will check that information and inquire whether there is any further information that the Minister can give in response to those questions that were raised and any other matters that may have been raised in his question today.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations and again is in reference to the Telecom Australia dispute. I ask: If as reported in this morning's Press the Telecom union members do decide to refuse Telecom's pay offer, will the offer then be withdrawn and negotiations restricted more in line with Government policy?

—I do not intend to answer questions on hypothetical possibilities. I would have thought that there were two levels of concern in this chamber about the dispute. One is the fact that the dispute itself has a potential to disrupt severely the lives of most Australians and the other is its wider implications in the wages field. It is an area in which decisions are not easy. I do not believe that it is helpful to speculate on possibilities. The fact is that the Government has agreed or has decided that it will not interfere with Telecom's proceeding with the agreement it entered into with respect to the question of wages. The matter is now in the hands of the union and I think we should await the outcome of that.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE: BREACHES

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate: Did Cabinet discuss whether Mr Sinclair should comply with a request from the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations to put his evidence about past breaches of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade in the form of a statutory declaration or sworn evidence instead of a letter? Did the Cabinet decide that he should not do so?

—I will refer that question to the Minister concerned. As to the particular discussions that may have taken place, I do not normally reveal what discussions have taken place in Cabinet. I will refer the matter to the Minister and ask him to provide an answer for Senator Walsh.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate whether he has seen the report in today's Australian Financial Review that last Tuesday the Minister for Communications stated at the National Press Club:

QUESTION.PARA: The only reason I didn't give evidence by statutory declaration was that Cabinet felt, as I do, that if you're going to draw a distinction between two types of ministerial letters you can generate quite considerable confusion in the community.

As the Minister has said in his reply that he does not normally disclose the proceedings of Cabinet, I ask him whether this is further evidence of the twin set of rules applying in the Cabinet-one for Liberal Party Ministers and another for National Country Party Ministers?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware that the statement was made. Obviously, Ministers who have responsibility in relation to Cabinet decisions constantly reveal what decisions have been made by Cabinet. It is the appropriate Minister who should make a statement about this matter, and I have said that I will refer the matter to him.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Transport: How much national highway still remains to be built in Tasmania? What is the current estimation of the cost of the unbuilt section and what is the estimated time for completion of this highway?
—I have no particular information on the matter raised by Senator Archer. I will try to get a reply for him by the end of Question Time in respect of that matter.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Has the Minister seen reports that the Victorian Health Commission is considering moving all, what it calls, routine surgical procedures-toenails, varicose veins, et cetera-to the private hospital sphere and leaving the public hospitals to deal with high technology services such as renal dialysis and intensive care? Does the Minister think it is a desirable state of affairs to confine high technology medicine to large public hospitals and routine procedures to small private hospitals? Has the Minister also seen the report that this development may be encouraged by the Government's new health scheme? Was this an intent of the Government in introducing its new health scheme?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator has asked several questions. In the first he asked whether I had seen certain reports relating to some intentions of the Victorian Health Commission. The answer is no, I have not seen the reports. I am unable to comment on them for that reason. The honourable senator then asked whether the Victorian Health Commission intends to reallocate its priorities in certain ways. We will have to check that information for the honourable senator.

ANSWER.PARA: The aim of the Government's changes to the health scheme is to enable State health authorities to make their own decisions in relation to priorities and procedures within their own State borders, in accordance with the constitutional responsibility which they bear. It will be up to any State government to decide where the benefit to its citizens lies and to be answerable for its decisions in that area. It is entirely up to the State government to decide whether, in terms of efficiency, access, equity and the proper marshalling of its resources, to proceed to any particular model of allocation of hospital beds for particular purposes. As I have said, I am not aware of the intentions of the Victorian Health Commission and, therefore, I cannot comment on the accuracy of the reports.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Education, concerns the Review of Commonwealth Functions decisions in the tertiary education area and, in particular, the decision that fees will not apply to recognised double degree and double diploma combinations. Can the Minister confirm that specialist courses for teachers, such as Aboriginal education, special education, school librarianship and similar courses in public demand because of community need, and specialist courses in agriculture, such as oenology, all of which are supplementary to a basic degree, will be approved combinations for these purposes? Also, can the Minister confirm that principals of colleges of advanced education will be included in consultations well before the detailed lists of approved combined courses are finalised? I am referring to principals such as the Director of the Adelaide College of the Arts and Education and the Director of the Roseworthy Agricultural College.

—Senator Teague has stated correctly the proposition in relation to fees. I simply confirm that. As to the detail of the working out of these matters, I am afraid I do not have the information the honourable senator seeks. I will refer the question to the Minister for Education and ask him to provide an early answer.

—Mr President, in view of the fact that Mungo MacCallum made comment in the Age this morning on my gentlemanly behaviour, I thank you for calling me on the last day of your presidency of this chamber. Casting aside my gentlemanly behaviour for a moment, I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. In view of the Government's propensity to hand over government enterprises to the private sector, is the Government considering replacing all or part of the defence personnel at the Enoggera base in Queensland with personnel from Metropolitan Security Services?
—I will refer that question to the Minister for Defence.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Education. On Friday the Minister announced that school funds had not been cut but merely relocated to areas of greater need. How can the Minister and this Government justify using taxpayers' money by allocating $625 per student in private schools compared with $180 per student in government schools, as stated by the President of the South Australian Institute of Teachers?

—I shall not actually comment on the accuracy of the figures Senator Elstob gave. The fact of the matter is that the government schools to which he referred are the major responsibility of the State governments. They have had a long tradition of responsibility in that area. They accept that responsibility and basically provide the funds. Federal Government contributions are, of course, an important addition, but they are additions to what are the basic responsibilities of State governments. The Federal Government's role in the funding of schools in the private education system is much more important. Those schools have become vitally dependent upon the funds being provided to them by the Federal Government. I would be very surprised if it were suggested that the Government should not properly recognise some major factors relating to the funding of those schools today. I refer to their enormous importance to the community and to the further demands that are being made on those private schools by parents wanting to send their children to them.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Transport aware of the serious implications of the recommendations of the report by Transport Australia which, if implemented by the Government, would force all but the very rich out of the sky, would almost completely wipe out flying training due to massive fee increases, would force many essential services, such as the Flying Doctor Service to country areas, to cease operation and would put the viability of the general aviation industry in serious jeopardy? If so, can the Minister assure us that the Federal Government will not implement such drastic measures, to the detriment of the general aviation industry as a whole and of the people in country areas who are so dependent upon such services?

—The question of the general aviation study has been raised in the Senate several times in the last few weeks. On each occasion I have indicated that the Government will not take any action until there has been the fullest consideration of the report which is now in the hands of the Government. Of course, at the same time it will take into account the views of the general aviation industry in respect of these things. I am unable to give the specific assurance that Senator Bjelke-Petersen seeks, as I need to refer the matter to the responsible Minister in order to obtain his reply. I undertake to do that.

—My question, which is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, follows the question asked by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition this morning in regard to the funding of the State health systems and the actions of the Victorian Health Commission in scaling down public hospitals and forcing thousands of patients into private hospitals. The Government will be aware that overseas capital has been flowing into private hospitals in Australia. Has the Government any plans to control the prices charged by private hospital operators in this country? Has it any plans to prevent overseas monopolies from taking over all the private hospitals in Australia? Has it any plans to limit the amount of profit from private hospitals that can be taken out of this country?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The facts, as brought out in the Senate a couple of weeks ago, are very simple. Foreign owned private hospital beds in Australia represent about one per cent of total hospital beds in this country-as I recall it, about 1,500 out of some 95,000 hospital beds. I am not sure how many of those are in Victoria. I am not quite certain what relevance there is to the assertions that the Victorian Government has taken decisions to proceed in a particular way. I must say again that the facts in relation to Victoria are not established, as far as I know, and I would not want to comment as if they were.

ANSWER.PARA: Investment by foreign companies in Australia is controlled by the Foreign Investment Review Board, as has been made clear in this place. Those guidelines operate in relation to foreign owned private hospitals. They operate because they are necessary, and it is clear from experience that even some of the smaller investors who could, if they wished, avoid Foreign Investment Review Board guidelines have always gone to the FIRB for approval because they consider that to be appropriate behaviour. I reiterate that the Commonwealth Government's intention is to try to ensure for Australians the proper protection and access to health services and simplicity, equity and efficiency of health services. This we will continue to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Is it a fact that the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development has just forecast an average inflation rate by 1983 of 6 per cent per annum for Australia and its major trading partners? Is the Government now concerned about the inflationary consequences of the failure of the wages arbitration process as parties such as Telecom Australia negotiate outside the guidelines? Does the Minister agree with suggestions being made by economists that to reduce Australia's inflation rate to that figure by 1983 it is necessary in 1981 to take some strong and unpopular measures, including a huge domestic surplus, meaningful cuts in the Public Service, no tax cuts for this year, no additional income transfers and a massive attack on social security and welfare, health, education and funds for the States?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I am not aware of the prediction of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development referred to in the question raised by Senator Lewis, nor am I aware of the reports to which he referred of the massive dislocation of existing programs and further cuts and revision to Government policy. In response, I can say only that I think it is well known that quite central to the Government's economic policies at present is the containment of inflation to as low a level as possible. There is growth and development within the Australian economy. We will be seeking to sustain that growth and provide the opportunities that are within our reach for improvements in employment opportunities and services that are in many instances desirable in Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: It is not possible for me to comment at present on what will be policy decisions relating to the forthcoming Budget. I note the list that was mentioned by Senator Lewis. I think some of the things that have been suggested are quite contrary to the policies that the Government has shown in its support for income security measures, welfare matters and many other things that, even at the time it has been attempting to restrain expenditure, it has continued to support. The restraint that we will need to exercise will naturally be one of the things discussed with State governments at the forthcoming Premiers Conference and Loan Council meetings. I do not think there is anything that I can add, other than to say that, if anyone is suggesting that there ought to be restraint in government expenditure, this Government has shown and will continue to show that where this is achievable there will be restraint. It is expected that that restraint will be shared by the States as well as by the Commonwealth Government. That, of course, will be part of the context in which the forthcoming Budget will be framed.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Attorney-General. I remind him of his statement at the Estimates Committee A meeting on 27 April when he said, in relation to the shortfall in legal aid funding of nearly $1m that has emerged in Victoria for this financial year, that he will be monitoring the effect of the various administrative measures instituted to deal with this and that, as the end of the financial year approaches, he will assess 'the magnitude of the problem' and 'see whether the stockpile can be eliminated by the end of the year'. In view of the fact that, as he well knows from the pile of submissions he has received from the Victorian legal aid community-for the first time in living memory there seems to be a unity ticket between the Law Institute of Victoria, the Victorian Bar Council and the community legal centres in this respect-the situation has remained at crisis level now for almost three months and people are being denied legal aid or having legal aid postponed in situations of urgency, will he now reveal the results of that monitoring? Will he further give an undertaking that necessary funds will be made available this financial year so that the stockpile can be dealt with?

—Senator Evans mentioned statements that I made at Estimates committees and in answer to questions here that I was keeping the situation regarding legal aid in Victoria and Tasmania under very close review. We are taking measures to see whether we can deal with the situation administratively within the budget that we have for this year. I think it is very important for people in the whole legal aid area-that includes the Law Institute of Victoria, the Victorian Bar Association or legal groups in any other State-to realise that there are very strict budgetary limits and policies by this Government. Everybody must take the utmost steps to live within the budgets that are allocated in these areas. The fact is that demand for legal aid fluctuates quite considerably from month to month and one can get a picture only over a lengthy period.
—You can't put a price on justice.

—I am just explaining, Senator Primmer, that I am concerned to ensure that the situation in Victoria is not one of these periodic fluctuations with which we are quite familiar, having been engaged in legal aid administration for a little longer than Senator Primmer has. I am pleased to say that with the co-operation of my colleague the Minister for Finance I am now in a position to take some steps to start reducing the stockpile that has occurred in both Victoria and Tasmania.
—How much?
—Within the next few days I will inform the people concerned of the details. Certainly significant inroads should be able to be made in the stockpile over the next few weeks.

—Is the Minister for Finance able to comment on the public speculation that an additional sum of around $100m will be given away as foreign aid as a consequence of the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting? Is the Minister aware that the cost of administering Australia's foreign aid has moved from the lowest to the highest in the world? Will the Minister ensure that any further foreign aid funds are spent within Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I am aware of some Press speculation with regard to the level of foreign aid that will be provided in this Budget. I think that arises from relating last year's level of foreign aid to the percentage of gross domestic product and looking at what would be required at least to maintain that same percentage level of GDP. The Press reports that have been the basis of Senator MacGibbon's question are speculative. When I earlier answered a question on this subject I said that the level of foreign aid in the Budget has not yet been determined and certainly would not be announced before the Budget.

ANSWER.PARA: I think it would be wrong for anyone to assume any direct relationship between the CHOGM meeting and the level of foreign aid because foreign aid goes to many countries. There is a continuing program of foreign aid and support for projects in many different countries. The determination of the level of foreign aid will be part of the Budget process. I think it is fair to say that Australia has a good reputation in respect of the foreign aid that it gives throughout the world in terms of grants to developing countries which enable many worthwhile projects to be undertaken.

It is suggested that our cost of administering foreign aid is the highest in the world. I cannot comment on that figure if we are talking about the terms or cost of administration. We are certainly not the highest givers of foreign aid in the world, but we have a very respectable record when compared with Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries. We do fairly well in regard to the level of gross domestic product that is directed to foreign aid. I detect support in many parts of Australia for foreign aid for worthwhile, essential and vital projects in many parts of the world. In the casting of the Budget, we will be seeing what can be provided in foreign aid that will enable us to do the things that we know will be useful in the world context.

The spending in Australia of funds earmarked for foreign aid is a matter on which I do not need to comment. Our foreign aid program is well known and well respected and will certainly be treated very seriously in the Budget context when we are casting these figures.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier, Senator Archer asked me a question in connection with the National Highway in Tasmania. I have now received a reply in respect of that matter. The Minister has advised that the National Highway in Tasmania is sealed throughout and, with the completion of major projects over recent years, provides a high level of service for motorists in the State. However, there is a need for significant upgrading between Burnie and Penguin, Ulverstone and Devonport and in the vicinity of Launceston. By-passes are also required for the towns along the highway including Bridgewater, Oatlands, Carrick, Deloraine and Burnie. Completion of the National Highway in Tasmania is estimated to cost more than $145m in 1980-81 prices to bring this link up to full national highway standards. The Minister expects that work on all major deficiencies on the National Highway as mentioned will have been completed by 1988, the year of the national bicentenary. However, there will be a continuing need for upgrading on other sections which will carry over into the 1990s.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ABORIGINAL COMMUNITIES: COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT EMPLOYMENT PROJECTS

TALK.START.PARA: —During Question Time, I promised Senator Robertson that I would supply him with some information in relation to Community Development Employment projects in the Northern Territory. Four communities in the Northern Territory are receiving grants-Bamyili, Galiwinku, Milingimbi and Gapuwiyak. I am not quite sure where the last-mentioned community is located. Some of the work that is done under this scheme is associated with homeland communities or outstations. The problem in getting the other detailed information for the honourable senator is that, because of the current Telecom problems, the extra information which would be available from the Northern Territory regional office is locked in there until we can make contact with the office. It is not possible to obtain this information this morning. We will give some follow-up information on that later. Some CDEPs are operated from my Alice Springs regional office, but they are in Western Australia or South Australia, not in the Northern Territory.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —As honourable senators are aware, it will be necessary for a re-arrangement of the Parliament House accommodation under my control to provide proper facilities for the Australian Democrats as a result of their increased representation in the Senate from 1 July 1981. I have been assisted in my deliberations by a very hard working, all party advisory committee of senators and I thank them for their efforts, particularly over the last six weeks. I regret that, in looking at the accommodation options on the Senate side of the building, we were unable, for the moment at least, to benefit from the review by generally providing improved accommodation for senators. However, I feel confident that the work undertaken by my advisory committee will greatly assist my successor in continuing to seek a re-arrangement to achieve this objective.

INTERJECT.PARA: I am now pleased to announce that the accommodation re-arrangement I have ordered provides proper facilities for the Australian Democrats in the form of a leader's office, a staff office and a party room and, whilst relocating certain Parliamentary Library staff within the building, it does not involve the removal from the building of officers engaged by the Library on research duties.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —After the recent demonstrations in King's Hall, instructions were given by the Presiding Officers to restrict the entry to the building of those involved so as to avoid the possibility of further disruption. These people are, however, able to enter the building if they seek and are granted an interview with a senator or member. I am informed by the Security Co-ordinator, however, that this arrangement was inadvertently extended to include persons from the so-called 'Atom Free Embassy'. As the result of this, an incident followed in which Mr Wright blocked an approach at the lower front entrance. He was removed by the police to outside the entrance. He became engaged in conversation with police, parliamentarians and the Press. As requested by Mr Wright contact was made with Senator Mason's office. When Mr Wright eventually returned to the entrance he was allowed into the building without delay.

INTERJECT.PARA: I am further informed that later that day the Security Co-ordinator had a discussion with Mr Wright and explained to him how the situation occurred. He apologised to Mr Wright for what had happened and for any inconvenience which it may have caused Mr Wright. A female who was present with Mr Wright when he first entered and who was stopped, requested to see a senator. The senator was contacted and she was admitted to the building to see the senator. Apart from the arrangements which I have stated being inadvertently extended to the 'Atom Free Embassy', the attendants did follow the procedure as laid down.

I must say that, normally, visitors to Parliament House are entitled to enter the public areas of the building without restriction. Should such a visitor wish to see a senator or member, the procedure is for a request to be made at the Senate or House of Representatives inquiry box, as appropriate. The wishes of the senator or member are then ascertained and arrangements made accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate the Government should instigate an inquiry under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 into-
(a) The environmental value of the Tasmanian south-west wilderness and wild rivers area to Tasmania and the nation;
(b) The most appropriate way of conserving that environment, consistent with necessary State development; and
(c) Whether Federal assistance is desirable and, if so, the nature of that assistance.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr President, I recognise, and I say this in all sincerity, that in your five years in the Chair you have served the Senate and senators well. You have done all in your power to try to provide reasonable and satisfactory accommodation for us. I recognise that once again you have not been able to get from another place the co-operation you deserve. But I wish to say, Mr President, that it is quite clear from the report which you have just put down that there is plenty of accommodation in this building to house senators and members of this Parliament. It is clear from what you have said that that accommodation is being used by people who do not need to be housed in this building. I make it perfectly clear that I am not talking about the Library staff in any way. I see no reason why the Library staff should be forced out of this building. They should be here to serve us. In the meantime, senators and members of the Parliament are being housed in what can only be described as dog boxes. My room is standard; it is less than 10 feet square. For those who do not understand that measurement, that is less than three metres square. I share my room with my research officer. The two of us crowd into this room and try to cope with each other-one on the telephone and the other using the typewriter.
—I know where my sympathies lie.

—Yes, I accept that. My sympathies rest with him too, because I get very cross at times and he is the unfortunate recipient of that crossness. Frequently, the crossness is to do with Senator Evans. I say to you sincerely, Mr President, it is about time the senators and members of Parliament were housed in proper and adequate accommodation. Surely that must be done no later than the commencement of the next sittings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Melzer Sen J.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr President, in regard to the question of the accommodation I wish to say some of the things that you were too polite to put down in your report. I think the Senate should be aware that for six weeks senators worked hard and constantly to find the fat on this side of the building that could give senators decent accommodation. We recommended to you, Sir, that the Joint House Department should be moved from this building. We did not do that lightly. We considered the matter in great detail. We considered that the work and comfort of members of this place would not be affected in any way if that Department were moved. We were of the opinion that this would enable all members of the House of Representatives to have an individual office instead of sharing, as some of them still do. We were of the opinion that this would enable senators' accommodation to be upgraded to something like a decent standard.

SPEECH.PARA: I agree utterly with what Senator Lewis said about the sorts of conditions in which people here have to work. Nevertheless, when we came down with this very reasonable report, which did not affect the workings of the Parliament, we got no co-operation from the House of Representatives. In fact, we got every indication that it had not looked at the matter seriously at all. Although the House of Representatives is demanding that more office space be made available, and although 13 members of the House of Representatives are accommodated on this side of the building, there was no evidence that it had looked at the matter seriously. Indeed, our recommendation was brushed aside in a most cavalier fashion. In fact, there were indications that those in authority on that side did not really believe that it was our business to allot space in this building. As I am leaving the Senate I would like honourable senators to be very aware that there is a move to take these sorts of considerations out of their hands and give them to other people in this place. I think that would be a very detrimental step.

Mr President, I would also like to comment on the other matter you raised this morning, namely, security in this place. I can understand that after the events of the last two weeks in King's Hall certain people would be a little uneasy and a little edgy about what went on. However, in the last two days two lots of women who have come to Canberra as visitors asked to see me. They were not part of any demonstration, they just happened to be women. They were left waiting in the rain outside the downstairs entrance to Parliament House while the security officers decided whether or not they would be allowed into this building. Mr President, I think you should be aware that these sorts of moves are going on. I agree with you utterly that this place belongs to the people of Australia, and they should be allowed into King's Hall. Whether or not they are allowed through the doors into members' offices is another matter, but I believe we are taking a very detrimental step if, outside your authority or our authority, people can be told that they have to wait outside in the rain while some unknown people decide whether or not they are fit and proper people to come into Parliament House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr President, I want to say something about the first part of your statement. I do not want to traverse this issue to any great extent. I think it was said that the Treaty of Versailles sowed the seeds of the Second World War. If all the people from the other side of Parliament House had been evicted from this side of the building when the new wing was constructed in the early 1960s-this would have been before you came to this place, Mr President-we would not have had this problem. Of course, they say that nice guys do not win. We have inherited this situation.

SPEECH.PARA: From my experience of negotiations, some of the Joint House Department people ought to be sent in the recess to either Mount Macedon Administrative Staff College or the Clyde Cameron College for some education. Quite candidly, the arrogance of some of these people had to be seen to be believed. It is regrettable that people in high places believed what they said. Officers of the Joint House Department blandly told me and other honourable senators that there was lots of room in the carpenter's shop, which housed machinery such as circular saws and band saws. All members of this group, including Government senators, were imbued with a sense of industrial safety, and we made it very clear that we were not going to be in that sort of rort. I simply want to say that you, Mr President, were much more temperate in this communique than Senator Chipp, Senator Melzer or I would have been. If we had drafted this statement we probably would have hammered home the shortcomings of the people across the way. We do not want anybody to distort the issue. We back to the hilt the views of every honourable senator about the need to retain the library in a state of maximum efficiency. It is not a question of nibbling at all. I simply say that the name 'Joint House Committee' is synonymous with the most arrogant attitude I have ever experienced since I have been a member of the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was the Joint House Department, not the Joint House Committee.
—I am referring to the Joint House apparatus, not the rank and file. Perhaps we need worker control. The problem is with the boffins who operate at the top.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present the sixth report of the Publications Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Report-by leave-adopted.

DEBATE.TITLE: SELECT COMMITTEE ON PARLIAMENT'S APPROPRIATIONS AND STAFFING

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-

SPEECH.PARA: The Select Committee has now completed its inquiry into the Parliament's Appropriations and Staffing. However, as there is not sufficient time to have the report printed before the Senate rises for the winter recess, accordingly it is proposed to release it through the President of the Senate in approximately two weeks' time. It will, of course, be immediately distributed to honourable senators and members. Due to the rather specialised nature of the inquiry the Committee did not advertise in the national Press for submissions. Instead, direct approaches were made to organisations and individuals having a particular interest in, or involvement with, Parliament's appropriations and staffing.

The importance of the reference, and the interest the inquiry aroused, is underlined by what was the first ever appearance of a Speaker of the House of Representatives before a Senate Committee and the ready co-operation and assistance of acknowledged experts such as Mr Jim Odgers and Professor Gordon Reid, and a number of parliamentary and government departments.

Mr President, over many years now honourable senators, and more recently, honourable members on both sides of the chamber have been concerned for Parliament to make such arrangements as are necessary to achieve its proper constitutional relationship with the Executive in practice as well as in theory. The Senate recognised this widespread concern by having all parties represented on the Select Committee. On behalf of the Select Committee I now express the earnest wish that our report will attract the same unanimity among honourable senators as was reached during our deliberations. With such support from the Senate, the report will then become the culmination of years of effort and the blueprint for rational, responsible reform.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.
