TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, the schedule shows that responses to five of the reports have been tabled since you made your report to the Senate on 14 May. Action in relation to the other further reports is certainly in hand to the extent that it is expected that they will be available in the Budget Sittings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report:
Redevelopment of the Brisbane International Airport-further dredging and reclamation.

I am moving this motion at the request of the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr McVeigh) who has provided the following statement for the information of honourable senators: The proposal is for the execution of further site reclamation only associated with the balance of phase 1 works including provision of a cross runway and general aviation areas. The estimated cost of the proposed work is $16m at May 1981 prices. I table plans of the proposed works as provided by the Minister.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report:
Armoured Centre Redevelopment, Puckapunyal, Victoria.

I have moved this motion at the request of the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr McVeigh) who has provided the following statement for the information of honourable senators: The Armoured Centre at Puckapunyal is the major training centre in Australia for the Royal Australian Armoured Corps. Most of the facilities currently operating from there are inadequate or outmoded. This proposal is for the consolidation of new and refurbished facilities into an integrated complex for training, administration and accommodation. The works will comprise a headquarters and instructional building, driving and servicing training facilities, a technical support building, a Q store and guard complex, sleeping accommodation, new and refurbished mess facilities, refurbishing of tank hangers, a parade ground, roads, car parks and engineering services including fire protection measures. The estimated cost of the proposed works is $12m at May 1981 prices. I table plans of the proposed work as provided by the Minister.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Durack) agreed to:
That-
(1) The Senate, at its rising, adjourn till Tuesday, 18 August 1981 at 3 p.m., unless otherwise called together by Sir Condor Laucke.

(2) In the event of Sir Condor Laucke being unable to act owing to illness or other cause, Charles Ronald Maunsell or one of the Temporary Chairmen of Committees shall act in his stead for the purposes of this order after consultation with the Leader of the Government in the Senate.
(3) The hour and day of meeting so determined shall be notified to each senator.
Motion (by Senator Durack) agreed to:
That leave of absence to be granted to every Member of the Senate from the termination of the sitting this day to the day on which the Senate next meets.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Honourable senators will be aware that we did not complete yesterday's business program despite our sitting until an early hour this morning. In view of the early start at 9 a.m. it was decided that the Senate should lift. However, that has left us a little behind with the program so extra pressure is on us today. I hope that we will have the co-operation of honourable senators in achieving our program today. I remind honourable senators that 12 of our colleagues are retiring. This will be their last day. Valedictory remarks are scheduled to be made before we rise, so we wish to complete our business so that satisfactory time is available for that purpose. As a result of discussions last evening it has been agreed that, to achieve today's program, we will if necessary continue to sit rather than suspend the sitting for lunch. At this stage I do not propose to move any motion in relation to that. If that does become necessary in order to achieve all our purposes today I signal that I will move a motion to enable the Senate to continue sitting.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 11 June, on motion by Senator Peter Baume:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I was interrupted at 1.9 this morning I was refuting some of the assertions of Senator Puplick. In view of the fairly long day we have ahead of us I will simply summarise my points. I should like to illustrate the difference between the views held by Senator Puplick and me. Senator Puplick placed great stress on certain impact statements. He said that all was well. Quite frankly, when the Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry second report-the Fox report-was brought down anybody who read page 289 would know that there was a note of warning there that there could not be any long-range prophesies that subsequent mining operations would not seriously impair the fragile environmental composition of the Alligator Rivers region. That is why my colleague, Senator Ryan, argued that if the government of the day allowed mining-the Opposition has well known views about uranium operations-and implemented a mining policy it should give total recognition to the fears of Mr Justice Fox. The implementation of such policies would have to be done in some sort of sequence.

SPEECH.PARA: With all due respect, the introduction of this legislation means that this Government is stepping up the demands on the Alligator Rivers system. I want to make this point: I was there recently with the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment. I asked the staff of the supervising scientist whether they were in a position to say that the river system will cope for the duration of the mining operations. They said they could not guarantee that. The operations of one of the existing mines, it is said, will be completed in eight to ten years. At that stage, of course, it will start packing in and covering over the tailings. With seepage and other environmental problems, no one knows whether it will be a success. I accept the fact that the mining companies have said that they are learning all the time, and they are. Do not forget that when the original safeguards were imposed by Mr Justice Fox the mining companies whinged that they were too excessive. Yet, if one looks at the recent report of the supervising scientist, minor breaches occurred. I do not say that these breaches occurred with evil intent, but they did indicate that the margin of safety has to be maximised.

The idea of a third mining operation will result in overloading the river system at a time when the Government does not know whether the rehabilitation methods to be used by one of the present operators when it closes its mine will be successful. There is no question about it. A monument of past errors was the Finniss River. It is not merely an environmental question. The fact is that the Australian taxpayer has been paying a pretty heavy burden for rehabilitation of that river. The same situation applies nearer home with the rehabilitation of the Molonglo River-the cost of which is being met by the New South Wales Government and the Commonweatlh Government. The cost has not been met by the discredited Lake George Mining Co.

We talk about emulating the United States in many areas. The United States Government, whether it be Republican or Democrat, is largely dominated by private enterprise concepts. When it came to cutting up Alaska, there were differences between the Republicans and the Democrats on the acreage that was to be forever off-limits to mining operations. They conceded the principle that some areas of Alaska would never be mined. The Secretary of the Interior, Mr Morton, in the Nixon Administration, was a man who had lots of ties no doubt with business interests and with various people who wanted to make a fast buck, but he went on record as saying that some areas in Alaska would never be touched.

Whatever the differences in relation to uranium mining, market forces and safety issues are, and whether some of the scientific reservations the Opposition has will be overcome, I cannot see why uranium mining cannot be carried out other than in what is a choice, prime environmental area. I cannot stress that point too much. My colleague from New South Wales Senator Mason will be well aware that a similar matter arose in New South Wales when it was said that the industry involved would not survive. We had a classic case in the middle 1960s of the Colong Caves which had limestone deposits. We were told that if we did not agree to the mining of the Colong Caves, New South Wales would lose its cement industry. I spoke to the Australian Workers Union about it. I said that no doubt alternative sites were available. Many of us ran through the streets of Sydney. We were well primed up seven weeks' before to get into condition. We carried banners proposing alternative sites. Alternative sites for limestone mining were found.

I simply say that this situation leaves me quite cold. What I fear is that over the years various prospecting will go on and a mining company will come in and say that it wants a few hectares. It is not a question of the area involved, it is a question of the principle of the matter. The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) wants Kakadu National Park and one or two areas listed on the World Heritage List. I wrote to him twice and asked him for a pledge and I asked Senator Carrick at Question Time whether he could assure me that if any more uranium mining took place it would not go into the park area. He declined to give that assurance.

I conclude by emphasising that what is said at page 289 of the Ranger report No. 2 epitomises all of our fears and reservations about the need to hasten slowly. Secondly, in regard to the matter of precedent, if it has been good enough for the United States in drawing up its Alaska land policy to put some land permanently off-limits for mining, it can be done here also. That does not throttle activity elsewhere; it merely establishes a principle. I suggest that in three years or less the Government will be coming back with another request for another little nibble. I have coined the phrase that the Government wants to have the Kakadu National Park pockmarked with various mining venture. It is simply not good enough. The chief scientist cannot give an assurance concerning the protection of the environment and, obviously, until one of the first mining operations closes down we will not know what is in store for us. That is the crux of the argument that has been presented by Senator Ryan and by me. I have no doubt that Senator Mason, in his own clear-cut style, will more than strengthen it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats agree with the basic points about tampering with the national parks that Senator Mulvihill has raised. Both he and I have the honour to be members of the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment and several times have been to inspect the park. We have been more fortunate than have been many Australians and know, perhaps better than most, what a tremendous asset this country has in the park and what enormous economic value it would have for Australia if indeed it were not pockmarked by mining operations. There is a demand in the world for wilderness areas, one that I believe in the next 20 years or 30 years will be of great economic importance. The Northern Territory and Australia are throwing away their heritage and economic asset, in the form of the Kakadu National Park, or are in grave danger of doing so, as a result of their supine yielding, at a moment's notice, to whatever a foreign-owned multinational uranium company may want. That is exactly what the Government is doing.

SPEECH.PARA: Beyond that, the Bill represents a blatant act of piracy, in the course of which the Government is tearing up the law designed to protect the public interest in preserving the national parks. That is one of the most important and serious implications of this apparently minor Bill. The law to which I refer is enshrined in the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975, section 7 (9) of which states that removal of land from a park or reserve or within a wilderness zone shall not be made except in accordance with a resolution passed by each House following the giving of at least 15 sitting days notice of such motion. Clauses 11 and 12 of the same section lay down machinery which ensures in the public interest that no proclamation may be made until the Executive Council has received a report from the Director of National Parks and Wildlife. This in turn allows interested organisations 60 days following publication of notice in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette.

These very proper and reasonable safeguards allow the community to have notice of this kind of tampering with its assets by a government. That is what is happening now. The Government has chickened out. It knows that, if it followed the proper procedures, it would be heavied by the public over this. It has tried to get the measure through by presenting it on the last sitting day of the Parliament. It hopes that it will sneak through the measure in that way. That is a dishonest trick by which the Government is taking away from the Australian people rights enshrined in law to ensure the protection of their most sacred assets, the national parks and wilderness areas of this country. The Australian Democrats condemn the Government unequivocally for that action. The Act has been blatantly and arrogantly disregarded. A most dangerous precedent has been set on behalf of a totally foreign mining interest, Dension Mines of Canada, which owns the Koongarra lease. I would like the Government to tell me what persuasions have been brought to bear on it by that foreign multinational in order to commit this blatant trick against the Australian people.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is like a mugging in the park-an environmental mugging.

—That is a valid comparison. I will accept that and I am sure that Government senators in their own hearts will accept the same principle. It is what will happen in future-the precedent they are setting-that I am commending to them, amongst other things.

SPEECH.PARA: What will we lose if mining is permitted in this area? We are destroying, or at least marring, an area of unique scenic and ecological importance. There is not time today to stress sufficiently to Australians, who may be listening, what an enormous asset in world terms we have in Kakadu National Park and the degree to which it is being messed about already. In flying over the park now one can see pockmarks from old uranium mines all over it. We are destroying some of the most valuable historical Aboriginal sites in Australia-the actual land bridges which over the millenia Aboriginals have used to enter this country. We are destroying one of the few places where we can still go to see Australia as it was before European settlement. Of course, that is what we hope the Kakadu National Park will remain.

The Fox report states that the Koongarra deposit at the Nourlangie Creek catchment is upstream from the extremely valuable Woolwonga Wildlife Sanctuary-an area so valuable ecologically that the report opposed in principle any mining development upstream of it. Indeed, if we were to proceed with such mining we would be going against the Convention on Wetlands of International Importance and Australia's agreement with Japan for the Protection of Migratory Birds in Danger of Extinction.

Yesterday I received representations by telegram from the Gagudju Association, the traditional owners of Kakadu National Park protesting strongly about these changes to the boundaries of the Kakadu National Park. One of the main points the Association made to me was that it had only just received notice from the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) about this Bill being put through Parliament. The Minister may perhaps deal with that. I am not making any claims on that; that is what the Association said to me. The Association also said that one of the major features of the Kakadu National Park, the Nourlangi Rock area, will be affected by the mining operation if the park boundaries are altered. The Gagudju Association notes that the proposed mining area is upstream of one of the most important and best water-bird areas in Australia and no one can guarantee that this area will not be polluted or silted up if mining goes ahead. The Association also said that this mining would produce noise, very heavy traffic and a large population in the area.

It is interesting of course that the Gagudju Association feels that way because it is in a position to benefit financially from uranium mining. It is aware of this. I have had discussions with the Association. At the same time I think it is fair to say that these people are deeply concerned about the land. I do not believe that Australians generally understand the real feelings of Aboriginal people towards their land. I think that I have come to some understanding of that simply through listening to them for long enough speaking on that subject. These people obviously feel they will be forced to agree to the making of a grant of a mining interest with respect to this land. The telegram states:
It is all very well to say that the boundary will not be changed until or unless we reach agreement with Denison Mines. That is still holding the gun at our heads.

That is the view of the traditional owners of the land. The point which comes through most strongly in this representation from the Gagudju Association is that these people feel they need time to study the proposal and consider it fully before coming to a decision. They stated in the telegram:

This is our land and our father's land and the Federal Government agreed with this. We have lent our land freely to the people of Australia to make a great national park for the use of all people. To protect that land we therefore ask all Senators to defer this Bill until we have had a chance for discussions amongst ourselves.

So in all sincerity I convey that message to the Senate. It is of course the sort of thing that the original legislation that the Government is pirating had in mind-the opportunity for people to put forward their point of view. The Government, in forcing this Bill through today by using its numbers immorally again-as I said last night it is doing this immorally-is, of course, breaching that trust which I think it had made with the Gagudju people when it made the land available to the people of Australia for a national Park.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many people go to the national park?

—Senator Townley is saying that he does not believe that Kakadu National Park is of any value in the future to Australia because very few people go there. Most national parks start off with very few people going to them. The intention of Senator Townley and also Senator MacGibbon, I gather, is to make sure that nobody goes there in the future. They are in the pockets of the uranium interests of Australia. That is plain. We know that.

—Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I remind the honourable senator that his slogan was: 'Keep the bastards honest'. If he is going to allude to what other people have said, I suggest that he speak the truth.
—Order! There is no point of order. Senator Mason, address your remarks to the Bill.
—I take exception to that. I raise a point of order. The honourable senator has alleged that I have not spoken the truth.
—You have misstated what he said.
—I require his withdrawal of that statement.
—You are preaching morality. Be truthful yourself.
—Order! I have ruled that there is no point of order from Senator Baume. Senator Mason, continue your remarks, speak to the Bill, and ignore interjections.
—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. I am properly replying to interjections made in this place.
—Mr Deputy President. I raise a point of order. Senator Mason has called on the Minister to withdraw his remark, which he found objectionable. That was his point of order.
—I did not hear that.
—Indeed, that is so.

—Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Senator Mason alleged that I had said things that I had not said and, therefore, the Minister took up the point that I was loth to take up but now find that I must. He said that I had said that the Kakadu National Park was of no value. I may have different values about the Kakadu National Park. I asked Senator Mason whether he knew how many people visited there each year. Senator Mason implied that I had said something entirely different. That is why the Minister said what he said. I feel it is not really necessary for him to withdraw what he said because what he said was true.

—Mr Deputy President, I wish to speak to the point of order. I distinctly heard Senator Townley ask how many people visit the park. That is not what Senator Mason claimed Senator Townley said. Senator Mason also went on to say that both Senator Townley and I were in the pockets of the uranium mining interests of Australia, which is grossly untrue.

—Mr Deputy President, that is not a point of order. If these people want to make personal explanations they can make them at the end of the debate. Let us not have personal explanations. Let us get on with the business of the chamber.
—Order!
—I am speaking to the point of order. The allegation made by Senator Mason was that Senator Baume was wrong in saying that Senator Mason was not telling the truth.

—Mr Deputy President, I take a point of order. Senator Mason is taking a position on this Bill which it is his right and prerogative to do. If interjections are made and answered in debate, honourable senators take what they get in this place. If they want to interject and they get a reply that is not satisfactory, so what? That is too bad. I think it is totally wrong for the Minister to take a point of order on a senator who is speaking when the Minister has the right of reply in this place. It is true that senators may be tired, but on all the empirical evidence that is available to us, we regard this as a negation of the Government's responsibility. If honourable senators on the Government side want to interject they have to be prepared to get a rejoinder which they may not like. There is obviously a difference of opinion. Mr Deputy President, I think you should therefore tell the Government senators that if they want to debate the matter they can put their names on the speakers' list but that they should cease their interjections when an honourable senator is making a speech.

—Order! I ruled earlier in the piece that there was no substance to the Minister's point of order. The matter has been going on from there. I believe statements have been made by honourable senators on both sides which probably are not strictly in accordance with the Standing Orders. I suggest that Senator Mason proceed with his speech and confine his remarks to the Bill.

—I am happy to proceed with my speech. I would hate to feel that I have in any way offended Senator MacGibbon and Senator Townley. I will withdraw my statement and substitute for it a statement merely that their utterances in this place and elsewhere over the years tend to indicate that they are very much in sympathy with the aspirations of foreign uranium mining companies.
—That is a restatement.
—That is a restatement.
—Order! Ignore interjections, Senator Mason.

—I think the Hansard record will prove that to be a statement of fact. I return to the Bill. As I have said, it distresses me greatly to find that honourable senators apparently have not listened to that message which I attempted to convey from the Gagudja people about their feelings for the national park. They feel that they have given the Australian people this great park and that now the undertakings they have been given are not being properly carried out. I again turn to environmental aspects. I have had information -I think this is a point Senator Mulvihill raised earlier-that the pollution problems connected with sulphides of heavy metals evident at Rum Jungle and Finniss River are a very likely possibility at the Koongarra site. That is another reason for the concern of the traditional owners and, indeed, for all of us in this country who see a duty to the future to retain this great national park for the Australian people in an uncontaminated form.

SPEECH.PARA: In totally economic terms, opening this area to the mining of uranium is a completely bad proposition. We know now that all over the world nuclear power is becoming increasingly discredited. We had the dangerous situation earlier this week where a nuclear reactor became a target for a military attack. It has set a precedent which could lead to great harm to the world and to us, as a species, in the future. A nuclear reactor, wherever it is put, and for whatever purpose, will be regarded as a military target. That enforces the Australian Democrats' view that the Government is among the lemmings of this world who are helping us towards a mutually assured destruction because of their support of this dangerous, uneconomic and contaminative industry. I suggest that events near Baghdad earlier this week ought at least to have driven that lesson a little further home to anyone who has any spark of intelligence and imagination whatsoever. Beyond that, demand for uranium has dropped dramatically in recent years.

The Australian Financial Review recently reported that oversupply is so great that yellowcake is heavily stockpiled in the United States of America and the price has dropped from $US43 a pound in 1978 to $US25 a pound in 1981. It is not only stupid of us to go ahead with the Koongarra mine but also it is completely unjustified on any economic terms for this country. Any uranium mine there can create only a bad oversupply situation. In fact, such a mine would be against the interests of Australia's existing mines, such as Ranger. There is some sympathy for that view even amongst our present uranium miners.

The Australian Democrats-I make this point quite plain-are utterly opposed to the mining of uranium anywhere in this country. I concede freely that our attitude in this debate is coloured and affected by that view, which we feel is thoroughly justified. We are extremely concerned at the massive problems of waste disposal, for which there is no sign of solution. We are worried about the security of plutonium, which is becoming worse as time goes on. We are concerned with the costing of such processes as long term waste disposal and the demolition of nuclear reactors. This has been instanced by the enormous costs, running to billions of dollars, and the length of time being required to clean up the Three Mile Island reactor. The world might have taken a warning from that incident. Luckily, we did not lose a lot of people as well. I take it some honourable senators would rather see us proceed with the industry to a stage where it killed thousands of people and contamined huge areas of civilised countryside. If that is what they want, so be it. The Australian Democrats will do their best to stop them.

If we dare to look at the mining of uranium without considering those factors, surely the uniqueness of the Kakadu National Park, the fact that this legislation would break faith with so many people both inside and outside Australia and the Government's blatant disregard for its own laws which are still on the statute book will convince honourable senators to vote against this legislation as I certainly shall be doing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Koongarra Project Area Bill 1981, which is designed to alter an excision area within the Kakadu National Park. Senator Mason, who has just spoken for the Australian Democrats, has admitted that his speech was based upon the opposition he has to uranium mining.
—I didn't say that.

—Perhaps I have misquoted the honourable senator; it was at least partly based on his opposition to uranium mining. I am most disappointed in the fact that he failed to refer to some of the provisions in the Bill, or to some of the facts which should be well known to everyone in relation to the excision and to the truth of the situation. I remind the Senate once again of what Senator Chipp said to the Senate the other day when he read us a little morality lesson, a little homily about how the Australian Democrats went to the people with the slogan 'Keep the bastards honest'. With a slogan like that, when he is talking about a matter, it is necessary that he tells not only the truth but also the whole truth. On this occasion facts have been omitted from the honourable senator's speech which I think does no credit to the Australian Democrats or the case they are putting up. Last night we heard an excellent speech from Senator Puplick in which he did something that others have not done. He brought the environmental impact statement into the chamber and quoted directly from it. He set out the facts and reasons why this Bill is appropriate and sound in an envionmental context. Why was it not mentioned this morning that there has been an environmental impact statement and that the problems raised have been appropriately answered? Last night Senator Puplick made it clear--
—You brought down the statement.

—I do not think Senator Mason was here for the speech last night. The environmental impact statement answers most of the questions which have been raised. Senator Puplick made one other point which Senator Mason has failed to comprehend. There is no more open way of proceeding. There is no better way to put matters into the public place for public scrutiny than to proceed by legislation. To proceed by bringing in a piece of legislation which is open to scrutiny and for debate in the Parliament is an appropriate way to move. For anyone to suggest that to proceed to achieve a legislative end by introducing a Bill, by coming into the Parliament and seeking legislation, is in some way sneaky, he must have the most topsy-turvy view of what the legislative process is all about. I think it illustrates that there are none so obtuse as those who do not want to understand. The procedural argument has absolutely no legs to run on. We are proceeding by legislation. We are doing it so that there can be open debate and of course that is obvious to anyone.

SPEECH.PARA: There is one other matter which I would have thought that a man who wanted to preach honesty to the Senate, and a party that wanted to preach honesty as the Australian Democrats did, might have thought to mention. They might have thought to mention that there is an excision in the park now. They might have thought to mention that this Bill is not setting out to create an excision--

TALK.START.PARA: —Because they don't know.

—Perhaps they do not know. Another feature of the Australian Democrats is that their degree of knowledge leaves something to be desired. This Bill does not establish an excision where previously there was no excision. Yet to listen to those who wish to give us these moral homilies, one might have thought that that was the case. An excision has been there for some time. It has been there since 1979, I believe. Why was that not adverted to in the speech by the honourable senator? What is proposed is not to create an excision from the park. It is in fact to alter the shape of the excision and to reduce it in size, to let us end up with a larger Kakadu National Park than we have now. Why was that not mentioned by someone who says he wants to 'keep the bastards honest'? It was not mentioned because it is more convenient for the honourable senator in putting his case to be selective in his presentation to the Australian people and to leave out those facts which he might find inconvenient or which might weaken his case. There is an excision now and all that is being proposed is that we alter the boundaries of the excised area.

SPEECH.PARA: It makes me sick to hear some of the arguments that have been put to us today. The new excision area is an improved excision area. It is environmentally more sound for the project, if the project goes ahead. I will refer to that in a moment. It takes the excision area which exists now away from some environmentally important and sensitive areas. As Senator Puplick set out last night had the honourable senator been here to listen to him--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I take a point of order.
—I am only giving as good as I get.
—I take a point of order. I was in this place last night when Senator Puplick was speaking. I resent the Minister repeatedly making allegations that I was not here.

—Mr President, on the point of order, I was here during Senator Puplick's speech and I did not notice the honourable senator. Of course I accept his assurance if he says he was here. I ask honourable senators: What will be the effect of failing to pass this Bill? An excision area will remain. Environmentally it will be a less satisfactory excision area. It will be an excision area that takes in more sensitive territory and will be an excision area that could allow for greater destruction of the park. Failure to pass this Bill would be foolish and would, in fact, fail to achieve the very ends which the honourable senator says he espouses and which other honourable senators say they espouse. Of course, one must come back to their total opposition to uranium mining and their desire to oppose any- thing to do with uranium mining to understand why they are taking the view that they are taking.

SPEECH.PARA: Someone says that we are behaving immorally. Someone says that he will come in here to keep us honest. This Bill has three clauses. The honourable senator failed to speak to one of them, the critical clause 2 of the Bill. Honourable senators would have thought that if he were going to tell us the whole truth that he might have adverted to clause 2 of the Bill. Clause 2 puts total control of this excision into the hands of the people of the Alligator Rivers region. We are of the view that this excision can take effect only if the Aboriginal people in the area give their consent.

TALK.START.PARA: —I quoted that.

—No. The honourable senator quoted from a Gagudju Association telex but totally failed, in his address, to acknowledge or pay attention to this clause. What does the clause provide? This clause is an earnest of this Government's good intentions and bona fides. We are not just making an assertion that we will go to the Aboriginal people; we are not just making a promise, by ministerial statement or Press release, that we will look to the provisional owners to give their permission; we are writing into the legislation the particular ways in which we shall require permission and approval from the traditional owners in the park. That gives to the traditional owners a power of veto over this whole excision and we are putting it into legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Has there ever been a more honourable, honest, proper and decent way to proceed on an excision? I will read part of clause 2 for honourable senators because those who spoke in opposition conveniently failed to address themselves to it. Clause 2 states:
Section 3 that is the excision-shall come into operation on a date to be fixed by Proclamation--
Not the date of royal assent but the date to be fixed by proclamation-

being a date not earlier than the date on which the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and the relevant Land Council have consented, in writing, for the purposes of sub-section 40 (1) of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976, to the making of a grant of a mining interest in respect of the relevant land . . .

So it goes on. The point is that it is within the control of the people of the region. If they consent in their good time, following the processes laid down in the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act, to the Koongarra project going ahead and if they advise me in writing and if I am satisfied, as Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, in terms of that land rights Act and if I then consent in writing then, and only then, can the excision come into operation. It is a perfectly clear, perfectly straightforward proposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —And a very honest one.

—And a very honest one. I thank Senator Kilgariff. We are converting an excision that already exists in a way that will enhance and improve the Kakadu National Park. We are doing it in a way which puts control of that excision into the hands of the very people who will be affected. It is an excellent Bill. It is a fair proposition and it is one that will work to the advantage of the Aboriginal people. They will have control of the whole process. Nothing could be fairer. To operate by legislation puts the whole matter before the Australian people. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: LANDS ACQUISITION (NORTHERN TERRITORY PASTORAL LEASES) BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 11 June, on motion by Senator Messner:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition expresses grave misgivings, as it did in the debate on the Koongarra Project Area Bill, about the support for the Lands Acquisition (Northern Territory Pastoral Leases) Bill perhaps on somewhat similar grounds because we believe that the Kakadu National Park ought to be inviolate and ought not to be changed in any way to suit the whims of those who wish to exploit the rich resources that exist. Whilst in some respects this legislation has a purpose which we regard as superficial-that of validating the Government's position in respect of the acquisition of these properties in the Northern Territory-it nevertheless shows that in due course the strategy of this Government will be to make them available for the purposes of uranium mining.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition doubts absolutely the integrity of this Government in respect of uranium mining and the rights of Aborigines in this region. We do not trust the Government. We have no faith in the Government's views and integrity, and the Aborigines have a similar view. In fact I believe the Australian people have a similar view. The fact is that the Government is totally immoral in seeking to force these Bills through the Senate in the dying hours of the session when it knows that the electors of this country have taken the very important step of changing the composition of the Senate. Because of some quirk those persons do not take their seats until 1 July. In fact, if the people who were elected in September last year as a direct result of the decisions of the electors had been able to vote the Government would not be able to ram through these pieces of legislation as though it has the moral right so to do.

I think the Democrats were correct when during the election of 1979 they used the phrase: 'Keep the bastards honest'. The fact that they were able to increase drastically their representation in this place, as indeed my party was able to increase its representation here, is an indication that the Australian people want the Senate to act as a brake upon the way in which this Government is operating, particularly in such sensitive areas as pastoral leases and other matters associated with Aboriginal land rights and Aboriginal rights, and the obvious conflict that exists in respect of mining companies which want to rip the guts out of our country without giving a continental about the basic views of the Australian people and the rights of the Aboriginals.

The Government is taking extraordinary steps. Not within living memory has the Senate sat day after day, night after night, into the early hours of the morning in order to rush legislation through the Senate before the electors' views can be properly expressed in this place. We regard all of this as a sneaky process by the Fraser Government. We would not have been put in this position if the Government had any decency or integrity at all. Therefore let me throw back into the face of any Minister or any Government member the suggestion that it is the Opposition, the Labor Party, the Independent and the Democrats who are acting improperly. It is the Government-from the top to the bottom-which is responsible for the sort of situation in which the Senate is now placed. The Senate has lost temporarily its position as a House of review. It is a rubber stamp for the Fraser Government.

Whilst it is true that we do not have any basic disagreement with some of the aspects of this legislation, because in essence it seeks to validate the compulsory acquisition made in June 1978 by the Commonwealth of the Mudginberri and Munmarlary pastoral leases in the Northern Territory, ostensibly to include them in stage 2 of the Kakadu National Park, the fact is that this Government has in the back of its mind, and is not saying so in this debate, to allow the Jabiluka uranium mining project ultimately to proceed. So, we test and challenge the sincerity of this Government. We say that the Government is not properly putting its basic position before the Parliament. As the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) has pointed out under the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act the two areas are subject to a current Aboriginal land rights claim which is now being considered by Mr Justice Toohey. Of course, it is pretty clear that that issue before Mr Justice Toohey will take a considerable time to resolve. We have no compunction, no testing of our security or our conscience in this matter, in proposing this motion:
Leave out all words after 'that', insert:

'the Bill be withdrawn and re-drafted to provide for the Munmarlary and Mudginberri Pastoral Leases to be included in their entirety in Stage II of Kakadu National Park without the excision of any portion of the leases for the purposes of uranium mining'.

The mining companies are fighting this Government every inch of the way. This Government, which claims to stand for small government, finds it necessary to introduce legislation in this place to establish public interest as far as these pastoral leases are concerned. This shows, of course, that we cannot operate on a principle of small government; government intervention is essential to protect the public interest. We are up against the powerful corporations which have influence with this Government and which use every opportunity to rip out and exploit the resources of this country. Even this Government, as much as it is a part of that process, is forced to act and to try at least to put up some semblance of protection of the public interest.

We are not opposed to the validation of Federal resumption of Mudginberri and Munmarlary leases to allow a successful conclusion to the land rights case and then for their inclusion in Kakadu National Park. But-this very important qualification was dealt with very adequately by the speakers on this side of the chamber in a previous debate-we are totally opposed to the mining of uranium ore from these or any other areas, and the Opposition therefore takes advantage of moving the amendment that it has.

The area in question includes Mudginberri and Munmarlary pastoral leases and vacant Crown land to the west of South Alligator Creek and almost to the East Alligator or the edge of Arnhem Land. Despite what Government spokesmen say, it is an area of environmentally sensitive wetlands which clearly must go into the Kakadu National Park forthwith without any recourse, without any pressure and without any suggestion that there should be uranium mining in the particular area. The pastoral leases, the subject of this Bill, are Munmarlary, held by the 2nd Pastoral Co. and Mudginberri, held by Mudginberri Station Pty Ltd. Both of these companies, as honourable senators ought to know, belong to the Northern Pastoral Services which in turn is a subsidiary of Pioneer Concrete owned by CSR. So we see the connection, the web, the network, which operates in these matters. It is clear that many of these companies are supporters of this Government. But in order to establish some defence of the principles involved in land rights, this Government is forced to bring down this legislation.

The Commonwealth and the companies concerned could not agree on compensation to be paid to the companies, so the properties were compulsorily acquired in June 1978. The properties were valued at $1.4m. The Commonwealth was prepared to offer $3m in compensation to these companies. We find that these companies, which are part of the big corporate sector which exercises too much economic and political power in this country, were not prepared to accept the Government's propositions and had the audacity, the temerity, the gall, to suggest that a sum of $10.5m ought to be the terms of settlement in respect to these areas. These companies which make gigantic profits at the expense of the Australian people and which will use every endeavour to take advantage of the natural resources which belong to the Australian people, seek a payment in excess of seven times the actual value of the land concerned. They have lodged challenges to the acquisition of the properties in the Northern Territory Supreme Court as late as seven or eight months ago. I think they were lodged in November 1980. Those challenges will take months or even years to determine. They have the effect, as a result of the greed and avarice of the companies concerned, of holding up the settlement of the Aboriginal land claims to the land in question. The companies are obviously more interested in collecting dollars and cents-as much money as possible-from the Commonwealth rather than retaining their leases. It is an indictment of the companies that they should take this shortsighted position.

The Government is clearly worried that if these court challenges take too long, Jabiluka, the big uranium mining proposition requiring Aboriginal approval, will not proceed before Australia is shut out of the world uranium market. I give credit to the Government speakers who spoke during the previous debate on this legislation and who set out to say what was part of the overall strategy of the Fraser Government in these matters. I understand that these areas will not be included in the stage two development of the Kakadu National Park until the Aboriginal claims are settled. I suppose to that extent the Opposition will be grateful for the time that it will take to resolve these matters because we will have a much better Senate at that time. We will be able to exercise our powers of review. We will be able to listen to the views of the Aboriginal people. We will be able to protect the public interest in these matters.

We can assume that when the land is duly held in trust for the traditional land owners of the Kakadu Aboriginal Land Trust under the legislative arrangements contained in the National Park and Wildlife Conservation Act and the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act the area will be leased to the Director of the Australian Parks and Wildlife Service. Then we can expect the Jabiluka area with its 206,000 tonnes of yellowcake to be excluded from the park when the Governor-General proclaims stage two. The danger area, of course, will be excluded, that exclusion having occurred under stage one. No doubt the Government will ensure that, unlike Koongarra, the boundaries of the area set aside for uranium mining are those designated by Pancontinental Mining Ltd. No doubt the mistakes which led to the shameful retrospective alterations to the Koongarra boundaries will not be repeated this time because we will have a much more watchful and a stronger view being expressed in this chamber. The end result will be that Jabiluka will become, like Koongarra, a uranium mining enclave within the famous Kakadu National Park.

Nobody has done more in this area than the Opposition to establish those important principles in respect of one of the most wonderful areas not only in Australia but also in the world. Koongarra itself is a valley on the edge of the Arnhem Land plateau. Ranger is in the lowlands below the escarpment. Jabiluka is on the very edge of the flood plains of the Alligator Rivers region. All these areas are situated on the edge of the proposed boundaries of stages one and two of Kakadu National Park. All three should be part of the park. We make no apologies for stressing that, for defending it and for attacking the Government on any suggestion that there should be changes in this area. What nation, what government except the Fraser Government, would nominate an area for World Heritage listing and then proceed to allow uranium mining-the most environmentally devastating form of mining-to proceed in that park's most beautiful and sensitive area.

If Government senators were really interested in the issue they would be listening to the views that have been expressed by that section of the Australian population which does accept its responsibilities in respect of environmental matters and which has conducted a public campaign on this matter. I am talking of the Total Environment Centre and other groups in Australia that keep informing the Senate and the people of Australia of what is happening in these sensitive areas. I applaud their attempts, as well as deplore the failure of the Government to listen to these very important watchdogs. Citizens groups have set themselves up to act in defence of basic rights and preservation of not only the Aboriginal people but also the important environmental areas. The Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony), the Northern Territory Minister, Mr Tuxworth, and the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, Mr Everingham, are always interested only in the exploitation of mineral resources in the area. While they may not say so publicly, they have basically rejected the way in which the operations of the developers take place. Nevertheless, they are seen to be opposed to this area of the Kakadu National Park being part of the World Heritage listing.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Chief Minister in the Northern Territory has viciously attacked Professor Ovington.

—Of course, because he is a short-sighted person, as indeed as are so many of our State political persons. They are unable to comprehend national responsibility and are unable to understand what we are talking about. Even this Government from time to time is forced to take a position well to the left of the position taken by such people as the Premier of Queensland, the Premier of Western Australia and the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory. They are at least 50 years behind in their basic understanding of what the world in the latter part of the twentieth century is about.

SPEECH.PARA: Again I want to make it clear to the Aborigines, as we have consistently in this place, that after winning this claim to the Mudginberri and Munmarlary pastoral leases under the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act they will have a veto over uranium mining on any section of their land excised from the park for that purpose. They will have the buffer of the Senate from 1 July to assist them in that process. We will be doing everything we can to influence decisions in that area. When I say that, I do not disagree that there are Government members who have adopted a position of honesty with respect to protection of Aboriginal land rights. Some former Ministers-none of them in this place-have used their position to confuse Aboriginal land owners in various land councils in Australia. If my memory serves me right, a case arose in, I think, Oenpelli when the Minister took extraordinary steps to create a state of confusion about what was happening in respect of that claim.

Whilst the Opposition accepts that some of the subsequent Ministers displayed a certain amount of integrity the fact is, of course, that they are subject to the majority view, the overall philosophical view and to the ideological position of the conservatives in this Government who really make the decisions-the Minister does not really make the decisions-in respect of all these matters. In the long term the Minister is forced to accept the decisions that are made by the Frasers, the Anthonys and those way-out type State leaders who have no concepts about the rights of the original people in our country. They certainly have a very bad negative attitude about the whole environmental movement in our country.

Section 40 of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act gives such a veto except over the Ranger uranium area on Groote Eylandt and areas where petroleum leases were issued prior to the land becoming Aboriginal land. It is true that Jabiluka is not in these categories, so the Aborigines will have the right of veto. They will be able to stop mining at Jabiluka-the largest, most unacceptable and most environmentally damaging mine. Of course, the largest deposit of uranium in Australia and perhaps in the world is at Jabiluka. Of course, that area is owned 65 per cent by Pancontinental Mining Ltd and 35 per cent by Getty Oil Development Co. Ltd. They are two of the great transnational companies whose power and influence extend much further, in many cases, than even those of governments and parliaments.

Whilst the Opposition concedes that there is some validity in the Government's intention, approach and legislation in these matters the Opposition wants to place on public record that it believes underneath the Government's intentions lies the very grave challenge to uranium mining and to all that that means in respect of the development of these areas so far as land rights, environment for Aborigines and maintenance of our basic environmental responsibilities in this area are concerned. Of course, the Opposition is concerned that an environmental statement has suggested that above-the-land development of this region would be detrimental. It has suggested, therefore, that we might have other options available to us and that we might be able to have underground mining in this region.

Of course, the razor gang's proposition that these matters be handed back to the States ought to be referred to in this debate. God forbid if the Government hands back to those three States that I mentioned any responsibility in this particular matter. We should not abdicate our responsibility as a national parliament which accepts national responsibilities for the protection of the environment, land rights and for an even greater involvement in the whole uranium industry.

I could go on to confirm what honourable senators have said in the debate on the Koongarra Project Area Bill but I shall not labour the point. I merely re-emphasise the question: To whom are we to sell our uranium? Although that is part of the total strategy of this Government, the answer to that question is not clear. What happened in the Middle East this week has shown us how fragile is the whole uranium industry. I refer both to its decline and to the use of uranium in an increasingly unstable environment. Such are the conditions that exist, for example, in the Middle East, that apparently one country can bomb out of existence a nuclear plant in another. These problems confirm that it is important for the Opposition, as the protector of the national interests, to say: 'If we take steps which will facilitate the development of the uranium mining industry in Australia, how can we at the same time place any faith in this Government, which has an open-ended position in regard to uranium mining? To whom is it to allow the companies concerned to sell the product? Which countries are to be allowed to buy the uranium that in due course will be produced in these areas? What guarantees have we that those countries will adopt a responsible attitude in the use of the uranium, as indeed certain major powers have done?

We must be concerned about events in the Middle East, about the conflict between Pakistan and India, and about the unstable regimes in Latin American countries, some of which aspire to become nuclear powers. Surely, in such an international climate, such considerations ought to be the principal motivation for the actions of any government which claims to speak on behalf of the Australian people. That is why the Opposition believes that an amendment should be agreed to which will place on the public record the fact that we cannot give our approval to any proposal that may, in view of the Government's strategy, allow in this area uranium mining which can prove so disastrous, firstly, to world peace, secondly, to the environment and, thirdly, to land rights, the protection of which, thank God, as from 1 July the Senate will accord a higher place on its agenda.
I move:
Leave out all words after 'That', insert:

'the Bill be withdrawn and re-drafted to provide for the Munmarlary and Mudginberri Pastoral Leases to be included in their entirety in Stage II of Kakadu National Park without the excision of any portion of the leases for the purposes of uranium mining'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Gietzelt for his speech. There is a genuine philosophical difference between the Government and the Opposition on the question of uranium mining and the honourable senator set out the case of his party with, I believe, care and moderation. The honourable senator knows that on this side the view is held that uranium mining, properly controlled, has caused no harm in the Northern Territory and will cause none. I wish to address my remarks on the Lands Acquisition (Northern Territory Pastoral Leases) Bill to the Aboriginal lands rights aspects. As Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, I have a particular interest in that aspect of the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind honourable senators that we are awaiting a report following a hearing on the Alligator Rivers land claim. That claim, which is important to the Aboriginal people, was mentioned by Senator Gietzelt in his remarks. It is important to the local traditional owners and to those who wish to see the Kakadu National Park properly established. It is also of great importance to the communities which have been waiting for this land claim to be resolved. The Land Commissioner, Mr Justice Toohey, will report within the next month or six weeks-certainly fairly imminently. His report can be acted on only if the land concerning which he reports is available for claim. If not, no grant of land can be made. Under the Aboriginal Land Rights Act I am required, once the Land Commissioner has reported-and I note in the chamber a former Minister for Aboriginal Affairs-to certify certain things. I am required to make a decision and to recommend that the grant of land be made to an appropriate trust. I cannot make that grant of land if it is not properly available for claim.

Some doubt has been thrown upon the capacity of the Aboriginal Land Commissioner to make his report. In fact, recently there was an action in the Supreme Court of the Northern Territory which sought to enjoin me and other people from proceeding to act upon the recommendations of the Aboriginal Land Commissioner on the basis that the case was not determined. It has been held over. It was withdrawn but the action will be started again. It was done on the basis that the acquisition in June 1978 by the Commonwealth of the two pastoral leases, Mudgenberri and Munmalary, may have been improperly made. We believe that we would win an action in court. There is no action at the moment but there could well be an action by the Northern Pastoral Services company if the Land Commissioner reported and if we proceeded to try to do something about giving the land to Aboriginal people. If the report were favourable and if it seemed appropriate there could be some action to frustrate that intention.

This Bill will put beyond doubt the capacity of the Land Commissioner to hear the claim and to make a report and the capacity of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to make an appropriate response in the light of that report. It will do that without removing from Northern Pastoral Services its rights as to compensation should in fact it take legal action and should it suggest that the June 1978 acquisition had not been properly made. The company's rights to proper compensation are not affected by this Bill. If the Bill were withdrawn and redrafted, as was suggested in the amendment, there is a real doubt as to the capacity of the Commissioner to do the things he needs to do or of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to respond as he might wish. The people who would be disadvantaged in that event are the traditional owners within the region who are waiting on the completion of this claim. When I was in the region they emphasised to me how serious and important this claim is to them. For those reasons I think it is inappropriate that we agree to the amendment because it would, in fact, impair or imperil the capacity of the Land Commissioner to do his job and of the people in the region to get the land which they wish to have.

I indicate to the Senate that I have had communications from Mr Eric Pratt, Q.C., counsel for the Northern Land Council, indicating that he believes that this Bill, as it has been drafted and amended, is appropriate to achieve the ends and he urges its early passage through the Parliament. I have also had a telex from Mr Eric Pratt, Q.C. which bears up, on the other matters raised by Senator Gietzelt. I will read from the telex because it will complete my argument and because I think it is important that it be in the record. The telex states:
Have seen Press statement issued today by Stuart West.
I take it he means the honourable member for Cunningham. The telex continued:
Statement contains major technical errors.

1. The mining is justified environmentally and economically and will result in substantial economic benefits to Aboriginals. Environmental requirements have been established and agreed to by Government, the supervising authorities and the Northern Land Council, so as to ensure protection of the environment.

2. Only one mine is proposed at Jabiluka-namely an underground mine to recover ore body No. 2. Our consultants agree with government and Pancontinental Consultants. Pancontinental Mining Ltd consultants that expected never to be exceeded maximum flood level is--
Here he uses a surveying term-

RL 10 metres. Mine portal will be at RL 26 metres and conveyor portal at RL 13 metres. There is no basis for the statement that due to water levels during the wet season that there is any threat of radioactivity leakage into the proposed park area.

I interpolate here that of course the traditional owners are concerned and of course the Northern Land Council is concerned that there should be an environmentally appropriate proposition before them. The telex goes on:

3. Jabiluka proposal is designed on a no water release system with superior technology considered and approved by Northern Land Council's consultant engineers. After receipt of all reports from the Northern Land Council's three consultant engineers and its consultant environmental geologist, the Northern Land Council on . . . June 8, 1981, delivered the following letter to Pancontinental:
Within the telex he quotes the letter. It reads:

'The Northern Land Council has completed its technical examination of the Jabiluka project as generally described in the final environmental impact statement dated July 1979 and in documents made available to the Northern Land Council and consultants engaged on behalf of the Council, which documents are listed in the attachments to this letter . . .
The Northern Land Council has no objections to the technical aspects of the Jabiluka project as therein generally described.'

We have from the Northern Land Council, representing the traditional owners, its authority to say that the environmental impact statement is environmentally sound and that the project need not be held up on that basis. The final line in the telex reads:
This information is supplied to you for use in Parliament.

I believe it is necessary for the successful and early conclusion of the land claim that this Bill be passed quickly. That is the reason it is before us now and not at some later time. It is before us now so that the Land Commissioner can report and we can act on his report. As I have indicated, we are not able to agree to the amendment moved by the Opposition. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be left out (Senator Gietzelt's amendment) be left out.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the last day of sitting and I think it should be again placed on record that this place is nothing but a rubber stamp for the House of Representatives. No Opposition amendments are agreed to or accepted by the Government. People outside should be reminded once again that this is not a House of review; it is just a fallacy for anyone to say that it is.
