The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Bill is a clarification of legislation which was imposed upon the Australian National University in accordance with Government policy last year and which has caused some problem in its interpretation. As a result of the problems, both the Council of the Australian National University and the Australian National University Students Association obtained legal opinions. Those legal opinions differed as to the proper interpretation of the legislation. The question of how what was passed last year was to be implemented became a matter of some concern. The net result has been that the Government has decided to put beyond doubt-presumably it hopes that that will be the result-the way in which it expects the legislation which it passed last year in relation to the compulsory nature or otherwise of student fees will be applied. That should be clarified beyond doubt and this Bill does no more than that.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not propose to participate in a division on this matter, should a division result, because as a Senate representative on the University Council, I would prefer to leave my position as one of interpretation. So far as is possible, I believe I should dissociate myself from the determination of the Parliament's will and, as a member of the Council, endeavour to interpret that once it has been clarified by legislation. I take the opportunity to say that it has been suggested sometimes that the University Council and the Students Association have acted other than with the best of good will and propriety--

TALK.START.PARA: —Not from us.

—I am not saying who made the suggestion. I believe both the University Council and the Students Association acted with total propriety in their attempt to determine what the legislation passed last year by this Parliament meant. It was necessary and desirable that whatever was the view of the Government and the majority, it should be clarified in the way in which it is in this Bill. That does not mean that every person agrees with the principle. I do not wish to debate the principle but I indicate that it was desirable and necessary to clarify what on earth the legislation passed last year really meant. This Bill attempts to do that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a few remarks at the Committee stage of the Bill. I endorse the remarks made by Senator Rae concerning the propriety of the behaviour of the Council of the Australian National University and the Australian National University Students Association. The reason that we have this Bill before us today is that the Government was unable to achieve, at its last legislative attempt, its true objective. Of course that objective has been to destroy the ANU Students Association. In 1979 the amendment was to ensure that membership of the Association be voluntary and, most importantly from the Government's point of view, that funds collected by the compulsory services and amenities fee would not be used for political activities and would not be expended on affiliation with the Australian National University. As Senator Rae has just suggested, the legislation was quite complicated. I believe the Council of the Australian National University tried in a most sincere fashion to understand how the legislation could be implemented.
—It spent an inordinate amount of time trying to do that.

—I take note of Senator Rae's interjection that it spent an inordinate amount of time trying to do that. I understand that and the frustrations of the University Council when it had to spend weeks of its time on what is essentially a very trivial and rather petty piece of legislation. The Council of the Australian National University ought to have better things to do with its time than to have to waste enormous amounts of energy on what is really an ideological attack on student unionism by the Fraser Government, delivered in a form which is truly a sledgehammer set to crack a nut. Unfortunately from the Government's point of view, its 1979 legislation did not have the desired effect. The ANU Students Association had other sources of revenue which the Council, following legal advice, decided were not subject to the constraints imposed by the 1979 amendment. Following the May 1981 meeting of the University Council, the ANU Students Association transmitted its affiliation fee to AUS from funds it had derived from sources other than the compulsory fee. That was an entirely legitimate and proper decision for it to make. So the piece of legislation before the Committee today is an attempt to succeed where the 1979 legislation failed. It makes income in any way derived from compulsory student fees subject to the same restrictions as student fees, that is, it may be only for the provision of amenities and services and not to support socio-political activities. Honourable senators can see that we are dealing with an extremely petty piece of legislation in which a government, which professes to oppose excessive regulation, imposes a particularly detailed and cumbersome set of restrictions on a student organisation.

SPEECH.PARA: The political aim of the Bill is clear. It attempts to prevent students at ANU from engaging in any organised socio-political activity through their Student's Association and it attempts to prevent the ANU Students Association from affiliating with the Australian Union of Students. Of course it is not difficult to see why the Government wants to pursue this course of action at this time. The Fraser Government is committed to dismantling the education system established by the Labor Government which was based on access to education as a right of all Australians. The Fraser Government wishes to replace this system with an education system based on privilege. In doing this the Government does not want a strong united national student union which will fight tooth and nail erosion of the Labor education system. The role of the AUS, I remind honourable senators, is like that of other unions. It looks after the interests of its members. This is why the Government would like to ensure that the AUS-as indeed it would like to ensure with all other unions in Australia-is weak and ineffective. The students of the Australian National University made a democratic decision that their student association should affiliate with the AUS. The Government attempts to overturn that democratic decision through this legislation.

I believe the legislation represents an improper use of parliamentary power to interfere with the internal affairs of the Australian National University. It attempts to remove from the democratic processes of the Students Association, decisions as to how its income will be spent. The ANU Council has endorsed the view that student organisations should be free to make their own decisions and manage their own affairs. In the light of that endorsement the Government's action is an insult to the University Council whose advice will now be ignored and experience disregarded. Just before the May ANU Council meeting, the Minister for Education, Mr Fife, wrote to the Council advising it to disallow transmission of student association fees to the AUS. He threatened that if the Council decided otherwise legislation would follow. This legislation is the result of that piece of Government blackmail against the Council of the Australian National University.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not so.

—By way of interjection Senator Rae suggests that something is not so. I repeat that Mr Fife wrote to the Council advising it that if fees were not disallowed then legislation would follow. If Senator Rae wishes to correct that, he will have the opportunity to do so. My advice is that there was a clear threat that the Council had to fulfil the Government's objectives regardless of the Council's interpretation of the legislation otherwise further legislation would be introduced to force the Council to carry out the objectives of the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The Labor Party's objection to this is quite obvious. We are perfectly confident in the ability of the Council to manage the affairs of the Australian National University. We are absolutely committed to the concept of democratic decision making by student organisations. We do not accept that this legislation or the legislation which preceded it is an appropriate use of parliamentary power. I think many Liberal senators would profess that they believe universities ought to be autonomous institutions insofar as the communities of the universities can determine their own affairs. For some years there has been an increasing onslaught on the Australian National University by the Fraser Government and it seems to me that there has been a most inappropriate use of the Parliament. Either the Government has confidence in the Council of the ANU or it does not. If it does not, I think we are dealing with a much more serious matter than how students decide to allocate the funds that are available to them. It is really a very serious erosion of what one would have thought would have been a principle supported on a bipartisan basis in this community, that is, the university ought to be able to run its affairs particularly in dealing with such relatively trivial matters as the way in which students decide to use the very small sums which they have at their disposal.

An article published in the Daily Mirror yesterday referred to Mr Philip Ruddock attacking the Australian National University for being involved in the practice of laundering huge sums of money. This is the kind of melodramatic statement and exaggeration that the Fraser Government likes to engage in.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ruddock always does that.

—As Senator Sibraa has pointed out, this kind of extravagant and melodramatic attack is in keeping with Mr Ruddock's general behaviour. I simply place on record the Labor Party's rejection of that claim. The whole concept of laundering money is insulting. It suggests an improper transmission of funds. As Senator Rae himself has said, the decisions made by the students' representative council were made on the understanding of the Council of the ANU itself that it was acting within what was intended by the legislation currently in operation. So the whole matter has been blown out of all proportion. The whole purpose of the legislation, as I have said, is that the Government does not want to see a healthy independent students' organisation that can adopt various political or social stances. We of the Labor Party endorse the rights of students, as we endorse the rights of all Australians, to participate freely in union activities and to make their own democratic decisions. It really is an appalling state of affairs when, on the last sitting day of what has been an extraordinarily exhausting, controversial and serious session of the Parliament, senators should have to be engaged in debating what, as I have said, is a petty and ideologically very biased attempt to interfere in the way that a few students want to run their affairs. Of course the Labor Party opposes the whole of the legislation outright.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to raise a couple of points. I have listened to Senator Rae. I reinforce what Senator Rae has had to say. It has been an embarrassment to the Senate representatives on the Australian National University Council. I am one of the representatives. It has been embarassing over the past two years almost in which we have been required to spend an extraordinary length of time on debating the requirements of the Government in respect of the use of funds. The Government has endeavoured to do something which I consider to be impossible. In fact, the provisions in certain clauses of the Australian National University Amendment Bill cannot really be carried out without extraordinary and continual supervision. If the previous legislation has failed to the extent that we need further legislation, this legislation also will fail. What it means, of course, is that the Council of the ANU, which has very important matters that concern it and other grave difficulties which it faces, has to spend further time debating this matter. It will have to spend extraordinary amounts of time in supervising-or endeavouring to supervise-or to carry out the requirements of the new legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I will vote against the legislation. I understand how difficult it is for Senator Rae and also for Senator Reid. Senator Reid also is a member of the ANU Council. She is, I think, the Governor-General's appointee to the Council. Three senators directly and indirectly represent this place on the Council. I do not doubt that Senator Reid fully realises the conflict of interest which arises from time to time. I do not know exactly what her views are. She may be given the opportunity to express them. It has been, according to the Chancellor, the Vice-Chancellor and the leading members of the Council, an unwarranted and unnecessary intrusion into the affairs of the University. Having spent a considerable amount of time endeavouring to carry out the wishes of the previous legislation, we are now faced with these amendments. Proposed new sub-section 3 states:
(3) Where an organisation of students receives prescribed moneys-
(a) it is the duty of the organisation-
(i) to apply those prescribed moneys and any moneys derived by that organisation from those prescribed moneys; and
(ii) to take all reasonable steps to ensure that any moneys derived by that organisation from those prescribed moneys and received by any person on behalf of the organisation are applied,

only in respect of the provision, for students liable to pay the fees out of which those prescribed moneys were made available, whether members of the organisation or not, of amenities or services that are not of an academic nature and are--

So it continues. It is a tortuous, confused and impossible sub-section. What it means, of course, is that if an organisation or an association within the university receives certain moneys, as has been prescribed by previous legislation, it cannot use those moneys to raise further moneys, except for the express purpose of the previous legislation. In other words, that organisation cannot, using those moneys, hold a function which raises money. It prevents those further moneys being used by that organisation to carry out the rest of its program. In other words, it cannot, if it wishes, pay affiliation fees to the Australian Union of Students because it has used moneys which have been provided to raise further moneys. In other words, if it puts the money in a bank account for a time and earns interest, that interest cannot be used to go beyond the demands of the Government in the previous legislation.

That might mean that the interest cannot be used; that it is direct income. I think that is wrong. Supposing that organisation runs a function on property which has been erected using prescribed money. It cannot allow that area to be used for raising any other moneys which may be used contrary to the wishes of the Government. Nor can it do anything with any moneys of that sort. The Council and the administration of the University have to follow out step by step the use of prescribed moneys to make certain that no subsequent moneys which are raised by that money, even to the third, fourth, fifth or sixth degree--

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you not know what laundering means, with AUS-run functions at the ANU? I bet you do know.

—All I can say to the honourable senator is that the students will find a way around this. That is why the legislation is impossible. If the Government wants to achieve its objective-that is to destroy AUS; it is as simple as that-further legislation will be required in this place. Because the students happen to be smarter than members of the Government who are trying to impose their will upon this organisation they will, if they want to, get around the legislation as simply and as easily as they have got around it previously.
—With the connivance of the university.

—I put on record Senator Withers's interjection that the university is going to connive in order to misuse fees. This is not money subscribed by the Government but money subscribed by the students themselves.
—Compulsorily subscribed by students.
—We accept that there is a compulsion on all people to pay certain moneys.
—I do not accept compulsory unionism in any form.
—The honourable senator accepts compulsory payments--

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Geitzelt-We carried legislation only yesterday--

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to start a fight on the last day.
—Peace, colleague, peace.
—The Minister did not set a good example in earlier legislation.
—Order! The Committee must allow Senator Georges to address himself to the Bill.

—I am addressing myself to a clause of the Bill, the provisions of which I believe are impossible to carry out. It is ridiculous and by its absurdity it fails. Might I also draw attention to the embarrassment which I and I believe other representatives from the Parliament have faced at the Australian National University as a result of attacks made by Mr Ruddock.
—Isn't he a member of the University Council?

—Yes, but he is also carrying out the initiative of the Government on the Council, to the embarrassment of the rest of us. It is an absolute disgrace. Anybody who has been to a university will appreciate how necessary it is to protect an environment that is free from government interference and intrusion. The Government's actions are foolish in that most students go through a time of intellectual debate, political and otherwise, which influences their development. This sort of legislation has the very opposite effect to the one the Government wishes. It does not reduce the militancy of various organisations, it increases it. It does not allow for the free flow of exchange between student and student. To me, it is an interference which is quite contrary to the tradition of universities in democratic countries, and that is why I object to what Mr Ruddock is doing. I object to the comments which Senator Withers has made by way of interjection. I also object to the remarks of Senator MacGibbon about laundering. In most instances laundering, in effect, is something of a semi-criminal nature. The honourable senator was actually saying that universities and student organisations are endeavouring by illegal means to use moneys in a way not prescribed by law. What we are doing is imposing a law-an extremely stupid law-which forces people to take what eventually people like Senator MacGibbon claim to be criminal actions. He has accused these people of using covert means to carry out their wishes.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me get back to the tradition of allowing campuses to remain free. I will come back to the clause. I ask the Minister to explain the clause. I know his views. He may take some highly debative stance to point out the weaknesses of my arguments. His speech will have nothing to do with the substance of my remarks but merely the form in which I have made them. I am always open to attack on that basis. If he would like to go beyond the method in which I have made my presentation, possibly he will agree with what I have said. Will the Minister describe how the Council can possibly do what is described in proposed new sub-section 3 (b)? Proposed new sub-section 3 (b) states:

it is the duty of the Council to take all reasonable steps to ensure that those prescribed moneys and any moneys derived by that organisation from those prescribed moneys are applied only as mentioned in paragraph (a).

I want the Minister to apply himself to that part of the provision and explain how he expects the Council to carry out that function? What sort of supervision does he expect the Council to carry out? How can it possibly carry out that sort of function? To what extent must the supervision be maintained? How is this money to be followed around? Are the bills to be marked and followed around the university? What will the Council do? Will it follow every action of every organisation? Senator Withers talks about compulsion. It is not compulsory for anyone to join any organisation on campus.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course it is.
—Of course it is. You don't know what you are talking about.

—Of all things, I belong to the Biblical Literature Society of the University of Queensland. If I looked back, I would possibly find that I belonged to about 20 organisations. But it was a voluntary decision by me about which organisation I joined. I did not join the Liberal Club.
—That is the crux of the matter.
—I did not join the Liberal Club because I decided of my own free will to join the Labor Club. There was no compulsion, and the honourable senator knows it.
—What about the students union? You are talking nonsense.
—The students union is the umbrella organisation.
—And it ought not to be.
—And it is compulsory, even under this legislation, for the Government to provide certain money so that Senator Withers, if he were at university, could engage in his favourite sport of rowing.
—No. Sports union fees are separate from student union fees.
—Sports union fees are separate these days but they are compulsory.
—Once more you do not know what you are talking about.

—They do not come under the prescription of this legislation. I am surprised at Senator MacGibbon. In any case, the honourable senator came from a faculty and profession which had no interest in general humanities. He is like doctors, dentists, chemists and engineers. They roll on to the confounded campus; they may as well have gone to a technical college for all the interest they show in the general environment of the university. It is not until one goes into the humanities that one properly understands what damage this sort of legislation does. I am incited now. Honourable senators have got me away from the point. I wish it were possible, for the sake of the record, that all of the interjections could be recorded.
—You can abuse all the other faculties, but you cannot abuse the Arts. You can say anything about the other faculties.
—It is good to see that Senator Withers is starting to take an interest in the place. Incidentally, I wish him success in the ballot. If he succeeds in that, I will no longer be bothered--
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a very difficult task to follow a speech such as that. I want to tackle only one point. I should like Senator Georges to give a legally binding assurance that no student function has ever been held for the purpose of raising funds for the Australian Union of Students and a profit declared from that function and transmitted to the AUS when the cost of operating that function exceeded the takings from it. If Opposition senators choose to call that a criminal activity, so be it. But that is my point. The purpose of this Bill is to deny the compulsory levying of union fees for socio-political purposes. It in no way restricts the levying of fees for legitimate student union activities, such as the refectory, the expansion of library services or any one of a dozen things that student unions do for their members which are clearly beneficial to the welfare of the students at the time that they are on the campus. That should be very clearly understood. Least of all is it an ideological attack on the Australian Union of Students, as Senator Ryan suggested.

SPEECH.PARA: What has happened with the student unions on Australian campuses is perfectly simple. They have made unionism compulsory. They have levied fees. By the way, the fees levied are not $5 or $10; in many universities they are around the $100 to $120 mark. I know that because I have to pay fees for one of my daughters. Those fees are used for political purposes, to attack the Government of the day and for other nefarious practices. I have been a student protester myself. I would deny no one the right to protest about government actions. But they can do that without the support of a compulsory union fee. That is the only point I am making. That is the point, of course, that the Labor Party will not grasp. It sees the unions as its umbilical cord, to get it into power and to keep it in power. That is why it is holding itself in abeyance to them.

It is a travesty that we should have free tertiary education-in fact, free education-in this country, except for compulsory union fees. Students have to pay those fees. What a perversion of a system it is that one has to pay union fees to be a university student. Yet, all tuition fees are paid by the Australian taxpayer. That is the thing that sticks in my craw. That is the thing that I will not tolerate. The worst part about it is the way in which the university administrations around Australia support the unions' position. I find it intolerable that university administrations will say to students such as my own daughter: 'If you do not pay your compulsory union fees you cannot enter for university examinations and if you could enter for university examinations we would not award you a degree at the end'. I think that is intolerable. The intent of this Bill is to remedy that situation in respect of one university.

I hope in time that this Government will move to legislate that as a condition of all tertiary educational institutes in Australia receiving funding, either directly or indirectly-I refer not only to universities but also to colleges of advanced education and the rest of them-so they have to provide full services to students, and so that they can not turn around to students and say that because they have not paid their compulsory union fees therefore they cannot enter for university examinations. I hope that the Government legislates to do that. That, of course, was the intention of this Bill when it was brought in two years ago. We had hoped that by setting an example as to what we thought was a fair and equitable social system of education the other universities in Australia would have seen the light and followed course. To my great regret they have not done this. The other State universities, including to my eternal regret my own State of Queensland which professes to be a free enterprise State and has a non-Labor government, have shown a marked reluctance to do anything to get rid of compulsory union fees.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Rae very clearly stated the problem that the Australian National University and the Australian Union of Students found because of opposing legal views presented to them. That has been very clearly spelled out. The necessity for this legislation is encompassed in just that one sentence of Senator Rae. Senator Ryan considers that this Government is irresponsible in passing legislation to clarify the intention of this Parliament when it passed legislation last year. I am sick and tired of hearing from members of the Opposition lectures on the parliamentary system and the rights of people in this Parliament. Every day we receive lectures to the effect that we are putting through legislation faster than they think we should. They claim that senators have certain rights, but when a matter goes against what honourable senators opposite believe in, those rights suddenly disappear. We are told that the intention of the legislation which was passed in this place last year should not be given effect to. The Bill merely seeks to justify and clarify the intention of this Parliament. Honourable senators opposite are saying that the Committee should not agree to the Bill. Senator Ryan was not debating the rights or wrongs of the matter. She was debating the fact that legislation was passed and the Government was forcing the universities, by passing this Bill, to carry out certain things.
—You try to dictate to the universities but you never dictate to the multinationals.

—All I can take from the interjections and speeches of Opposition members is that once again they have not a clue about freedom in this community. In their true, socialistic fashion they say: 'We will say what is right. If it suits our policies people must pay'. Because the Students Union is very politically motivated, they are saying that every student must financially support that political motivation and we will say that this is enforceable. Senator MacGibbon spelled out very clearly the fact that there is indeed freedom of education in Australia, but at the moment there is in the universities a compulsion for students to pay for political activities of which they have no intention to be part. That is compulsion. We are merely removing that compulsion and allowing students who wish to be part of that political activity to finance it. Students who do not wish to be part of it should have the choice not to fund it. It is as clear as that, but it does not suit the Opposition that such freedom of choice should be extended.

—It might be appropriate for the Government to become involved in the debate at this stage and to indicate to the representatives of the Australian National University who are in the chamber that their difficult position is comprehended and appreciated. This measure relates to the Australian National University because of the direct relationship that the Government has with the ANU-one that it does not have with a number of other universities. As I understand the issue, it relates to fees which are levied compulsorily for certain purposes. I understand that the Bill is designed to ensure that the intention of the Government's 1979 amendments is fulfilled.
—To ensure that they can be understood and put into effect.

—I appreciate my colleague's interjection. I understand that the University had certain advice as to its legal position and acted within that advice, but the Government wishes its intentions to be better understood and put into effect. The purpose is to make the Government's intention clear and seek to have the university accommodate it. The arguments as to why legislation was necessary were put two years ago. I note that Senator Withers is in the chamber. I recall the role played by Simon Withers in bringing to our attention some years ago certain problems with which people had concern. All the Government is merely seeking today is to clarify the 1979 legislation. I urge honourable senators to acknowledge that intention and express the hope that the legislation will receive a speedy passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: — Mr President--
—I have tried to be conciliatory.

—The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has done very well. But he did not actually indicate in reply to the question I asked how this would be carried out. I would like to find out how much further we have to involve ourselves in legislation in order to carry out the wishes of the Government. I want to say that the Australian National University received legal advice and found that moneys raised and used as prescribed had been dealt with quite legally. Let us forget what Senator MacGibbon said about the Council running some function and paying more to the Australian Union of Students than it raised. It does not need to do that. Any function the Council wishes to organise to raise funds, for example by employing a band, raises three or four times the amount expended on the function. This is what it generally does to raise further moneys. This legislation will now make this impossible. The Council does not engage in any of those stupid propositions just outlined by the Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: That was the way in which many Liberal Party supported organisations used to run their functions. They used to get around the law by running a function for charity, the expenses for which would be about $5,000 and the amount that went to charity about $10. If honourable senators are talking about evading and getting around the laws and regulations of this country that is something that has been practiced in the past. I ask honourable senators not to start talking about a few students trying to raise a bit of money to carry out some of their activities. They will do it very well indeed.

Senator Walters mentioned the matter of compulsion. I will answer that point. There are wide areas of compulsion which I have to accept. For a long period, one of these has been to pay tax. It is compulsory for me to pay tax in a variety of directions. I have no right and no control over where that money flows. I objected to our involvement in the Vietnam war but there was no way in which I could have said 'I refuse to pay that portion of my tax which supports the war'. There are certain areas where there is a certain compulsion that is acceptable and necessary. Certain fees that we have to pay in certain areas are subject to compulsion. Senator Walters argument does not hold. I will now come back to the fact that I would like the Minister to explain how it will be possible to carry out the legislation. Will he explain to me how the Australian National University administration will, without unnecessary expense, maintain the wishes of the Government?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that the honourable senator referred to line 4, page 3 of the Australian National University Amendment Bill. I remind the honourable senator that it says that it is the duty of Council to take all reasonable steps. I think it might be appropriate to leave the matter as generally as that. In that case it might be as much an earnest as possible of our desire to have the University Council involve itself in trying to answer that question. I do not think that at this stage we want to be more specific. I think that a Council with the skills, capacity and experience of the ANU Council will find a way to interpret that requirement 'to take all reasonable steps'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Christmas Island Agreement Amendment Bill 1981 follows the report of the Sweetland Commission of Inquiry into the Viability of the Christmas Island Phosphate Industry. That report is an important one and stems largely from the activities of the workers on the island, who believe they have been ignored by governments over a considerable time-with the exception of the period of the Whitlam Administration. They have been acting correctly through their own union, the Union of Christmas Island Workers. These activities were born out of desperation in the face of the lack of concern shown by this Government for their plight and their future because of the limited nature of the industry. So in a very real sense this Bill is due to their efforts, not to the concern of the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill will rectify some of the problems on the island-but by no means all of them-that have emerged since the Australian Labor Party last held office in 1975. In the period from 1972 to 1975 we had many concerns about the island and its future. We were concerned about the continual attitude adopted by the conservatives in this country and about the colonialist and discriminatory policies being applied to those working for the Christmas Island Phosphate Commission. Of course, previous conservative administrations took advantage of certain disabilities arising out of the way in which the Christmas Island Phosphate Commission operated. They relied largely upon the difficulties relating to the administration because of the involvement of other countries.

The Bill provides that the British Phosphate Commissioners will be replaced on the island as managing agents for the Christmas Island Phosphate Commission by an Australian Government owned and controlled company. We are very pleased that that step has finally been taken. It is something for which we have constantly pressed, as have the workers on the island. We have overcome this last vestige of colonialism and have established a much more effective administration. After 1 July this year there will be a Christmas Island Phosphate Company. Because the Bill seeks to set up such an administration, naturally the Opposition supports it. My party notes that the appointment of the Chairman has been announced. He will be a very distinguished former public servant, Mr George Warwick Smith, who has had a very long and distinguished career in the Australian Public Service. We do not quarrel with that appointment either.

The Christmas Island Phosphate Company will actually mine the phosphate on Christmas Island. This will be carried out basically on a non-profit basis, even though the company will act in accordance with basic commercial principles. We are pleased that occasionally some of our philosophical views come through as they are doing in this legislation. The Christmas Island Phosphate Commission is no longer required to have British Phosphate Commissioners as managing agents. Eventually, the Christmas Island Phosphate Commission itself will be wound up. This depends upon a final agreement with the New Zealand Government. Surely it has to be conceded that there has been a very unusual arrangement in respect of this area for very many years. Unlike the Government's action with the Australian Wool Testing Authority where a series of organisations seem to have been set up, in this instance there is evidence that the Government actually knows what it is doing. We applaud it for taking that positive step. Rather than opting out we are opting in.

The second thing the Bill does is to enable the Christmas Island Phosphate Commission to transfer stockpiles at the manufacturers' plants in Australia and New Zealand to the respective governments. Finally, the Bill reflects impending changes in purchasing and distribution arrangements for phosphate by removing the requirement on the Christmas Island Phosphate Commission to dispose of Christmas Island phosphate in conjunction with phosphate supplied from other sources by the British Phosphate Commissioners. As from 1 July the responsiblity of the BPC will be transferred to the Australian Phosphate Commission. Those are the positive aspects of the legislation. It appears that eventually we will have a Christmas Island phosphate company which will mine the phosphate and also look after the municipal type functions on the island. The Australian Phosphate Commision will assume responsibility for the purchasing and distribution of Australia's phosphate requirements. We are not quite at that step yet. There will still be a need for the Parliament of Australia to exercise some jurisdiction and supervision of the municipal functions which will be assumed.

The manufacturers will take over the shipping of the phosphate presently being undertaken by three ships of the Australian National Line under long term charter to the British Phosphate Commission. The Opposition believes that the new arrangements are sensible but we would expect the new organisation, owned and controlled by the Australian Government, to take decisive steps to look after the people on the island in a less paternal way than has occurred in the past. The Sweetland Report on the viability of the island's phosphate deposits brought these matters into full focus. Briefly, the report stated that Christmas Island is viable and that there are at least eight more years of rock on the island, even given the payment of workers at Australian federal minimum award wage rates. That is a very important recognition of a basic wage requirement by the Fraser Government. We have allowed the British Phosphate Commissioners to discriminate against workers on the island for all the years that the rock has been extracted from an Australian territory. We must all surely recognise that the island contains a multi-racial society. The Sweetland report stated that the British Phosphate Commissioners did not adapt to the passing of colonialism. I refer the Senate to page 3 of the report which stated:
The institutional framework within which Christmas Island operates is outmoded, discredited, and in many ways repugnant.
It is very difficult to overcome that criticism in 1981. The report continued:

Many of the Island's problems can be traced to this fact. The British Phosphate Commissioners (BPC) is an organisation which has not adapted quickly enough or willingly enough to the passing of the colonial era. Its shareholders, the governments of Britain, New Zealand and Australia, have not required it to adapt to these changes. Responsibilities ultimately rests with those governments and their servants. The structure of the Government Administration on the island and much of the law that is in force, is more appropriate to a colonial possession than it is to a remote multi-racial mining community on Australian territory.

If ever there is an indictment of conservative governments in this country, New Zealand and the United Kingdom it is that comment by the person appointed by this Government to inquire into the problems on the island. We know that some of the leaders of the union representing Christmas Island workers have been traduced, criticised and pressured into taking a less militant position in order to rectify the last vestige of colonialism within Australian territories.

My main criticism of the report was that apart from the wages issue it advocates major changes in the organisation of phosphate mining on Christmas Island. But nowhere in the report was it suggested that the members of the work force, who obviously will be greatly affected by the suggested changes, should in any way be consulted. One would have thought in this modern age, when there are moves taking place in most countries of the world about worker participation, worker control, worker consultation, that the Government would have consulted the work force in a much more consistent and proper way.

The weakness that exists in many government reports that come down from time is that the people most likely to be affected by any proposed changes are rarely given the opportunity to have their voices heard. They are rarely consulted. I think it is a matter to which this Government, conservative as it is, ought to be giving much more serious consideration. If it wants to stay contemporary it should take up a position that is now accepted by a wider variety of private organisations as well as many governments all over the world. If the workers' lifestyle, environment and future are to be affected by these changes-I am sure they will be; that is as sure as night follows day-a consultative process ought to be set in motion which at least will allow to be heard the views of those who will be affected by the change. After all this new company will take over the municipal responsibilities. That is important because it deals with a whole range of matters which we know are part of municipal charters of local government in our country. There ought to be some process by which the views of the people and the workers are noted.

Whilst I accept the fact that the Sweetland report is a very good report, we should not be making recommendations without consulting those who are affected by them. More consideration should be given to avenues of consultation with those who will be affected by the very dramatic changes that will come about as a result of the passage of legislation. As from 1 July the changes not only will be noted in this place but also will be very much apparent on Christmas Island. However, it is generally the case in Public Service industries that those who will be affected by the considerable number of reports presented to the Parliament are rarely given an opportunity to present a view or to have their views incorporated in the report. Although broadly the Opposition agrees with the trend of the Bill there is no evidence that this Government is prepared to take that aspect into consideration.

I ask the Minister: What arrangements are being made in these matters? I ask also about a whole number of other matters which he might very briefly refer to in his reply. What arrangements are being made to provide in the future for teachers on the island and other territories? I also ask about the health care of people on the island. Previously industrial awards on the island incorporated free health care provisions for what I understand to be quite long-standing historical reasons. So, given the Government's about face and the five changes it has made to medical arrangements in this country, I think those are relevant questions and I ask the Minister to give some consideration to them in his reply.

Finally, the most crucial matter is the long term future of the island and the island's industry. The security and stability of employment is naturally of the greatest concern for those who live on the island. I understand that Mr Sweetland, who wrote the report, is currently examining these matters. Of course we await his consideration of them because the livelihood of many people is at stake. I hope that the Government will not take the view that that is not an important consideration for the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek the approval of the Senate to incorporate in Hansard a letter, a copy of which is in the possession of Senator Baume, sent to me by the Hon. Ian Wilson, the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. The letter deals with the attitude of the Government on the preservation of the habitat of the Abott's Booby bird.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Minister for Home Affairs and Environment Parliament House Canberra, A.C.T. 2600
Dear Senator Mulvihill,
I refer again to your letter of 9 April 1981 drawing my attention to your remarks in the Senate on 8 April 1981 concerning threats to Abbott's Booby on Christmas Island.

I note that on 9 April 1981, in his response to your remarks, Senator Baume pointed out that the moratorium on further jungle clearing in certain central and western areas of Christmas Island could be extended while results of the survey of Abbott's Booby are being considered. I am now able to advise you that the moratorium has been extended until 31 May 1981 to permit further consideration of options recommended by Professors J. D. Ovington and J. M. Cullen and Dr J. B. Nelson in their 'Appraisal and implications of a survey (1979-80) of Abbott's Booby on Christmas Island'.

The Government is committed to the protection of Abbott's Booby. After the present detailed consideration of the report findings has been completed there will be an announcement of actions being taken to ensure the long-term survival of the species on Christmas Island.
Yours sincerely,
IAN WILSON
Senator J. A. Mulvihill,
Commonwealth Parliament Offices,
Chifley Square,
Sydney N.S.W. 2000

TALK.START.PARA: —Stemming from that letter, I am interested to know who ultimately will be responsible for the decision-making when it is determined that jungle clearing will cease forever more on Christmas Island and thereby preserve the Booby bird's habitat. This Bill sets up the new Christmas Island Phosphate Company and the New Zealand Government has a vested interest in it. I put this in clear terms to Senator Baume: Will the decision be made by the board of the new phosphate company as to the ambit of its mining operations? Conversely, will the Honourable Ian Wilson, as the Minister responsible, decide that? Will it be a decision for the Cabinet of the Australian Government? Will the Australian Government have to hold talks jointly with Mr Muldoon? They are the questions I want answers to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their support of this Bill. This Bill seeks to improve the situation on Christmas Island. Honourable senators on both sides of the Parliament are in agreement with the provisions in the Bill. I respond firstly to the points raised by Senator Mulvihill concerning the Abbott's Booby bird. The honourable senator is very well aware of the appraisal and implications of the survey of the Abbott's Booby bird on Christmas Island.
—A very comprehensive report.
—A very comprehensive report by Professor Ovington, Professor Cullen and Dr Nelson. This report is in the hands of the Government.
—The Duke of Edinburgh has a passing interest in this.

—Not only does the Duke of Edinburgh have a passing interest, but also I did notice when I was reading the assessment that on the inside cover some of his comments are quoted. The Government is working towards a response on this appraisal by late August. In the meantime the moratorium which is protecting the Abbott's Booby bird has been extended to the end of August. At that stage a decision will be made by the Government.
—Our Government?

—Consultations are taking place with New Zealand now. It will be a government decision, but the implementation of the decision will then be in the hands of the new company. There will be a response towards the end of August. As I have said, the moratorium has been extended to make sure that protection continues, as the honourable senator would want.
—Will it be on a Prime Minister to Prime Minister basis or will it be on a ministerial basis between our Minister for Home Affairs and Environment and New Zealand's equivalent?

—I take note of the honourable senator's interjection. I cannot answer him. In the end it will be a decision which, I think, will be taken by government, but at what level I do not know. I will try to find that out for the honourable senator.

SPEECH.PARA: Several queries have been raised by Senator Gietzelt. The whole question of reorganising in regard to Christmas Island has been a difficult one. There was a period in the early 1970s when Labor governments were in power in all three countries involved at the same time. It has been difficult-not just on the question of ideologies-to get the package put together. The honourable senator did ask me about union involvement. Christmas Island unions were involved in consultations on the implementation of the Sweetland report. I understand that the Australian Council of Trade Unions will have a representative on the board of the new Christmas Island Phosphate Company. So there will be very direct trade union input in the area which Senator Gietzelt mentioned.

The other matter that was raised concerned medical care for workers on Christmas Island. It is a little early for me to give a response on that question. I understand that previously free medical care was obtained in Perth for the workers from Christmas Island. The honourable senator will be aware that the administrative details to put the new arrangements that have been announced into operation are presently being negotiated. Part of the negotiations will be the arrangements for medical care for Christmas Island workers. Negotiations and discussions are going on now to try to resolve that matter. It might be most appropriate if we take a record of the honourable senator's concern and as soon as we have some kind of an answer we will make the information available to him. I thank honourable senators for their support on this Bill.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

Senator Peter Baume-Madam Acting Deputy President, I comment, before I move the appropriate motion, that today we have two temporary chairmen, one Senator Davidson, reporting to the other yourself, Senator Melzer, and both of you are leaving the Senate tonight. I pay tribute to the work which you both have done in the Chair over a number of years.
Bill (on motion by Senator Peter Baume) read a third time.
