That the Bill be now read a second time.
Senator Robertson-Mr Acting Deputy President, while you are moving into the chair, I reinforce the views expressed by my colleague from the other side of the chamber.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure Senator Melzer and I appreciate what you have said.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Melzer-If only we could always have that sort of co-operation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Melzer Sen J.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition, whilst believing that there must be some amendments, welcomes the introduction of this legislation to ratify the 1972 Convention on the Prevention of Marine Pollution by Dumping of Waste and Other Matter. Australia signed that Convention in 1973. We question why it has taken eight years to get to this point of ratification of a matter that is so vital to Australia and to the world. It is as well to look at the definition of 'dumping' as defined in the Convention. Article III states:

SPEECH.PARA: For the purposes of this Convention:
1. (a) 'Dumping' means:
(i) any deliberate disposal at sea of wastes or other matter from vessels, aircraft, platforms or other man-made structures at sea;
(ii) any deliberate disposal at sea of vessels, aircraft, platforms or other man-made structures at sea.
The definition goes on to include things that are not identified as dumping. I seek leave to incorporate Article III of the Convention in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take it, Senator Melzer, that that article is capable of incorporation?
—It is.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The article read as follows-
ARTICLE III
For the purposes of this Convention:
1. (a) 'Dumping' means:
(i) any deliberate disposal at sea of wastes or other matter from vessels, aircraft, platforms or other man-made structures at sea;
(ii) any deliberate disposal at sea of vessels, aircraft, platforms or other man-made structures at sea.
(b) 'Dumping' does not include:

(i) the disposal at sea of wastes or other matter incidental to, or derived from the normal operations of vessels, aircraft, platforms, or other man-made structures at sea and their equipment, other than wastes or other matter transported by or to vessels, aircraft, platforms or other man-made structures at sea, operating for the purpose of disposal of such matter or derived from the treatment of such wastes or other matter on such vessels, aircraft, platforms or structures;
(ii) placement of matter for a purpose other than the mere disposal thereof, provided that such placement is not contrary to the aims of this Convention.

(c) The disposal of wastes or other matter directly arising from, or related to the exploration, exploitation and associated offshore processing of sea-bed mineral resources will not be covered by the provisions of this Convention.

TALK.START.PARA: —It should be remembered that there has been an increasing inclination of late to dispose of waste by incineration at sea. A resolution made at the third consultation meeting in 1978 stated that incineration at sea was an interim measure for waste disposal pending the development of better solutions and that the intention of the adoption of mandatory provisions for the control of incineration at sea is not to increase the amount of waste incinerated at sea for which there are practical land-based methods of disposal. There has been increasing pressure from industry in Australia to allow for more disposal of waste at sea. Senators will recall the pressure to bring incineratorial ships to Australia for the disposal of toxic wastes. But we must never forget that the sea is not the ideal receptacle for waste. Pollution of the sea could affect the world's population far into future generations. The two opening paragraphs of the preamble to the Convention that we are ratifying state:

SPEECH.PARA: Recognizing that the marine environment and the living organisms which it supports are of vital importance to humanity, and all people have an interest in assuring that it is so managed that its quality and resources are not impaired;
Recognizing that the capacity of the sea to assimilate wastes and render them harmless, and its ability to regenerate natural resources, is not unlimited;

It is imperative that we look at the disposal of waste very carefully. We must make industry in Australia take full responsibility for disposing safely of the waste it produces, or we must look carefully at the part that that industry plays in our lives and whether the industry is necessary if it is to continue to need to pollute. Many industries will only look to their processes and the necessity for updating or changing to a safer method of processing if they are forced to by being held responsible for the wastes they produce which can endanger life on earth and can certainly endanger life in the sea.

Although there have not been many horror stories to date of the results of dumping of toxic chemicals into the sea from ships, there have been many examples of shore-based dumping into the ocean. The most notable was the dumping of mercury into the sea off Minamata Bay in Japan. The residents ate fish and other marine life that was heavily contaminated with mercury. As a result, the acute mercury poisoning they suffered became known as Minamata disease. By April 1977, 1,076 residents of Minamata were certified victims of the disease and 3,000 others were awaiting examination. Needless to say, mercury as well as cadmium, another environmental poison which became publicly prominent from massive health problems in Japanese waters, are both on Annex I and are totally prohibited from being disposed of in the ocean. Other metals, such as arsenic and zinc, are on Annex II and will require special permits for dumping.

It was the zinc contaminated oysters of the Derwent estuary in Tasmania which gained notoriety early in the 1970s when one was analysed and found to contain 26,000 parts per million of zinc. It should be noted that the Electrolytic Zinc Co. of Australia Ltd is the only company in Australia regularly to dump wastes into the sea. It does so in 1,500 metres of water south of Hobart. The company would like to move to shallower waters for cost reasons. Toxicity tests on the company's wastes are being carried out for the company in the United States of America on an American species of fish, not those normally found in the area where the company has dumped or hopes to dump. We feel that any research that is carried out to determine the suitability of the application for a dumping permit should logically be done under Australian conditions. Indeed, up until now we have had really precious little information about what has been dumped in Australian waters. We have precious little information about what amount has been dumped or where it has been dumped.

I would like to quote from evidence given to the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment during its investigation into marine science. It was pointed out that the then Department of Science and the Environment was responsible for regulating marine dumping through a voluntary scheme in accordance with the London Dumping Convention. Of course, why we are debating this Bill today is so that it will no longer be wholly voluntary. Officers of the Department were asked a number of questions about dumping. The transcript of evidence stated:

Mr Fletcher-At the moment, dumping in Australia is controlled in accordance with the London Dumping Convention which was signed by Australia in 1973. A number of dumping operations are going on around Australia at the moment and we are co-operating with industry and State governments to control those operations in line with provisions of the London Dumping Convention.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are we dumping?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Fletcher-Off the coast of New South Wales a number of vessels have been disposed of to build an artificial reef. In Tasmania a number of industrial dumping operations have occurred.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you mean by that?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Fletcher-Electrolytic Zinc Company of Australasia Ltd has undertaken dumping operations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that dumping of waste at sea?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Fletcher-Yes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Appendix A of the Department's submission says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Department is responsible for regulating marine dumping through a voluntary scheme . . .
What is 'voluntary' about it? Do people do it and then tell you?
Mr Fletcher-At the moment the Commonwealth has no legislation to ratify the London Dumping Convention. It is being discussed between the Commonwealth and the State governments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does that mean we have no control over it?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Fletcher-There is a measure of control through an old Act of Parliament but it does not pick up all the facets of the London Dumping Convention.

TALK.START.PARA: —What sort of control does this old Act of Parliament give?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Fletcher-It is the Beaches, Fishing Grounds and Sea Routes Protection Act and it relates only to identifying a number of dumping sites and specifically controlling disposal of derelict vessels and quarantine wastes around the coast.

TALK.START.PARA: —When you say it identifies dumping sites do you mean that material can be dumped on those sites only?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Fletcher-The Act relates to the disposal of derelict vessels and quarantine wastes. It does not extend to other wastes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does this voluntary scheme in fact mean that your Department has control over dumping in the ocean only if somebody tells you that he has dumped something?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Fletcher-For material to be dumped at sea it has to be transported to the sea and the Department of Transport has certain controls regarding what sort of material is carried on vessels. So there is some measure of control through the Department of Transport.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Department of Transport informed by the vessel that it is carrying a certain product to a spot for it to be dumped overboard?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Fletcher-Through ports and harbour authorities we are often aware what vessels are carrying.
And so it went on. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard this small piece of evidence from the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

TALK.START.PARA: —In appendix A it reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The Department is responsible for regulating marine dumping through a voluntary scheme in accordance with the London Dumping Convention.
Could you expand on that for me?

Mr Fletcher-At the moment, dumping in Australia is controlled in accordance with the London Dumping Convention which was signed by Australia in 1973. A number of dumping operations are going on around Australia at the moment and we are co-operating with industry and State governments to control those operations in line with provisions of the London Dumping Convention.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are we dumping?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Fletcher-Off the coast of New South Wales a number of vessels have been disposed of to build an artificial reef. In Tasmania a number of industrial dumping operations have occurred.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you mean by that?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Fletcher-Electrolytic Zinc Company of Australasia Ltd has undertaken dumping operations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that dumping of waste at sea?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Fletcher-Yes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Appendix A of the Department's submission says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Department is responsible for regulating marine dumping through a voluntary scheme . . .
What is 'voluntary' about it? Do people do it and then tell you?
Mr Fletcher-At the moment the Commonwealth has no legislation to ratify the London Dumping Convention. It is being discussed between the Commonwealth and the State governments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does that mean we have no control over it?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Fletcher-There is a measure of control through an old Act of Parliament but it does not pick up all the facets of the London Dumping Convention.

TALK.START.PARA: —What sort of control does this old Act of Parliament give?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Fletcher-It is the Beaches, Fishing Grounds and Sea Routes Protection Act and it relates only to identifying a number of dumping sites and specifically controlling disposal of derelict vessels and quarantine wastes around the coast.

TALK.START.PARA: —When you say it identifies dumping sites do you mean that material can be dumped on those sites only?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Fletcher-The Act relates to the disposal of derelict vessels and quarantine wastes. It does not extend to other wastes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does this voluntary scheme in fact mean that your Department has control over dumping in the ocean only if somebody tells you that he has dumped something?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Fletcher-For material to be dumped at sea it has to be transported to the sea and the Department of Transport has certain controls regarding what sort of material is carried on vessels. So there is some measure of control through the Department of Transport.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Department of Transport informed by the vessel that it is carrying a certain product to a spot for it to be dumped overboard?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Fletcher-Through ports and harbour authorities we are often aware what vessels are carrying.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you get that information before the vessel leaves port or after the material has been dumped?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Fletcher-Normally we are approached by whoever is disposing of the wastes and we process the application in line with the London Dumping Convention provisions.

TALK.START.PARA: —On what grounds are you approached by the people who are dumping the wastes?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Fletcher-They are aware that there is a voluntary scheme operating. It operated previously under the Department of Transport through its regional offices and was widely advertised through those offices. The former Department of Environment took over the scheme in about 1974.

TALK.START.PARA: —Exactly what does the voluntary scheme cover? What does it say and how does it attempt to bind people?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Fletcher-There is no binding legislation except what I have already mentioned. It is a voluntary scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —What does the voluntary scheme entail?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Fletcher-It entails dumping wastes in line with the provisions of the London Dumping Convention.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does that mean, for instance, that people have to dump outside the 3-mile limit or outside the 200-mile limit? Are they expected not to dump in certain areas or to dump in certain areas?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Fletcher-It depends on what sorts of wastes are to be disposed of. For instance it may be a derelict vessel to be dumped near the Narrabeen Reef off Sydney, which is within a couple of kilometres of land. On the other hand it may be the dumping operation undertaken by Electrolytic Zinc Co. Ltd. That disposal takes place approximately 110 kilometres out to sea. It depends upon the type of waste.

TALK.START.PARA: —So under the voluntary scheme an industry which wants to dispose of some toxic waste approaches your Department and asks for your advice as to where it should dump that, does it?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Fletcher-Yes, and the conditions under which it should be dumped.

TALK.START.PARA: —What might those conditions be? Are you talking about weather conditions, conditions of the sea or what?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Fletcher-They concern the dump site, the characteristics of the site, how the material should be transported to the site, frequency of disposal and so on.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does that mean you do have dump sites?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Fletcher-No, we look at each individual waste and look at the proposed dump site for each of those wastes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who decides the dump site? Does the industry decide it or does your Department decide it?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Fletcher-The industry may put forward a site and we will then look at the proposal. If it does not, we will look at the kinds of sites which have been used for the purpose.

TALK.START.PARA: —How would an industry find a site? There is a big ocean and the industry is on land. How would it come upon a site?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Fletcher-The industries are often aware of the provisions in the London Dumping Convention. There are a number of annexes attached to the convention which talk about dump site characteristics. A number of industries look at that and look at possible sites in their vicinity which may meet those requirements.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The point I have been endeavouring to make is that we do not know what has been dumped, we do not know where it has been dumped, nor do we know in what amounts it has been dumped. It is at this point that the Opposition feels we should call a halt and be very sure that we know what is going into the sea and where it is going from now on.

SPEECH.PARA: Annex I of the Convention covers the substances that are banned. It bans the dumping of substances such as mercury, cadmium, high level radioactive wastes, persistent plastics, crude oil and materials produced for biological chemical warfare. All these are materials which I feel we all agree should not be dumped in the sea. This legislation will allow special permits to be issued for the dumping of waste as listed in Annex II. This includes materials such as arsenic, lead, copper, zinc, and their compounds; pesticides and radioactive wastes. It is here that we believe Annex II is not tight enough. We do not believe that any radioactive waste should be dumped at sea. Increasingly, scientific work shows that any radioactivity is dangerous, that its effects are cumulative. Therefore we feel that in relation to Annex II the Government should have taken a firm stand to make sure that under no circumstances were any radioactive wastes allowed to be dumped at sea.

The Opposition welcomes at last the introduction of this legislation. We feel that the quicker the situation is brought under control, the better. However, the Bill as drafted contains a major omission. There is no power to control dumping on Australia's continental shelf by foreign vessels. Clauses 10, 11, 12 and 14 control dumping beyond Australia's territorial seas only by Australian vessels, aircraft, or platforms or by vessels or aircraft loaded in Australia. What about the 200 mile zone for which we have taken responsibility? This Bill does not assist Australian jurisdiction over dumping on the continental shelf by foreign vessels, and we ask why. Under this Bill it is possible for ships from Indonesia, Papua New Guinea or Japan to dump on Australia's continental shelf substances which Australia considers are harmful to its seabed resources. We know that Japan is still looking for a disposal site for its nuclear waste. What will happen if other countries begin to look for disposal sites for arsenic or zinc or the metals that may come in the future?

It is submitted that international law today clearly recognises the right of a coastal state to control dumping on its continental shelf. Article 210 (5) of the Draft Convention on the Law of the Sea provides:

Dumping within the territorial sea and the exclusive economic zone or onto the continental shelf shall not be carried out without the express prior approval of the coastal State, which has the right to permit, regulate and control such dumping after due consideration of the matter with other States which by reason of their geographical situation may be adversely affected thereby.
Article 216 (1) (a) provides:

Laws and regulations adopted in accordance with this Convention and applicable international rules and standards established through competent international organizations or diplomatic conference for the prevention, reduction and control of pollution of the marine environment by dumping shall be enforced:
(a) by the coastal State with regard to dumping within its territorial sea or its exclusive economic zone or onto its continental shelf.

These articles provide a clear indication of the rights of a coastal state in international law. While these provisions are not in force, they reflect widely accepted international agreement and are not controversial articles.

It would be proper, therefore, for Australia to assert jurisdiction over dumping on its continental shelf. In support of such a view, it may be useful to mention briefly some background to the enforcement provisions contained in the London Dumping Convention itself. Article VII (1) (c) provides for each party to apply the measures to implement the convention to vessels under its jurisdiction believed to be engaged in dumping. The extent of jurisdiction possessed by a coastal state was a hotly debated issue at the London conference in 1972. The compromise was to leave unspecified in the Convention itself the jurisdiction of the coastal state and to leave this for determination by reference to the developing law of the sea.

Article VII thus needs to be read with Article XIII of the International Control of Marine Pollution. But what is clear is that the jurisdiction provided for in Article VII (1) (c) is additional to that in Article VII (1) (a). The negotiating history of the provision clearly shows that it was intended to provide for coastal state jurisdiction in a zone adjacent to the coast. At the time, agreement could not be reached on the extent of this zone. Since then, however, international law has clearly established that a coastal state can control dumping on its continental shelf and in its economic zone. Australia has not yet established an economic zone having only asserted jurisdiction over fisheries resources in a 200-mile zone. Australia has, however, asserted sovereign rights over its continental shelf. Because of the delay in finalising the Law of the Sea Convention, no definition of the nature and extent of responsibility of the coastal state has been made under the provisions of Article XIII. The Opposition, however, maintains that this need not prevent Australia from asserting jurisdiction in a manner that has now clearly been accepted as consistent with international law. This view is reinforced by the consistent policy of Australia in this matter. Throughout the Law of the Sea Conference, Australia has strongly argued for recognition of the jurisdiction of the coastal state over dumping on the continental shelf. At the London Dumping Conference itself, Australia and New Zealand in a joint statement said:

It is the understanding of the delegations of Australia and New Zealand that this Convention in no way detracts from the rights of a coastal state to take action in areas under its jurisdiction, and in particular from the right of the coastal state to take action for the purpose of protecting the resources of its continental shelf.

For Australia now to legislate, almost 10 years since the Convention was drawn up, and not to assert jurisdiction over dumping on its continental shelf would represent not only a departure from a long held position expressed at the 1972 conference itself but also would fail to reflect developments in international law since that date. It may be argued that Australia should not, at this stage, assert jurisdiction over dumping on the continental shelf but that it should wait until it establishes a full economic zone with powers over all forms of pollution as provided for in the Draft Law of the Sea Convention. The Opposition maintains that the problem with this approach is that Australia already has rights over its continental shelf and it ought to act to the full extent permitted by international law to protect the resources of the shelf. It is likely to be a considerable time before Australia moves to establish a full economic zone. In the meantime there seems to be absolutely no justification for not asserting jurisdiction over all dumping on Australia's continental shelf.

The Opposition is particularly concerned that the Government's attitude to dumping on the continental shelf will allow the Japanese to have a free hand in dumping radioactive waste off our coast. What attitude will the Government take to this? In a letter to my colleague, Mr West, in another place the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Wilson) on 21 May said:

Officials advised the Japanese mission that Australia considered it essential that the disposal of nuclear waste in any environment, and in particular the Pacific Ocean, should be undertaken only in compliance with the strictest safety measures and in full accordance with the relevant international agreements on the subject.

But what are the strict safety measures? How safe are they? Do they mean this sort of material could be dumped five miles off the Great Barrier Reef or dumped in our fishing grounds on the east coast of Australia? The Opposition asks whether the Government intends to accept the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development decision on establishing a multilateral consultation and surveillance mechanism for sea dumping of radioactive waste? This decision would authorise dumping consistently with the convention but under international supervision. Is this what the Government has in mind? If it is, will it tell us? We would appreciate it if the Government would accept that decision. But we ask the Government to remember that all life on earth originated millions of years ago in the sea. In the last century there has been wholesale pollution on the basis that, because the sea is so vast, any waste would be diluted quietly, quickly and safely. We cannot go on saying that while we pour millions of tonnes of wastes of all kinds into the sea, as we have done in the last 100 years.
The Opposition supports the Bill in principle but asks the Senate to allow Australia to show the way to the world by amending the Act and thus producing a stronger, more purposeful Act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats agree with the Australian Labor Party that the Bill is an approach in the right direction but does need improvement in a number of significant respects. We support substantially the amendments which the Labor Party is moving because they would appear to any conservationist or person interested in the future of the natural assets of this country to be necessary amendments to the legislation. We have a community of view in that regard.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like particularly to refer to clause 22 of the Bill, which relates to the disposal of radioactive waste. This provision, under some circumstances, permits radioactive waste dumping to take place off the Australian coast. We feel that this is wrong and should not be considered in any circumstances. I believe we are reinforced in this view by the recent quite heavy publicity in the United States, and to some extent in this country, about the effects that are now becoming apparent of the massive dumpings off the United States coast of drums of radioactive waste which resulted from the building of nuclear weapons in the 1950s. Undersea exploration craft operating in deep water have now found that many of those drums, which were dumped in huge numbers, have breached or rotted away and are now leaking, that sponges and other marine life are attached to them and that there is every indication that there is substantial contamination which will continue over the centuries and into the indefinite future.

The behaviour of any radioactive isotope in the marine environment, according to our research into United Nations Educational Scientific and Cultural Organisation dissertations, probably will be different at different locations. Any amount of research which Australia could carry out into the effects of radioactive waste on our marine environment must therefore be considered to be vastly inadequate as a basis for allowing any dumping of radioactive waste material in our waters. One cannot lay down general standards on these matters.

We must also remember that the effect of radiation on living organisms is cumulative, that no individual organism will ever become immune to its effects. Unlike other forms of contamination, the effects of radioactivity become more pronounced with time rather than otherwise, and the time lapse involved where radioactive isotopes are concerned is vast compared with that of any other form of pollution. The half life of plutonium, for instance, is some 24,400 years, so we may expect contamination to continue for literally millenia. Even with low rates of radiation there is an increase in the rate of mutation of genes and, as each individual in the sea, as elsewhere, is after all a highly complex and integrated machine, any mutation is likely to be harmful rather than beneficial. That is basic to any genetic consideration.

Coastal waters, including the seas over the continental shelves such as the Coral Sea, are the most productive areas of the oceans. They are the sites of the highest biological activity in the oceans, where primary production of the organic material which forms the base of the food chain ending in fish, birds and marine mammals takes place. The end effects of pollution on the base of the food chain or indeed any organism in the food chain are dramatically shown by, as Senator Melzer pointed out, the classic example of the massive occurrence of neurological disease from mercury poisoning which was contracted by the residents of Minamata Bay in Japan as a result of eating fish and shellfish from that bay, which had accumulated mercury from the wastes from the production of vinyl chloride and formaldehyde consequent upon their being discharged into the water by the Chisso Corporation. We have there a classic case of the dangers of dumping which needs to be observed constantly.

The United Nations Educational Scientific and Cultural Organisation from our research, agrees that the greatest danger of harmful effects from any radioactive pollution of the oceans would be in coastal waters, including the waters over the continental shelf. I believe that to be a matter of common sense. I will deal also with the matter of foreign vessels because as the Bill stands Australia has no power to control dumping on its own continental shelf by foreign vessels. As Henry Burmester of the Australian National University Law Department pointed out, this Bill makes it possible for an Indonesian, Papua New Guinean or Japanese vessel, for instance, to dump on Australia's continental shelf substances which Australia may consider harmful to its seabed resources.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the amendments made following that representation?

—It is possible I might not know of those. I am obliged to the honourable senator if that matter has been covered. Indeed, if it has, that is a matter which I know both of us would applaud. The other point I want to discuss concerns the inclusion of platforms. As a result of the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Miscellaneous Amendments Bill 1981 being passed we can expect drilling platforms to be very much in evidence over our continental shelf in future. Why should these platforms and those located in other parts of Australian territorial waters not also be subject to the same limitations as vessels and aircraft in relation to dumping?

SPEECH.PARA: The last point I want to raise concerns the matter of States passing similar legislation to this Bill and then being allowed to administer the legislation in regard to their own territorial waters. The Australian Democrats believe this would lead to inefficiency in the administration of the legislation. There is a remote possibility admittedly, but still a possibility, of one of the States not complying fully with the legislation. Our view is that the surrounding seas ought to be a national responsibility and be administered on a uniform basis. This is not a philosophical viewpoint. Indeed, our policy is for the devolution of power, but we believe in this case there is ample evidence that due to the very mobility of the seas, by the movement of the currents, effects will be felt in geographic locations quite remote from their point of origin. We believe that is a good reason for there to be a purely national standard in this regard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Bill 1981 gives ratification in Australia's jurisdiction to the 1972 London Dumping Convention. Currently 41 countries are signatories to that Convention. By Australia's accession there will be 42 signatories. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a list of countries which have ratified the Convention to date.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
