TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. As I said, Australia now joins this list which includes most of the great maritime nations with the exception-it is a significant exception-of Japan. I believe one of the important things for Australia to do will be to encourage the Japanese to become parties to this significant international Convention. If people are reading this Bill and attempting to get some appreciation of the measures taken by Australia to prevent the dumping of noxious material in the oceans they undoubtedly would have had drawn to their attention the fact that this Bill does not really say anything about the discharge of oil into the sea. The reason is that some time ago the Senate passed a Bill entitled the Protection of the Sea (Discharge of Oil from Ships) Bill which in fact fully covers that. In order to indicate the completeness of the regime I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard clause 9 of that Bill which deals with the prohibition of the dumping of oil and oily wastes into the sea.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The clause read as follows-
Prohibition of the discharge of oil or oily mixtures into sea

9. (1) Subject to sub-sections (2) and (3), if any discharge of oil or of an oily mixture occurs from an Australian ship into the sea, the master and the owner of the ship are each guilty of an offence punishable, upon conviction, by a fine not exceeding-
(a) in the case of the master-$50,000;
(b) in the case of the owner, if the owner is not a body corporate-$50,000; and
(c) in the case of the owner, if the owner is a body corporate-$100,000.
(2) Sub-section (1) does not apply to the discharge of oil or of an oily mixture from a ship-
(a) into the territorial sea of Australia;
(b) into the sea on the landward side of the territorial sea of Australia;
(c) for the purpose of securing the safety of a ship, preventing damage to a ship or cargo or saving life at sea; or

(d) if the oil or oily mixture, as the case may be, had escaped from the ship in consequence of damage to the ship or unavoidable leakage and all reasonable precautions were taken after the occurrence of the damage or the discovery of the leakage for the purpose of preventing or minimising the escape of oil or oily mixture, as the case may be.
(3) Without limiting the generality of sub-section (2), sub-section (1) does not apply to-
(a) the discharge of oil from a ship other than a tanker or from the machinery space bilges of a tanker if all the following conditions are satisfied:
(i) the discharge occurs when the ship is proceeding en route;
(ii) the instantaneous rate of discharge of oil content does not exceed 60 litres per mile;
(iii) the discharge is made as far as practicable from land;
(b) the discharge of an oily mixture from a ship other than a tanker or from the machinery space bilges of a tanker if all the following conditions are satisfied:
(i) the discharge occurs when the ship is proceeding en route;
(ii) the instantaneous rate of discharge of oil content does not exceed 60 litres per mile;
(iii) the discharge is made as far as practicable from land;
(iv) the oil content of the discharge is less than 100 parts in 1,000,000 parts of the mixture;

(c) the discharge of oil or of an oily mixture from a tanker that occurs when the tanker is not on a ballast voyage (not being a discharge from the machinery space bilges of the tanker or a discharge to which paragraph (e) applies) if all the following conditions are satisfied:
(i) the discharge occurs when the tanker is proceeding en route;
(ii) the instantaneous rate of discharge of oil content does not exceed 60 litres per mile;
(iii) the discharge is made when the tanker is more than 50 miles from the nearest land;

(d) the discharge of oil or of an oily mixture from a tanker that occurs when the tanker is on a ballast voyage (not being a discharge from the machinery space bilges of the tanker or a discharge to which paragraph (e) applies) if all the following conditions are satisfied:
(i) the discharge occurs when the tanker is proceeding en route;
(ii) the instantaneous rate of discharge of oil content does not exceed 60 litres per mile;
(iii) the discharge is made when the tanker is more than 50 miles from the nearest land;
(iv) the total quantity of oil discharged on the voyage does not exceed one fifteen-thousandth of the total cargo-carrying capacity of the tanker; or

(e) the discharge of oil or of an oily mixture from a tanker that occurs when ballast is discharged from a cargo tank of the tanker, being a cargo tank that had, after cargo had last been carried in the tank, been so cleaned that any effluent from the tank, if it had been discharged into clean calm water on a clear day while the tanker was stationary, would not have produced any visible traces of oil on the surface of the water.

(4) In proceedings for an offence against sub-section (1) in relation to a ship, it is sufficient for the prosecution to allege and prove that a discharge of oil or of an oily mixture occurred from the ship into the sea, but it is a defence if it is proved that, by virtue of sub-section (2) or (3), sub-section (1) does not apply in relation to the discharge.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think this legislation essentially touches on three things. First, it will prevent the dumping of any of the materials which are described in Annex I to the London Dumping Convention. As Senator Melzer has already indicated, these are a listing of the most harmful and noxious waste materials. They include organohalogenic compounds, mercury, cadmium, persistent plastics, certain types of oil, high level radioactive wastes, biological and chemical warfare products and substances which do harm to the environment. In fact, the test imposed in part 8 of Annex I states:

SPEECH.PARA: The preceding paragraphs of this Annex do not apply to substances which are rapidly rendered harmless by physical, chemical or biological processes in the sea provided they do not:
(i) make edible marine organisms unpalatable, or
(ii) endanger human health or that of domestic animals.

Secondly, the Annex goes on to provide strict limits and controls on the materials listed in Appendix 2 which might be dumped into the sea. That deals with wastes containing significant amounts of substances such as arsenic, lead, copper, zinc, organosilicon compounds, cyanides, fluorides, pesticides, beryllium, chromium, nickel, vanadium, various containers and various types of radioactive waste. Finally, it gives a general power of permit to permit the dumping of other materials which are described in Annex III. I seek leave to have the full text of the three annexes incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
ANNEX I
1. Organohalogen compounds.
2. Mercury and mercury compounds.
3. Cadmium and cadmium compounds.

4. Persistent plastics and other persistent synthetic materials, for example, netting and ropes, which may float or may remain in suspension in the sea in such a manner as to interfere materially with fishing, navigation or other legitimate uses of the sea.
5. Crude oil, fuel oil, heavy diesel oil, and lubricating oils, hydraulic fluids, and any mixtures containing any of these, taken on board for the purpose of dumping.

6. High-level radio-active wastes or other high-level radio-active matter, defined on public health, biological or other grounds, by the competent international body in this field, at present the International Atomic Energy Agency, as unsuitable for dumping at sea.
7. Materials in whatever form (e.g. solids, liquids, semi-liquids, gases or in a living state) produced for biological and chemical warfare.
8. The preceding paragraphs of this Annex do not apply to substances which are rapidly rendered harmless by physical, chemical or biological processes in the sea provided they do not:
(i) make edible marine organisms unpalatable, or
(ii) endanger human health or that of domestic animals.
* Signatures omitted
The consultative procedure provided for under Article XIV should be followed by a Party if there is doubt about the harmlessness of the substance.

9. This Annex does not apply to wastes or other materials (e.g. sewage sludges and dredged spoils) containing the matters referred to in paragraphs 1-5 above as trace contaminants. Such wastes shall be subject to the provisions of Annexes II and III as appropriate.
ANNEX II
The following substances and materials requiring special care are listed for the purposes of Article VI (1) (a).
A. Wastes containing significant amounts of the matters listed below:
arsenic
lead
copper and their compounds
zinc
organosilicon compounds
cyanides
fluorides
pesticides and their by-products not covered in Annex I.

B. In the issue of permits for the dumping of large quantities of acids and alkalis, consideration shall be given to the possible presence in such wastes of the substances listed in paragraph A and to the following additional substances:
beryllium
chromium
nickel and their compounds
vanadium
C. Containers, scrap metal and other bulky wastes liable to sink to the sea bottom which may present a serious obstacle to fishing or navigation.

D. Radio-active wastes or other radio-active matter not included in Annex I. In the issue of permits for the dumping of this matter, the Contracting Parties should take full account of the recommendations of the competent international body in this field, at present the International Atomic Energy Agency.
ANNEX III
Provisions to be considered in establishing criteria governing the issue of permits for the dumping of matter at sea, taking into account Article IV(2), include:
A-Characteristics and composition of the matter
1. Total amount and average composition of matter dumped (e.g. per year).
2. Form, e.g. solid, sludge, liquid, or gaseous.
3. Properties: physical (e.g. solubility and density), chemical and biochemical (e.g. oxygen demand, nutrients) and biological (e.g. presence of viruses, bacteria, yeasts, parasites).
4. Toxicity.
5. Persistence: physical, chemical and biological.
6. Accumulation and biotransformation in biological materials or sediments.
7. Susceptibility to physical, chemical and biochemical changes and interaction in the aquatic environment with other dissolved organic and inorganic materials.
8. Probability of production of taints or other changes reducing marketability of resources (fish, shellfish, etc.).
B-Characteristics of dumping site and method of deposit

1. Location (e.g. co-ordinates of the dumping area, depth and distance from the coast), location in relation to other areas (e.g. amenity areas, spawning, nursery and fisning areas and exploitable resources).
2. Rate of disposal per specific period (e.g. quantity per day, per week, per month).
3. Methods of packaging and containment, if any.
4. Initial dilution achieved by proposed method of release.
5. Dispersal characteristics (e.g. effects of currents, tides and wind on horizontal transport and vertical mixing).

6. Water charactersitics (e.g. temperature, pH, salinity, stratification, oxygen indices of pollution-dissolved oxygen (DO), chemical oxygen demand (COD), biochemical oxygen demand (BOD)-nitrogen present in organic and mineral form including ammonia, suspended matter, other nutrients and productivity).
7. Bottom characteristics (e.g. topography, geochemical and geological characteristics and biological productivity).
8. Existence and effects of other dumpings which have been made in the dumping area (e.g. heavy metal background reading and organic carbon content).

9. In issuing a permit for dumping, Contracting Parties should consider whether an adequate scientific basis exists for assessing the consequences of such dumpings, as outlined in this Annex, taking into account seasonal variations.
C-General considerations and conditions
1. Possible effects on amenities (e.g. presence of floating or stranded material, turbidity, objectionable odour, discolouration and foaming).
2. Possible effects on marine life, fish and shellfish culture, fish stocks and fisheries, seaweed harvesting and culture.

3. Possible effects on other uses of the sea (e.g. impairment of water quality for industrial use, underwater corrosion of structures, interference with ship operations from floating materials, interference with fishing or navigation through deposit of waste or solid objects on the sea floor and protection of areas of special importance for scientific or conservation purposes).
4. The practical availability of alternative land-based methods of treatment, disposal or elimination, or of treatment to render the matter less harmful for dumping at sea.

TALK.START.PARA: —I turn now specifically to the provisions of this Bill. The first provision I want to take up deals with the matter of the control of the continental shelf. Both Senator Melzer and Senator Mason have criticised this Bill on the basis that it does not give legislative power to the Australian Government to undertake proper protection of dumping on the continental shelf. Senator Mason is right in saying that the attention of honourable senators was drawn to this problem by a detailed submission from Mr Henry Burmester who is a lecturer in law at the Australian National University. He wrote an analysis of the Bill as it was first introduced into the House of Representatives. I seek leave to have Mr Burmester's analysis incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
ENVIRONMENT PROTECTION (SEA DUMPING) BILL 1981

This Bill has been introduced to enable Australia to give effect to the London Dumping Convention. The Bill is a significant piece of environmental legislation and in general is worthy of strong support. There is however a major omission which, it is submitted, should be remedied.

2. The Bill as drafted, contains a major omission-there is no power to control dumping on Australia's continental shelf by foreign vessels. Clauses 10, 11, 12 and 14 only control dumping beyond Australian territorial sea by Australian vessels, aircraft or platforms or by vessels or aircraft loaded in Australia. The Bill does not assert Australian jurisdiction over dumping on the continental shelf by foreign vessels. It would, therefore, be possible for an Indonesian, Papua New Guinean or Japanese vessel, for instance, to come and dump on Australia's continental shelf substances which Australia may consider harmful to its seabed resources.

3. International law, it is submitted, today clearly recognises the right of a coastal State to control dumping on its continental shelf. Article 210 (5) of the Draft Convention on the Law of the Sea provides:

5. Dumping within the territorial sea and the exclusive economic zone or onto the continental shelf shall not be carried out without the express prior approval of the coastal State, which has the right to permit, regulate and control such dumping after due consideration of the matter with other States which by reason of their geographical situation may be adversely affected thereby.
Article 216 (1) (a) provides:

1. Laws and regulations adopted in accordance with this Convention and applicable international rules and standards established through competent international organisations or diplimatic conference for the prevention, reduction and control of pollution of the marine environment by dumping shall be enforced:
(a) by the coastal State with regard to dumping within its territorial sea or its exclusive economic zone or onto its continental shelf;

4. These Articles provide a clear indication of the rights of a coastal State in international law. While these provisions are not in force, they reflect widely accepted international agreement and are not controversial articles. It would be proper, therefore, for Australia to assert jurisdiction over dumping onto its continental shelf.

5. In support of such a view, it may be useful to briefly mention some background to the enforcement provisions contained in the London Dumping Convention itself. Article VII (1) (c) provides for each Party to apply the measures to implement the Convention to 'vessels . . . under its jurisdiction believed to be engaged in dumping', (emphasis added). The extent of jurisdiction possessed by a coastal State was a hotly debated issue at the London Conference in 1972. The compromise was to leave unspecified in the Convention itself the jurisdiction of the coastal State and to leave this for determination by reference to the developing Law of the Sea. Article VII, thus needs to be read with Article XIII-see Timagenis, International Control of Marine Pollution I, 236 ff. (1980).

6. What is clear is that the jurisdiction provided for in Article VII (1) (c) is additional to that in Article VII (1) (a). The negotiating history of the provision clearly shows that it was intended to provide for coastal State jurisdiction in a zone adjacent to the coast. At the time agreement could not be reached on the extent of this zone. Since then, however, international law has clearly established that a coastal State can control dumping onto its continental shelf and in its economic zone. Australia has not yet established an economic zone, having only asserted jurisdiction over fisheries resources in a 200 mile zone. Australia has however, asserted sovereign rights over its continental shelf.

7. Because of the delay in finalising the Law of the Sea Convention, no definition of the nature and extent of responsibility of the coastal State has been made under the provisions of Article XIII. This need not, however, prevent Australia from asserting jurisdiction in a manner that has now clearly been accepted as consistent with international law: see Article VII (5).

8. This view is reinforced by the consistent policy of Australia in this matter. Throughout the Law of the Sea Conference, Australia has strongly argued for recognition of the jurisdiction of the coastal State over dumping on the continental shelf. At the London Dumping Conference itself, Australia and New Zealand in a joint statement said:

'It is the understanding of the delegations of Australia and New Zealand that this Convention in no way detracts from the rights of a coastal State to take action in areas under its jurisdiction, and in particular from the right of the coastal state to take action for the purpose of protecting the resources of its continental shelf.' (emphasis added)-see Timagenis, supra 248.

9. For Australia now to legislate, almost 10 years since the Convention was drawn up, and not to assert jurisdiction over dumping on its continental shelf would represent not only a departure from a long held position expressed at the 1972 Conference itself but also would fail to reflect developments in international law since that date.

10. It may be argued that Australia should not, at this stage, assert jurisdiction over dumping on the continental shelf but that it should wait until it establishes a full economic zone with powers over all forms of pollution as provided for in the Draft Law of the Sea Convention. The problem with this approach is that Australia already has rights over its continental shelf and it ought to act to the full extent permitted by international law to protect the resources of the shelf. It is likely to be a considerable time before Australia moves to establish a full economic zone. In the meantime there seems no justification for not asserting jurisdiction over all dumping on Australia's continental shelf.

11. It is, therefore, strongly submitted that the Bill should be amended by the insertion in clause 10 (a) after the words 'Australian waters' of the words 'or into the sea above the continental shelf of Australia'. This would then reflect Australia's proper entitlement at international law and the position consistently taken by Australia since 1972.

TALK.START.PARA: —Following that, the Government took the representations that were made by its own back bench committee on the Environment in conjunction with Mr Burmester's representations very seriously. The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, Mr Wilson, in fact introduced in the House of Representatives an amendment to deal specifically with this matter. The definitions clause of the Bill reads:

SPEECH.PARA: 'Australian waters' means-

(a) the territorial sea of Australia and any sea that is on the landward side of the territorial sea of Australia, other than any part of the sea that is within the limits of a State or of the Northern Territory; or
(b) the territorial sea of an external Territory and any sea that is on the landward side of that territorial sea,
That was the definition given in the original Bill. That was amended in the House of Representatives. Added into that clause are the following words:
and includes any area of sea that is declared by the regulations to be included in Australian waters for the purposes of this Act;

In other words the Australian Government by regulation may proclaim the continental shelf or, indeed, any part of the 200-mile zone or whatever it happens to assert as jurisdiction under the London Dumping Convention for the purposes of this Act to be set by regulation as waters to which this Act applies. In other words, the amendment introduced in the House of Representatives by the Government added to the definition of the term 'Australian waters' a power to proclaim by regulation any other waters, including the continental shelf obviously, as waters to which this Act was to take application.

The time constraints of today's debate do not allow me to go into very great detail about this Bill. I will perhaps just highlight a couple of matters that are to be found within it. Clause 5 of the Bill provides an exemption in relation to dumping in the sea. It reads:
. . . the disposal of wastes or other matter directly arising from, or relating to, the exploration, exploitation and associated off-shore processing, of seabed mineral resources.

It is one of the early steps in the development of an off-shore mining code. Clause 9 indicates the degree of co-operation which we seek to have with the States whereby, if they pass legislation which the Commonwealth regards as satisfactory, the Commonwealth will withdraw from that part of the seas around Australia over which State jurisdiction is asserted and allow the States to administer that Act with the safeguard that if the Act, in the first place, is subject to the Commonwealth's approval before it withdraws its legislative control over that area and if, in the administration or further amendments to the Act, the Commonwealth believes that the States are no longer taking their full share of responsibility or that their legislation does not accord with the principles that the Commonwealth has laid down, section 9 (3) allows the Minister, by publication in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette to revoke his original declaration that the matter should be under State jurisdiction.

Clause 13 of the Bill establishes a fairly significant regime of penalties for breaches of the Act. We are talking about fines that range between $10,000 and $100,000. Clause 15 lists the possible defences. It is important to note that defences in that clause are that dumping can take place within certain limits, provided a permit has been granted by a country which is a signatory and a party to the London Dumping Convention. As far as Australia's own waters are concerned, it requires a permit from Australian authorities for that dumping to take place so that a permit-even a permit issued by another signatory to the London Dumping Convention-does not have effect in Australian waters without Australian consent.

Clause 16 of the legislation goes on to deal with the question of the restoration of the environment. That and its related clauses through to clause 23 are important because they indicate that where dumping has taken place in a fashion which is not in accord with the legislation, then the Commonwealth may require the person who undertook the incineration or dumping to make good the restoration of the environment. The Minister may direct how the environment is to be restored. He may arrange for the work to be done to restore the environment and he may arrange to recover the costs so incurred from the guilty party. If necessary, he may hold and take possession of ships, vessels, platforms and various things, pending the settlement of the account due to the Commonwealth. It also provides that the Minister may order research to be done and may require the actual polluter to pay for the cost of research, for the cost of analysis which may be done and for matters related to that. The rest of the Bill goes on to deal, for instance, with the powers of inspectors along much the same lines as our other environment legislation such as the Whaling Act and the Antarctic Marine Living Resources Conservation Act. It lists a number of indictable offences; it provides for the appointment and the work of an analyst in conjunction with matters under this Bill and it provides for regulations to be made. As I have said, in the definition of Australian waters regulation becomes important because it allows the extension of the definition previously contained in the Bill as it was first introduced.

This regime will replace the previous voluntary code for dumping. In the period June 1975 to April 1981 there were some 91 inquiries for dumping permits in Australian waters. Twenty-nine of those related to chemical dumping-things like caustic soda, cyanide and sulphuric acid; seven to the dumping of explosives-things such as detonators and ammunition; seven to the dumping of scrap metal, including aircraft exhausts, valves and steel containers; 26 to the dumping of obsolete vessels such as barges, tugs, ferries and pontoons; and 22 to other things such as dredge spoils, rock and concrete. Of those 91 applications, 18 were withdrawn following advice being provided on possible alternative disposal methods, 14 were diverted to definitive alternative disposal or re-use methods and one was refused approval in line with the provision of the London Dumping Convention. Five applications, I understand, are undergoing review at present while the remining 53 applications resulted in approval being given to 25 organisations to dispose of material at sea. A number of these organisations made multiple applications in the period 1975 to 1981 to dispose of the same material at different times. I think it is important that we indicate that this voluntary regime will now be replaced with a more formal, more rigid and more enforceable regime.

I have already indicated by having incorporated in Hansard the exact nature of the materials specified in three Annexes. Therefore, I will turn only to the question of the dumping of radioactive material. Low level radioactive material may be dumped in accordance with part D of Annex II; high level radioactive waste, of course, may not be dumped at all under the provision of Annex I. Part D of Annex II draws particular attention to the recommendations of the appropriate international authority-that is, the International Atomic Energy Agency. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the document entitled 'International Atomic Energy Agency Information Circular, Convention on the Prevention of Marine Pollution by Dumping of Wastes and other Material. The Definition Required by Annex I paragraph 6 to the Convention, and the Recommendations Required by Annex II section D'.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
INTERNATIONAL ATOMIC ENERGY AGENCY
Information Circular
Convention on the prevention of Marine Pollution by dumping of wastes and other matter
The Definition Required by Annex I, paragraph 6 to the Convention, and the Recommendations Required byAnnex II, section D

1. The Provisional Definition and Recommendations Concerning Radioactive Wastes and Other Radioactive Matter Referred to in Annexes I and II to the Convention on the Prevention of Marine Pollution by Dumping of Wastes and Other Matter1 had been the object of a review and revision process carried out by the International Atomic Energy Agency during 1975-1978, with the help of several consultants' meetings and advisory groups and taking into account the comments expressed by the Contracting Parties to the Convention at their First and Second Consultative Meetings, held in London in September 1976 and September 1977 respectively. As a result of this work, the Revised Definition and Recommendations were submitted to the Board of Governors by the Director General in June 1978.
2. On 9 June 1978 the Board of Governors authorised the Director General:

(a) To transmit the Revised Definition and Recommendations Concerning Radioactive Wastes and Other Radioactive Matter Referred to in Annexes I and II to the Convention, to the Inter-Governmental Maritime Consultative Organisation (IMCO) which performs secretariat duties in relation to the Convention; and
(b) To request IMCO:

(i) To provide the Third Consultative Meeting of the Contracting Parties to the Convention, to be held in London in October 1978, with the said Definition and Recommendations for the purpose of implementing the Convention; and

(ii) To inform the Meeting that such Definition and Recommendations, which should not be construed as encouraging in any way the dumping at sea of radioactive wastes and other radioactive matter, will be subject to review and revision by the Agency, as and when appropriate, in the light of technological developments and increased scientific knowledge.
3. The texts of the Revised Definition and Recommendations and of the Annex thereto for the purposes of the Convention are reproduced herein for the information of all Members.
1 The texts of the Convention and of the Provisional Definition and Recommendations have been reproduced in documents INFCIRC/205 and INFCIRC/205/Add. 1 respectively.
A. DEFINITION
A.1. Definition of High-Level Radioactive Wastages or Other High-Level Radioactive Matter Unsuitable for Dumping at Sea1

A.1.1. For the purposes of Annex I to the Convention, high-level radioactives wastes or other high-level radioactive matter unsuitable for dumping at sea means any waste or other matter with an activity per unit gross mass (in tonnes) exceeding:
(a) 1 Ci/t for *-emitters but limited to 10-1 Ci/t for 226Ra and supported 210Po;
(b) 102 Ci/t for */*-emitters with half-lives of at least 0.5 years (excluding tritium) and */*-emitters of unknown half-lives; and
(c) 106 Ci/t for tritium and */*-emitters with half-lives of less than 0.5 years.
The above activity concentrations shall be averaged over a gross mass not exceeding 1,000 tonnes.
A.1.2. The Definition must not be taken to imply that material falling outside the Definition is thereby deemed to be suitable for dumping.

A.1.3. Materials of activity concentrations less than those in the above Definition shall not be dumped except in accordance with the provisions of the Convention, in particular Annexes II and III thereto, and the Recommendations set out in this Document, in particular Section B.1.2.
1 The Definition is based on:
(1) An assumed upper limit to the mass dumping rate of 100 000 t per year at a single dumping site; and
(2) Calculated upper limits to activity release rates from all sources (other than natural sources) of
(a) 105 Ci/yr for *-emitters (but limited to 104 Ci/yr for 226Ra and supported 210Po);
(b) 107 Ci/yr for */*-emitters with half-lives of at least 0.5 years (excluding tritium) and */*-emitters of unknown half-lives; and
(c) 1011 Ci/yr for tritium and */*-emitters with half-lives of less than 0.5 years
at a single dumping site and also in the case of *-emitters when released to an ocean basin of not less than 1017 m3.
B. THE RECOMMENDED BASIS FOR ISSUING SPECIAL PERMITS FOR RADIO-ACTIVE MATERIALS LISTED IN ANNEX II TO THE CONVENTION
B.1. Environmental Evaluation of Specific Dumping Applications

B.1.1. The appropriate national authorities shall not grant a special permit for dumping of radioactive waste unless a detailed environmental and ecological assessment gives a reasonable assurance that such dumping can be accomplished in accordance with the objectives and provisions of the Convention and the Recommendations set out in this Document.

B.1.2. When granting a special permit, the appropriate national authorities shall, to the extent practicable, ensure that the proposed dumping operation complies with the radiation protection requirements set forth in the IAEA Basic Safety Standards for Radiation Protection(2). These requirements are based upon the System of dose limitation of the International Commission on Radiological Protection (ICRP) which requires that:
(1) The operations should be justified by assessing their net benefits, taking into consideration the radiation consequences and the possibilities of alternative procedures;

(2) The radiation protection aspects of the operation should be optimized, keeping the resulting collective doses (including their occupational and public components) as low as is reasonably achievable, economic and social factors being taken into account; and

(3) The doses to individual members of the public should not reach the appropriate dose limits, now or in the future. In estimating the doses, account must be taken of other practices which might expose the same critical population groups.
In particular, the upper limits to activity release rates from all sources (other than natural sources) when released into an ocean basin with a volume of not less than 1017 m3 shall not exceed:
(a) 105 Ci/year for *-emitters but only 104 Ci/year for 226Ra and supported 210Po;
(b) 108 Ci/year for */*-emitters with half-lives of at least 0.5 years (excluding tritium) and */*-emitters of unknown half-lives;
(c) 1012 Ci/year for tritium and */*-emitters with half-lives of less than 0.5 years.
No special permit should be issued which would cause these limits to be approached.

B.1.3. It is essential that a general policy of continued isolation and containment of radioactive waste after descent to the sea-bed should be pursued through the use of suitable packaging to minimize to the extent reasonably achievable the radioactivity which might ultimately be released, thereby preventing unnecessary contamination of the maritime environment.

(2) INTERNATIONAL ATOMIC ENERGY AGENCY Safey Series No. 9: 'Basic Safety Standards for Radiation Protection', 1967 Edition, Vienna, 1967, STI/PUB/147. (This publication is under joint revision by the IAEA, the World Health Organisation and the Nuclear Energy Agency of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development.)
*B.1.4. The environmental assessment shall include, in addition to the factors specified in Annex III to the Convention, consideration of:
(1) The justification for the proposed dumping operation when weighed against land-based alternatives, including the respective population dose commitments;
(2) The total alpha, beta and gamma activities and the activity of any individual nuclide of special significance for the assessment;

(3) Those factors likely to affect significantly the movement of radioactive materials from the dumping site to the human environment, including the nature of the sea-bed and the physical processes of mixing and transport in the sea at the dumping site;
(4) Dose commitments to individual members of the public and to the population via critical and other appropriate pathways;
(5) The risk to marine ecosystems resulting from the release of radioactivity from dumped packages;

(6) The degree to which it is practical to attempt to reduce dose commitments, either for normal dumping or in case of accidents, by techniques such as having the radioactive material in a relatively insoluble form or within a relatively insoluble matrix, by designing the containment to retain for a period of time radioactive material when it is on the sea-bed, or by selecting an area with characteristics that will facilitate the retention of the radioactive material in the vicinity of the dumping site;
(7) Operational methods to be used, including arrangements for dealing with accidents and emergencies and methods of verifying their correct execution.

**B.1.5. The IAEA is of the opinion that it is necessary that the reports to be submitted pursuant to Article VI.4 of the Convention, to the Inter-Governmental Maritime Consultative Organization (IMCO) include this environmental assessment in relation to an individual application for a special permit for dumping.
C.5. Escorting Officers
C.5.1 General

C.5.1.1. The dumping operation shall be supervised by approved escorting officers representing the national authorities granting the dumping permits. Their duties and responsibilities, powers and qualifications are separately specified in Sections C.5.2.1.
C.5.3.1 and C.5.4.1 below.
C.5.2 Duties and Responsibilities
C.5.2.1. The escorting officer shall have the following duties and responsibilities:
(1) He must ensure that the holder of the special permit complies with the requirements and conditions specified therein;
(2) In the execution of his duties he shall pay special attention to the following items:

(a) He must ensure that he is provided with a certified copy of the special permit with respect to each dumping operation. He must ensure that he is provided in advance with sufficient information about all containers and their contents to enable him to act appropriately in an emergency;
(b) Before loading, he must be satisfied that all containers are:
(i) of an approved type and on visual inspection appear sound and not to be leaking;
(ii) correctly identified and marked with the gross weight to show a specific gravity not less than 1.2; and
(iii) within the radiation and contamination limits laid down by the appropriate national authorities;
(c) The escorting officer must ensure that the master of the ship is provided with a loading sheet showing weights and volumes to be dumped;

(d) In conjunction with the master, the escorting officer shall ensure that the cargo is safely stowed. The consignment must be stowed and segregated to ensure that the levels of radiation measured at living quarters and regularly occupied working spaces do not expose the crew to doses exceeding those specified by the appropriate national authorities;

(e) He is responsible for the radiological safety and the individual dosimetry of all personnel engaged in the operation. For this purpose, he shall ensure that there is an adequate supply of personal dosimeters, protective clothing, monitoring and decontaminating equipment. He shall ensure that the crew is monitored and provided with protective clothing whenever necessary;

(f) The daily rate of dumping and the dumping hours must be approved by the escorting officer. Before dumping commences, the escorting officer must obtain from the master an assurance that the ship is at the approved dumping site and make arrangements for hourly fixes of the ship's position during dumping. He must also witness the dumping of all containers to satisfy himself that the drums and their contents sink;

(g) He must ensure that monitoring for radioactive contamination occurring on the ship is carried out and arrange for decontamination of the affected areas as necessary. Subject to his ultimate responsibility for the safety of the ship, the master must comply with any directions given by the escorting officer in this connection; and

(h) When the dumping operation is completed and after completion of any necessary decontamination, the escorting officer must provide the master with a Clearance Certificate of an approved type. He must also prepare, for the appropriate national authorities, a Certificate of Disposal confirming that the recorded cargo has been dumped at the designated site, with details of how the ship's position was fixed. This shall be accompanied by a certified copy of the ship's log for the duration of the voyage, including details of hourly fixes of the ship's position during the dumping period.
C.5.3. Powers
C.5.3.1. Without prejudice to the master's overall responsibility for the safety and control of the ship and the crew:

(1) The escorting officer must be empowered to refuse the loading or dumping of any container which, in his opinion, does not conform with the standards of packaging or have the documentation required by the special permit;
(2) He must be empowered to stop the dumping operation at any time if, in his judgment, the requirements for the operation cannot be met or the safety of the operation cannot be guaranteed;

(3) He must be empowered to prescribe, through the ship's officers or port officials, any protective measures which in his opinion are necessary for the radiological safety of the personnel engaged in the operation; and

(4) Subject to the requirements of the appropriate national authorities, he must be empowered to require that the ship or any part of it may not be used for other cargoes except in accordance with the terms of a Contamination Clearance Certificate.
ANNEX
I. INTRODUCTION
1.1. The London Dumping Convention of 1972

1.1.1. The Convention on the Prevention of Marine Pollution by Dumping of Wastes and Other Matter1 was adopted by an Intergovernmental Conference which met in London from 30 October to 13 November 1972, at the invitation of the Government of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland. The Convention was opened for signature by any State at London, Mexico City, Moscow and Washington from 29 December 1972 until 31 December 1973 and thereafter for accession by any State. After the entry into force of the Convention on 30 August 1975, a meeting of the Contracting Parties to decide on organizational matters, held in London from 17 to 19 December 1975, designated the Inter-Governmental Maritime Consultative Organization (IMCO) as the Organization responsible for Secretariat duties in relation to the Convention. The Convention provides for control of 'any deliberate disposal at sea of wastes or other matter from vessels, aircraft, platforms or other man-made structures at sea' and any deliberate disposal of such vessels, aircraft, etc. themselves. The prevention of marine pollution emanating from the normal operation of vessels, aircraft, etc. or directly arising from the exploration and exploitation of sea-bed mineral resources is excluded from the scope of the Convention (Article III. 1).
1.1.2. With respect to radioactive materials, the Convention entrusts the IAEA with specific responsibilities in the following provisions pursuant to Article IV:
(1) In Annex I on materials prohibited from dumping, item 6 states:

'High-level radioactive wastes or other high-level radioactive matter, defined on public health, biological or other grounds, by the competent international body in this field, at present the International Atomic Energy Agency, as unsuitable for dumping at sea';
(2) In Annex II on materials requiring special care in dumping procedures, item D states:

'Radioactive wastes or other radioactive matter not included in Annex I. In the issue of permits for the dumping of this matter, the Contracting Parties should take full account of the recommendations of the competent international body in this field, at present the International Atomic Energy Agency'.

1.1.3. Article IV.1 of the Convention makes a distinction between materials that may be dumped after the issue of a general permit and those that may be dumped only after the issue of a special permit. Annex II puts 'radioactive wastes or other radioactive matter' into the class requiring special permits without, however, defining such radioactive wastes or matter.

1.1.4. Article IV.3 of the Convention provides that no provision thereof is to be interpreted as preventing a Contracting Party from prohibiting, in so far as that Party is concerned, the dumping of wastes or other matter not listed in Annex I. Further, the content of the Annexes to the Convention will be kept under review by consultative meetings of the Contracting Parties, which will be convened not less frequently than once every two years, or by special meetings which may be convened at any time.
(1) Reproduced in IAEA Document INFCIRC/205.

TALK.START.PARA: —This document sets out the definition of what constitutes low level radioactive waste and what constitutes high level radioactive waste. It sets out a regime as to the way in which these things are to be measured and to be monitored. It sets out a regime providing for inspectors, the power of inspectors and the rights of inspectors, including the rights of inspectors to supersede the rights of masters of vessels which are involved in this process. It specifies a number of other technical matters which, if read as a whole, will show the extent to which the dumping of low level radioactive waste is capable of the very strictest control under these provisions. As I said, the Bill requires regard to be had to the recommendations and the regime set down by the International Atomic Energy Agency.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, the comments made about Australia's attitude towards Japan with regard to the dumping of waste have been misunderstood. I refer honourable senators to the letter that appears on page 2946 of the House of Representatives Hansard of 2 June, when this matter was debated. In that letter they will see quite clearly expressed the Australian Government's attitude towards the Japanese dumping of waste. I make the point at the beginning of my speech; that I think the most important thing for the Australian Government to do in this regard is to put pressure on the Japanese to become signatories to the London Dumping Convention. I think that ought to be a matter of the highest priority. I am happy to support this legislation. I believe it puts into effect a good, solid and dependable international regime in place of the voluntary regime. I believe that the safeguards provided by the London Dumping Convention, the annexes, and the regulations of the International Atomic Energy Agency will allow us to do this with purpose and effect. I believe that the amendment made in the House of Representatives to extend the definition of Australian waters under this Bill will allow us to protect not only our waters as we currently understand them but also the continental shelf and other areas as they become of significance to Australia in the immediate future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Puplick for his support of the Bill and for his explanation of a number of matters which were raised by Opposition senators and the Australian Democrats in their speeches. I also record my appreciation of the fact that all speakers, because of the tightness of the program, spent less time on the Bill than they might otherwise have done. Similarly, I will not reply at length. In response to the last point made by Senator Puplick, I am pleased to be able to say that within the last couple of months Japan has become a party to the Convention. This will be a matter of some satisfaction to honourable senators opposite as well as those on this side of the chamber. It will mean that the Convention will be more effective in an area of concern to this country. The purpose of the Bill is to control marine pollution through dumping and incineration by implementing the Convention on the Prevention of Marine Pollution by Dumping of Waste and Other Matter. I commend the Bill to the Senate. I hope it will have a speedy passage.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

Clause 9 (Declaration by Minister in relation to coastal waters of a State, &c.)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Melzer Sen J.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —We oppose clause 9, lines 21 to 23. The Opposition feels that this clause shows the Government's betrayal of the historic decision of the High Court of Australia, which ruled that the Commonwealth had power over the seas and what lay beneath them from the low water mark to the edge of the continental shelf. The result was the sell-out to the State Premiers which culminated in the package of off-shore legislation which went through the Parliament on 1 May last year. This caused problems with the Premier of Queensland and the Great Barrier Reef. We envisage further problems. The Queensland Government is waiting for the Coastal Waters (State Powers) Act 1980 to be declared which provides for at least three miles out to sea from a given base line. How then will the Federal Minister prevent oil drilling on the reef? Why will this Government not take national responsibility? We are told by the Government speaker that some of the problems that we have with the Bill about the continental shelf will be covered by regulation. We find that to be entirely unsatisfactory. If the Government can really see the problem there, why can it not write a provision into the Bill rather than leave the matter to regulation. This does not mean that that jurisdiction must happen but that it can happen if the Minister desires.

SPEECH.PARA: We point out to the Government that this is one country, not a collection of States. We are here to ratify an international convention. Australia, as a country, is expected internationally to take full responsibility for the enforcement of the laws of an international convention. We have the inanity of this mirror legislation where six States rule the waves and what is beneath them for three miles around our coast, rather than the Federal Government taking responsibility. The Opposition opposes this clause.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I briefly respond to the point made by the honourable senator on behalf of the Opposition. The matter she raises is, of course, one of the points which is of fundamental difference between the Government and the Opposition. It is true that Australia is one country but it is also a collection of States and jurisdiction in many areas is divided between the Commonwealth and the States. In line with the general provisions of the off-shore constitutional settlement to give each State powers with respect to the adjacent territorial sea, it was agreed that Commonwealth legislation would apply in respect of dumping outside the territorial sea-that is the 3-mile limit-and also apply in respect of dumping inside the territorial sea where a State does not wish to legislate. I emphasise that this is not a case of leaving a vacuum or of having a situation where the convention would not be applied. Clause 9 sub-clause (1) states:

SPEECH.PARA: Where the Minister is satisfied that the law of a State or of the Northern Territory will, on and after a particular date, make provision for giving effect to the Convention . . . the Minister shall, by notice published in the Gazette, declare that on and after that date, this Act does not apply . . .

In other words the Act applies to all of Australia's territorial waters unless and until the Minister is satisfied that the law of a State or of the Northern Territory gives effect to the convention. So there is total coverage. I think that the point made by Senator Melzer is essentially a point of philosophic difference. It is a very important point but it is one that I do not think needs long debate in this chamber for it to be understood both by honourable senators and the broader public which is familiar with the debate in this and other areas.
Clause agreed to.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Robertson

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish it to be recorded that all Opposition senators voted to oppose this clause.

INTERJECT.PARA: Clause 10. (Dumping of wastes or other matter).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Melzer Sen J.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition opposes clause 10. We feel that this is the key to much of our opposition to this Bill. The Opposition will move an amendment because the effects of the clause are as have been outlined in the debate to date. Ships of foreign nations which are signatories to the Convention on the Prevention of Marine Pollution by Dumping of Wastes and Other Matter need only an Australian permit from our designated authority to dump in territorial waters that is within 3 miles from the base line. Once they get outside that area they require only a permit from their own designated authority. That means that a ship from France, United States of America or any other nation could dump, according to its own permit system, four or five miles off the Australian coast. The situation is even worse for ships registered in a port of a foreign nation that is not a signatory to this convention because outside the 3-mile limit they do not need a permit from anyone. They can dump what they like and we cannot do a thing about it unless we amend the Bill. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Page 5, clause 10, line 5, before 'where' insert 'Subject to section 22,'.
(3) Page 5, clause 10, paragraph A, lines 7 and 8, leave out the paragraph, insert the following paragraph:
'(A) are, or is, dumped into Australian waters or into the sea above the continental shelf of Australia or of an external Territory from any vessel, platform or aircraft; or'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

The Bill is not one which seeks to assert to the maximum permissable degree the right of Australia to control dumping and incineration by foreign vessels beyond our territorial waters. We believe the Bill goes as far as we ought to go. The amendment to the definition 'Australian waters' makes it clear that the Bill puts it within the power of the Government to extend the provisions of the Bill. We believe that is an adequate provision.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Melzer Sen J.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (12) Pages 13 and 14, clause 22, line 21 (page 13) to line 38 (page 14), leave out the clause, insert the following clause:
'Radioactive wastes or other matter 22. (1) The dumping at sea of any radioactive wastes or other radioactive matter, being dumping to which this section applies, is prohibited.
(2) The incineration at sea of any radioactive wastes or other radioactive matter, being incineration to which this section applies, is prohibited.
(3) The loading of any radioactive wastes or other radioactive matter for the purpose of being dumped at sea or incinerated at sea, being loading to which this section applies, is prohibited.
(4) This section applies to dumping at sea and incineration at sea carried out from or by-
(A) any vessel, platform or aircraft in or into Australian waters or in or into the sea above the continental shelf of Australia or of an external Territory;
(B) any Australian vessel, Australian aircraft or Australian platform in or into any part of the sea.
(5) This section applies to loading on or on to-
(A) any vessel, aircraft or platform in Australia or in Australian waters or in the sea above the continental shelf of Australia or of an external Territory;
(B) any Australian vessel, Australian aircraft or Australian platform in, or in the territorial sea, of a country that is not a party to the Convention.

(6) The owner and person in charge of the vessel, platform or aircraft on or from which loading, dumping at sea or incineration at sea in contrvention of this section is carried out and the owner of the wastes or other matter so loaded, dumped or incinerated are each guilty of an offence against this section, punishable on conviction by a fine not exceeding-
(A) if the person is a natural person $50,000; or
(B) if the person is a body corporate $100,000.'.
It was interesting that in the debate in another place on this Bill the responsible Minister said:
The intention of the Bill is not to assert to the maximum permissible degree the right of Australia to control dumping and incineration by foreign vessels beyond our territorial waters.

The Opposition asks, why not? Clause 22 deals with radioactive wastes. We have already referred to the problems that could arise regarding signatory nations needing only their own permits to dump radioactive wastes within four miles of our shore and once dumped, I must point out to the Minister, this material cannot be recovered no matter how hard the Minister tries. Ships registered in a port of a foreign nation that is not a signatory to the Convention simply dump what they like outside the three mile limit. As they are not signatories to the Convention, they could dump high level radioactive wastes four miles from Sydney Heads and we could not do a thing about it.

Japan, which is not a signatory to the Convention, has indicated that it will dump 45,000 drums of low level and medium level wastes in the Pacific Ocean. The Opposition asks: Why has not Australia told the Japanese firmly that it has no right to dump any radioactive wastes at all in the ocean? Why was not this Bill expressly written to prevent the dumping of radioactive wastes on Australia's continental shelf? Scientists maintain that deep ocean currents and migratory marine life could spread accumulated radiation to Japan itself and to the islands of Micronesia, but we do not appear to care. Once it is dumped we cannot get it back; the problem is with us for a very long time-for generations into the future. We ask the Government to take the very logical step we have suggested so as to prevent this sort of thing from happening.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The fact is that the London Dumping Convention, which is what is being put into operation by this legislation, does prohibit the disposal of high level radioactive material and places strict controls on the disposal of other radioactive material. As I indicated earlier, Japan is now a party to this Convention. The Bill which we have before us and its application to Australia and Australian waters gives effect to the provisions of the Convention. The amendment which is proposed by the Opposition would provide for a total prohibition of the dumping at sea of any radioactive wastes. This goes well beyond the provisions of the Convention and is not acceptable to the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bounty (Printed Fabrics) Bill and the Bounty (Textile Yarns) Bill are part of the program of TCF-textile clothing and footwear-assistance to which the Government has committed itself and to which program the Opposition, as we have made it clear on a number of occasions, is equally committed. As such, we do not oppose these Bills. We note only that the level of assistance is provided at considerable cost to the community at large, not so much in aggregate terms as far as the Bounty (Printed Fabrics) Bill is concerned as it is only $2.5m. That means, given that there are only something like 200 employees in the part of the industry affected, a subsidy per head of employees of approximately $12,500. When we turn to the Bounty (Textile Yarns) Bill the cost to the revenue is estimated by the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Moore) at $71m in a full year which represents in this case a subsidy of over $10,000 per worker involved in this part of the industry.

SPEECH.PARA: There seems to be something of an incongruity in the Government's adopting the passionate views that it seems to about using the public sector as an appropriate vehicle for job creation at the same time being prepared to support private enterprise out of public funds to this extent. Obviously, there are a great many matters in these two Bills which justify extensive debate, but in the circumstances in which we now find ourselves with 10 minutes left for the consideration of these Bills and the whole of the Freedom of Information Bill with its 20-odd remaining clauses and 30-odd Opposition amendments and 12 amendments by the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) I will not spend any further time on this Bill. I simply make the points that I have and I refer everyone else who is interested in a proper exposition of what our industry policy ought to be in this respect to the speech of the shadow Minister for Industry and Commerce, Mr Hurford, in the other place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In August 1977, the Government stated that it regarded an efficient textile, clothing and footwear industry as an important and continuing part of the Australian manufacturing sector. Three years later, it reinforced this claim by essentially rejecting the thrust of Industries Assistance Report No. 240. But, despite this rejection, it did adopt certain features. The two bounty Bills before the Senate involving textile yarns and printed fabrics adopt some of these principles whereby a measure of the tariff and quota protection will be replaced by another protective measure such as a bounty. I believe that bounty protection can be justified if small amounts of public money is involved. But I cannot go along with the view that we should set aside large amounts out of the Budget for bounty purposes because I believe that costs should be borne by people who purchase goods which could attract a bounty.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government gave an undertaking last year that it wished to provide seven years stability to enable the industries to invest, to become viable, to re-equip and above all to maintain a high measure of employment within those industries. But basically what the Government has set in train by subsequent statements and enactments has been of great assistance to the textile, clothing and footwear industry. However, I foreshadowed in a speech this year that there could be some problem areas, particularly in relation to certain textile yarns. Unfortunately, I regret to say at the moment that my prediction is all too true. We have now reached the stage where, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) in his second reading speech, stated:
This bounty proposal is part of the Government's broader program designed to encourage--
I emphasise the word 'encourage'-
the development of a more efficient industry structure for the textiles, clothing and footwear industries.
However, I take exception to the subsequent paragraph which states:
It will also provide substantial benefits for industries using bountiable yarns in manufacturing textiles or textile products.

At this point, I acknowledge the sympathetic hearing I have received from Sir Phillip Lynch on certain moves to improve what was previously a completely untenable situation so far as certain sectors of the industry were concerned. I find it very hard as a Government member to accept those words right across the board. In some sectors, yes, it is true but there are some significant sectors where it is far from true and far from accurate because the proposal will not provide substantial benefits for some of the industries. In some cases it could sound their death knell. This is the serious part of the legislation to which I want to refer. Unfortunately the words 'we are trying to encourage' mean different things to different people. Sure, we are putting pressure on them. In some areas we are applying so much pressure that I would not be surprised if some of them restructure downwards or closed their doors. What is going to happen to the promise of maintaining employment under such circumstances?

I do not think it does our side of politics any good at all to take an attitude and to say that from now on this situation is not further negotiable. I can see situations where there will be problems in this industry. It is a poor situation when the industry itself is now not prepared and come out and criticise because it has been threatened with a complete overview of the whole structure of protection towards these industries. If this is not a heavy-handed threat, I do not know what is. We talk about the union movement's attitude of standover tactics, but I have never seen the like of this sort of attitude.

I admit there have been some Cabinet changes since last year when they made this undertaking before the election. It is true that the views of new members of the Cabinet have to be reflected in legislation. But basically, if an undertaking is given before an election I think it must be seen through despite the fact that the amount of money involved might have been miscalculated. On the other hand, if there has been a miscalculation, if the IAC has given a brummy figure as it did with the 33 per cent so far as the cotton system was concerned, why not come out and acknowledge it? Why not say 'We've made a mistake, we are going to review it; we can't afford it', or some other such thing, and not come back and try to kid the community at large that the proposal will provide substantial benefits for industries? Why do we not say it will provide some substantial benefits or, in a measure, will provide substantial benefits. But those substantial benefits are not, I repeat, spread right across the board.

Further it does not do our side of politics any good if Federal Ministers say that decentralisation is not a Commonwealth Government responsibility at all. I believe that if we are going to maintain this Federal Government we have to have certain responsibilities so far as decentralisation is concerned. A large measure of the protection was designed to encourage employment in decentralised areas. It is the decentralised areas that will be hit most by this legislation. Some of the city-based areas could probably make money out of it. But in some of the decentralised areas there will be major problems. It is no good the Ministers saying that the industries will have to make commercial judgments based on the Government decisions. True, they will make those commercial decisions; but what will be the final result? It will be loss of employment and loss of dignity and trust as far as our Government is concerned. I believe that our Government has lost its ability to communicate with all sections of the industry, particularly with manufacturing industry. We seem to be concentrating on a few magnates at the moment and neglecting the rest because they have an imput and they have information that I believe we should be acting upon.

I believe that the lines of communication with industry are breaking down and breaking down very severely, and I am rather concerned that a lot of our credibility in the manufacturing sector is being lost. I recognise that there have been substantial Cabinet changes; but basically we have to continue to honour the undertakings that we have given in earlier days. I wonder what people will say if factory managers find that they are not in a position to continue their operations. I cite areas such as Bendigo, Bayswater, and a couple of centres in non-metropolitan New South Wales which would see their operations perhaps in jeopardy-not tomorrow, but within the next two or three years as they phase down. If companies close, there will be effects on employment. In other areas it would be no longer economic to conduct certain activities, and this affects the whole basis of fixed costs. So this will have an effect spreading further than just the States of New South Wales and Victoria and into South Australia. So Ministers from those States, I believe should be aware of the consequences.

It is fashionable within our party at the moment to preach the free trade ethic. Unfortunately, it has such a stranglehold and it is running so fast that we have lost sight of some of our basic tenets. We have lost sight of the need to provide a measure of protection and support across the nation. I regret this new-found fad. I believe it is not in the interests of our country to follow this free trade ethic. The attitude of these theoretical economists who probably base their theories on an island economy such as Hong Kong is not applicable to this twentieth century when we are concerned about people. Some of us have criticised the IAC for not taking the social consequences of its decisions into account. I maintain here today that we are not taking the social consequences; we are merely taking economic decisions, and not all those economic decisions will be of great help to people. If a person has been unemployed as a result of government attitude, he knows what it is like.

I believe that in setting some of these bounty rates we have underestimated the value that the bounty will require. In other areas I can see industry coming back to government and if it continues to take this intransigent attitude of not listening and not caring, or not taking into account the social consequences, then I believe that we are in trouble. I believe that our Cabinet should have the moral fibre to honour its election undertakings to the full in this area. In other areas I can see industry coming back to government. If it continues to take this intransigent attitude of not listening, not caring, or not taking into account the social consequences, then I believe we are in trouble. I believe that Cabinet should have the moral fibre to honour to the full its election undertakings in this area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank honourable senators on both sides of the chamber for their support of the Bill. I wish the Bill a speedy passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not without some symbolic significance that now, at last, we come back to the Freedom of Information Bill, the last Bill on the last day of the last week of the session. We have exactly minus four minutes available to debate it if the Senate observes its original intention to finish Government Business at 2.15 p.m. in order to enable valedictories to commence. In other words, we have minus four minutes in which to debate the remaining 20-odd clauses of the Bill that have yet to be considered, the 30-odd amendments that have been proposed by the Opposition, and the dozen or so amendments of the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) that remain to be considered.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government could hardly give a clearer demonstration of the extent of its commitment to this measure. It is about as committed, clearly, to freedom of information as the Politburo of the Soviet Union is committed to freedom of speech. This must now be a derisory exercise. I am very conscious indeed that every minute that is taken now on this debate will detract from the time available which all honourable senators in this chamber want to spend on farewelling their departing colleagues. The only reason we are going through this derisory exercise at all is that the Government knows that if the Bill is left to be dealt with in the Senate after next July it will emerge a very different proposition indeed from what it is at the moment.

Given the time now available-I imagine that realistically we can spend only about 20 minutes on the whole exercise-there is necessarily a ritualistic quality to the remainder of this debate. We all know what will be accepted and what will be rejected by the Government. We know that there will be no spontaneity, no fireworks, no unexpected happenings. The Opposition will co-operate in expediting the passage of the Bill in the last few minutes available to it, only because it believes that on balance the measure will emerge as a better proposition than having no Bill at all. However, at the outset we register our deep unhappiness at the way in which our rather carefully thought-out amendments, which were based on a Senate Standing committee's report, have been treated.

To do my last little bit of arithmetic, which I know irritates the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) so much, I calculate that at the end of this 20-minute period, after we have played out the rituals laid down for us, the result will have been that of the 80 amendments moved by the Opposition just 30 will have been accepted in whole or significant part by the Government, leaving the great majority, some 60 per cent, not accepted in any shape or form. Although we still have something better than what we started with we still have nothing that amounts to effective freedom of information legislation.

I understand that, technically, we have before the Committee at the moment the amendments that I have moved, to constitute a new Part IVB of the Bill, in relation to the position of the Ombudsman. I understand, following consultations with everybody, that it would expedite the completion of this debate if I were now to seek leave to withdraw, for the moment anyway, the amendments presently before the Committee. We will then return to a consideration of the Bill as a whole and thereafter three successive blocks of amendments will be moved. The first, which will be moved by the Attorney-the dozen or so amendments that currently stand in his name-are accepted, with one or two reservations, by the Opposition. I will then move, on behalf of the Opposition, three amendments which I understand will be accepted by the Government. Then I will move, as a third block of propositions, the remaining quite substantial list of amendments. I will move them together and will speak to them as briefly as time will demand. It is understood that at this late stage the Government is unlikely to accept those amendments, and on that block, if the Attorney persists in his present attitude, there will be a division. I formally seek leave to withdraw the amendments presently before the Committee and I suggest that the course of action which I have outlined be followed.
Leave granted.
Amendments-by leave-withdrawn.
Remainder of Bill-by leave-taken as a whole.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of all of us on this side of the chamber I indicate that we have no quarrel at all with any of those proposed amendments, except those two clauses 23 and 58. Some of the other matters are essentially propositions which were suggested initially by the Opposition but which have been redrafted by the Government, some as recently as this morning; others of them amount in one way or another to improvements to the Bill. There is a remaining problem of a very significant kind in relation to clause 23-the catch-22 provision. Senator Mason will be articulating the basis of the Opposition's concern in relation to that clause.

SPEECH.PARA: The other matter that gives us ground for expressing concern in clause 58 which sets out the contents of annual reports for the future and which very largely embodies the proposal put forward by the Opposition. However, it omits one vital component of the proposed annual reports which we have put very strongly ought to be included on this list. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address my remarks primarily to clause 23, as Senator Evans said. I agree with Senator Evans that this unsatisfactory Freedom of Information Bill is now passing through its final Committee stage not with a bang but with a whimper, and that is entirely appropriate. The Australian Democrats reject it as anything but a cosmetic window-dressing operation devised to place almost every conceivable obstacle in the way of anyone seeking information on the activities of government.

SPEECH.PARA: Even though the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) has tinkered to some extent with clause 23 (2), I still think it preserves the spirit of the original clause in toto, that spirit being that an official can refuse to grant access to documents without having searched for or identified any of them if the nature of the documents as described in the request is such that they would be exempt. I suggest to honourable senators that this is a quite outrageous proposition and remains so in the amended sub-clause (2) that honourable senators have before them. It implies an omniscient capacity on the part of the agency that it is able to recall that all parts of a perhaps complex series of documents are exempt without having to search for them or even identify them. Granted the huge areas of exemption contained in the Bill as it now stands, this truly does add a catch-22 situation for the unfortunate applicant.

The nature of the documents described in the requests will frequently be vague. After all, the applicant is supposed to be seeking information, not giving it. He is like a man in a maze seeking guidance. We propose to confront him with a decision from the oracle in these terms: 'I am not quite sure what you want. It is probably impossible to know what you want until we have a look at what exists. But on my judgment what you probably want is certainly totally exempted material. Therefore, not only can you not have it but we don't propose to assist you even to the extent of trying to find out what it is'. If anything demonstrates the Kafkaesque qualities of this Bill which permeate it from end to end and a determination at all costs not to do the things it says it will, it is this clause and this sub-clause of the Bill. Moreover, it is a square-one situation which is well calculated to confuse, distress and confound the applicant right at the beginning of his or her inquiry. It also has the convenient quality of being unprovable and unappealable. No one, including the applicant, could know just what the truth was in any situation involving it. I must take it from the Government's attitude that this is precisely what it is looking for in the Bill. That is what it is all about. If honourable senators want to improve this Bill at some future time to give it a faint semblance of sincerity I urge them to look again at this ridiculous, cynical and dishonest clause.
