''PART IVB-ROLE OF THE OMBUDSMAN
''Interpretation
43EA. In this Part-
(a) a reference to the taking of action has the same meaning as it has for the purposes of the Ombudsman Act 1976; and
(b) action shall be deemed to have been taken by an agency in the circumstances in which it would be deemed to be so taken for the purposes of the Ombudsman Act 1976.
''Complaints to Ombudsman
''43EB. (1) Subject to this Act, a person may complain to the Ombudsman concerning action taken by an agency or by a Minister in the exercise of powers or the performance of functions under this Act.

(2) Notwithstanding anything contained in this Act or in sub-section 6 (3) of the Ombudsman Act 1976 but subject to sub-section 6 (2) of that Act, the exercise of the powers of the Ombudsman under the Ombudsman Act 1976 in respect of matters arising under this Act is not precluded or restricted by reason of the rights conferred on persons by this Act to make applications to the Tribunal.

(3) Where a complaint is made to the Ombudsman under the Ombudsman Act 1976 concerning action taken by an agency in the exercise of powers or the performance of functions under this Act, an application to the Tribunal for a review of the decision shall not be made before the Ombudsman has informed the applicant of the result of the complaint in accordance with section 12 of the Ombudsman Act 1976.

''(4) Notwithstanding anything contained in the Ombudsman Act 1976, a report under that Act to a complainant in respect of a complaint arising out of a request under this Act shall not contain information of the kind referred to in sub-section 24 (1) of this Act.
''Ombudsman may designate a Deputy Ombudsman for Freedom of Information matters
''43EC. (1) The Ombudsman shall, by notice published in the Gazette, designate a Deputy Ombudsman as the Deputy Ombudsman for freedom of information matters.

''(2) In relation to any action taken by a Minister or an agency in the exercise of any power or the performance of any function conferred by this Act, the Deputy Ombudsman for freedom of information matters has all the powers, and may exercise all the functions, of the Commonwealth Ombudsman under the Ombudsman Act 1976, other than the power of the Commonwealth Ombudsman to report to the Parliament under section 17 or 19 of that Act.

''(3) Nothing in this section prevents the exercise of a power of the performance of a function by the Commonwealth Ombudsman under the Ombudsman Act 1976 in relation to action of the kind referred to in sub-section (2).
''(4) In this section, a reference to the Ombudsman Act 1976 shall be construed-
(a) unless paragraph (b) applies-as a reference to that Act as modified in the manner provided in sections 43EA and 43EB of this Act; or
(b) in relation to a complaint concerning action taken by a Minister-as a reference to the Ombudsman Act 1976 as modified and adapted in accordance with the regulations made under section 43EF.
''Reports made by the Ombudsman
''43ED. (1) Where, in the course of an investigation by the Ombudsman in relation to action taken by an agency in the exercise of powers or the performance of functions under this Act-
(a) the Ombudsman has referred evidence concerning an officer to a Minister or to a principal officer under sub-section 8 (10) of the Ombudsman Act 1976; and
(b) that officer is employed under the Public Service Act 1922,
the Ombudsman shall furnish a copy of that evidence to the Public Service Board.

''(2) Where, after an investigation by the Ombudsman in relation to action taken by a Department in the exercise of powers or the performance of functions under this Act, a report is made to the Department by the Ombudsman under sub-section 15 (2) of the Ombudsman Act 1976, the Ombudsman shall furnish a copy of the report to the Public Service Board.

(i) such observations as the Ombudsman sees fit to make concerning the operation of this Act during the year, or the part of a year, to which the report relates; and
(ii) such recommendations as the Ombudsman sees fit to make concerning ways in which public access to documents of agencies or to official documents of Ministers might be better secured.

These amendments represent all the remaining amendments on the list circulated to honourable senators, with the exception of the following amendment numbers which I mention for the record and which we are not now perservering with. They are amendment Nos 51, 52, 61, 63, 64, 66, 69 and 70. Each of those amendments are essentially matters that were consequential upon our earlier proposed clauses which, unfortunately, have been defeated in earlier votes in this chamber. Because I am extremely conscious of the time constraints, very briefly I say that the amendments I have just moved fall into three broad categories. The first category goes to the role and functions of the Commonwealth Ombudsman. The second class of amendments concerns the matter of costs of Tribunal proceedings. Those in the third group-there are some other smaller matters as well-are all aimed at the Schedule. I wish to say a quick word or two on each of those propositions.

In regard to the Ombudsman, these amendments are an absolutely central part of the Opposition's approach to this legislation and, indeed, are based on the recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. Under the existing Ombudsman Act and the modification proposed to it, which was adopted earlier this afternoon, the Ombudsman will have in respect of freedom of information his ordinary functions of investigation, conciliation and report. It is probable that this will be a very useful function in respect of freedom of information. The Senate Committee's recommendations which are now embodied in this first group of proposed amendments go much further than that. They contemplate a significantly expanded role for the Ombudsman, a central role in the actual on-the-ground practical administration of the whole Act. There are five elements in these proposals. Briefly, they are as follows: in the first place--

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going to speak on the valedictory, too?

—Senator Walters, we did not start this debate until 20 minutes past 2 o'clock, as a product, among other things, of your tedious repetition and inanities on the subject of the Australian National University.
—Order!

—I am doing my best, Mr Chairman, to deal with an extraordinarily complex and important piece of legislation in less than 20 minutes. That is the time which we have to deal with 40 clauses and something like 42 proposed amendments. Senator Walters, will you curb your inane tongue?
—Order! Senator Evans, address yourself to the Chair.

—The first element in the proposal is the creation of a separate administrative unit within the Ombudsman's office and the creation of a deputy Ombudsman for freedom of information. The second element in the proposal is the extension of the Ombudsman's ordinary function of investigation and conciliation to enable him to investigate as well ministerial decisions. The third element in the proposed equation is the giving to the Ombudsman of a role as general counsel for applicants appearing on their behalf before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The fourth element in the equation gives the Ombudsman a specific role as adviser to departments and agencies to assist them in working out the scope and extent of their obligations under the Bill. The fifth and last element in the proposal gives to the Ombudsman a specific power to monitor and criticise the way in which the legislation is operating and to report to the Parliament. The whole range of functions, both executive and legislative, that I have outlined is not able to be conducted by him, as at present. It is our belief that they ought to be.

SPEECH.PARA: I did have something which I proposed to say on the resource question in the Ombudsman's office which seems to be the basic reason for the Government's resistance to this. Taking into account the concern of other honourable senators-I am not worried about Senator Walters in this respect-I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a short paper on the administrative implications of the freedom of information legislation for the Ombudsman.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
ADMINISTRATIVE IMPLICATIONS OF FOI FOR THE OMBUDSMAN

One way of approaching the issue is to calculate roughly the cost of handling complaints. For instance, in the year ended 30 June 1980 2,544 written complaints were resolved; the expenditure of the office was roughly $1,214,000. Consequently, the average cost of resolving a written complaint was $477. (This figure is an approximation, as it includes roughly 700 complaints in which there was no investigation (out of jurisdiction etc), but does not include roughly 3,000 oral complaints resolved in the same period, nor the many thousand other oral and personal enquiries.) By contrast, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal resolved 248 cases in the same period, and its expenditure was $592,000. That is, the average cost of an AAT hearing was $2,387, or five times the cost of an Ombudsman investigation.

The impact of FOI can also be analysed in terms of the working methods of the office. The normal procedure with written complaints is to write to departments, obtain their comments, analyse these, go to both the complainant and the department for further comments, and so the process goes on. Because the complaints often raise novel issues, there is little streamlining in the complaint handling procedure, for instance by resort to standard letters on a word processor. (Though some streamlining does occur for instance, many investigation officers are specialists in particular areas, and routine complaints like delay in the issue of a tax assessment can often be handled over the telephone.) By contrast, FOI complaints should be easier to handle. The issue in each complaint is likely to be clearly defined; investigations are unlikely to be prolonged, and will likely be determined after comments have initially been received from a department and perhaps their records have been inspected; a body of relevant principles will be built up by the Ombudsman's office and by the AAT; and it should be possible to allocate all such complaints to a couple of officers, including a Deputy Ombudsman who is designated to handle FOI complaints. Moreover, in the handling of other complaints an inordinate amount of time can be taken up in soliciting the views of complainants and analysing these (since they often have first hand knowledge of the issue), and in preparing a section 15 report to a department and undertaking all the preliminary investigation that must precede this. Neither of these factors is likely to figure largely in investigation of FOI complaints. On the one hand, people seeking access to documents will not have first hand knowledge of the contents of those documents, and it would not be necessary to solicit their views on a continuing basis. Further, I think it unlikely that many section 15 reports would be prepared in this area: as soon as it was clear that a department refused to disclose, one assumes that the complainant would be advised to lodge an appeal with the AAT or the Ombudsman might choose to do this himself. Another factor that will affect the ease and speed of investigations is that, by the time a person complains to the Ombudsman, they will in most cases have already sought an internal review of an agency's refusal to disclose. Thus, the point in dispute will already have been clarified, an agency will have examined the issue twice, and on two occasions the agency will have given to the complainant a reasoned statement of the refusal to disclose. Consequently, there is little orignal analysis or research to be undertaken at the time the Ombudsman commences investigation.

In summary the following points can be made. First, Ombudsman investigations are relatively cheap, by comparison at least with other mechanisms for resolving grievances. Secondly, investigation of FOI complaints should be relatively simple, and certainly easier in general than the investigation of other complaints presently handled by the Ombudsman. Thirdly, the Commonwealth Ombudsman's office is, at least on world standards, relatively efficient-to quote the Ombudsman from page 58 of his Third Annual Report:

'I am in no doubt, following my visit overseas last year to various Ombudsmen's offices, that no Ombudsman's office copes with a comparable volume of work with fewer staff, some have appreciably more and none have the additional, but essential, staffing handicap for a federal Ombudsman of maintaining branch offices in the States.'

Lastly, it seems certain that an increase in the Ombudsman's present staff ceiling would be needed to cope with FOI complaints, however there appears to be a generally accepted practice of increasing his ceiling in line with his work load. At a very rough guess perhaps two or three extra positions on top of the existing 45 would be needed to handle the FOI work load.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will deal with the remaining matters dealt with by these amendments in a sentence each. The first one concerns costs before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. It is not unprecedented now for costs to be able to be awarded, we believe for reasons that are amply set out in the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs report. The Tribunal ought to have a discretion to recommend costs for successful applicants so that it will be a reality and the departments will not simply exercise the muscle they can to stop matters being properly determined.

SPEECH.PARA: The final matter-I am trying now to summarise in one sentence the product of something like seven amendments and about 100 different line items in the Schedules, Parts I and II-is that the Opposition basically opposes all the Schedule items which list a whole series of agencies and classes of documents which are to be absolutely exempt from the operation of the Bill. They concern not only security agencies and other sensitive areas of this kind but areas of commercial competitive concern. We do not believe, again for reasons articulated in the report, that there is any justification for blanket exemptions of agencies and documents to the extent that is involved in that Schedule. I refer any honourable senator who is interested in a rather more reasoned approach to the explanation of these amendments than I am able to give in the time available, to the relevant sections of that report. I move for the adoption of those amendments.
