TALKER.ROLE: Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

I take this opportunity to say a few words in regard to 12 of our colleagues who are retiring from the Senate at the end of this month. It is, in one sense, a pleasing opportunity, but it is tinged with sadness. It is pleasing because of the associations and friendships that we have formed with them, and sad, of course, because we are seeing them leave us. They are 12 in number-12 good men and true. In total they have served 170 years. Their length of service has ranged from 34 years to a little over one year. Two of them have been President of the Senate, three have been Ministers, two have been Whips, and of course all have served in their various ways with dedication and distinction, particularly in our committee system.

Senator O'Byrne, the father of not only the Senate but also the Parliament, has been with us 34 years. Indeed, somebody has observed that when he came into the Senate neither Senator Neal nor Senator Puplick had even been born. Senator O'Byrne had a distinguished war career, followed by a very long career in the Senate. He was President for nearly two years. Those of us who were here at the time were particularly impressed by the way he presided over us and were grateful for his fairness in that office.

Senators Cavanagh and Bishop are the next two longest serving senators who are retiring. They have both been here for the same length of time, 19 years. They both came from a distinguished background in the union movement in South Australia and both served as Ministers for three years in the Whitlam Government. I had an association with Senator Bishop for part of that time when I was shadowing him as Postmaster-General. I certainly enjoyed that association, it being my first opportunity of serving on the front bench, and I appreciated the help that he, as Minister, gave me.

Senator Cavanagh, as I said, also served as a Minister in that Government, but the work for which I think he has acquired a reputation and for which he is better known amongst us is his work on Senate committees, particlarly the Standing Orders Committee and the Regulations and Ordinances Committee. It has been a pleasure of mine to serve with him on the Regulations and Ordinances Committee. Although I have never shared the fascinations he seems to have had for Standing Orders and the debates about them, I am sure that he has made a major contribution in that area.

The next two senators I wish to mention are also bracketed for various reasons. They are Senators Sim and Wheeldon. Both, of course are from my own State of Western Australia; they have both been in the Senate for almost the same length of time; and both of them are very long-standing personal friends of mine. Indeed, I have known Senator Wheeldon longer than I have known anybody else in this chamber. It was in 1947 or 1948 that we first met. I will not go into all the circumstances in which we met. The way in which we can agree and disagree and perhaps occasionally agree again-that is in some respects, I might say, especially in relation to foreign affairs-is a major tribute to the vigorous way in which we approach our political life. Both Senator Sim and Senator Wheeldon have had a major interest in foreign affairs and have made important contributions in this chamber, in the committees of this chamber and, indeed, in the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs.

Senator Davidson has been a member of the Senate for a little longer, I believe, than Senator Sim and Senator Wheeldon. He had a somewhat shaky start but settled down to 16 years continuous service from 1965. Senator Davidson has been a man of many parts in those years. He has been a great committee man-in fact, one of the pioneers of the committee system. The Senate Select Committee on Water Pollution on which he distinguished himself, of course, was one of the notable early select committees of the Senate. He has taken a great interest also in the National Library and has a very distinguished record of service in the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association, having been on the executive of that body for a period.

Then, Mr President, in order of length of service, we come to you. You, Sir, have been our President now for five and a half years. We are all deeply indebted to you for your service in that capacity. You had earlier service in many capacities in the Senate. But it is your work as President that we acknowledge especially. The way in which you have been able to keep us all in order and to solve those little problems that arise from time to time in this chamber by some quiet way which I have never been able to quite understand is remarkable. It has been a most effective method of doing so. We all recognise it. I think the secret is simply that we all recognise what a basic sense of fairness you have in your treatment of all of us. You have been able to control us by that most effective method.

Senator Maunsell has been a member of this Senate for 13 years. He has served for some six or seven of those years as the National Country Party Whip as well as serving on committees of the Senate. He has had a particular interest in matters relating to defence and occasionally has been on the offensive. He has been very effective as the Chairman of Committees over the last 18 months.

Senator McAuliffe came into the Senate at the same time as I did. He has shown a particular interest in financial matters and that, I have no doubt, befits a former businessman. He has been on committees with a bent in that direction and has contributed to them and in this chamber notably on those matters and, of course, on matters of sport. I think it is, perhaps, a salutary lesson for us to note that he is leaving us to take on a very major position in the sporting world in his major interest of rugby league.

Next I mention Senator Melzer who has been with us for nearly eight years. That seems to be a very short time. Senator Melzer has always shown a particularly live interest in matters affecting people; she has shown deep human interests. She has always had the interests of people primarily at heart. It is notable that her last contribution today was on a subject that she has been very concerned about. Her contribution demonstrated her concern for people, which I have always noticed.

Senator Puplick has been with us for only a relatively short time-three years. In that period he has shown a remarkable range of interests and a tremendous capacity for work on our committee system and particularly in contributions to debates in this chamber. I am certain that Senator Puplick, who is leaving us for only a temporary period, will rejoin us either here or in another place; he is only just beginning his parliamentary career.

Finally Senator Neal, who is the shortest serving of our 12 colleagues who are leaving us, has in a short time made a mark because of his particular interests in education and government affairs. I almost said constitutional affairs. He has the distinction of being only the second person, I think, who has asked me a question of the Constitutional Convention. Senator Neal has been a hard working and earnest senator. He is a young man and I am sure that this is not by any means the end of his political career and that we will see him returning either here or in some other parliamentary political role.

Mr President, as I said at the beginning, it is a pleasant occasion tinged with sadness. However, I am sure that the friendships that have been made with our 12 retiring colleagues are ones that will endure. I trust that they will enjoy their period of retirement and that we will see them returning here from time to time. I can assure them that they will always be welcomed by their former colleagues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to associate the Australian Labor Party with the good wishes and tributes to our retiring colleagues that have been put forward by the Attorney-General (Senator Durack). In a very short time we will have lost a considerable amount of talent and experience in this House, if we take into account the 12 people who leave us this month and add to them Ken Wriedt, Glen Sheil and the late John Knight, who left us only recently. As a relative newcomer, I have appreciated the assistance and the knowledge I have received from those who leave today. They are all good parliamentarians, they are all concerned for the welfare of their fellow citizens and they are all concerned for the maintenance of high standards of politics in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: On the Government side, Gordon Davidson is well known for his contributions to the various parliamentary committees-the Inter-parliamentary Union, the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association and the Parliamentary Christian Fellowship. Peter Sim is known to all of us for his goodwill and his carefully considered and, I might say, independent views on foreign affairs. Ron Maunsell is known for his contribution as Whip and Deputy President and for his appreciation of seafood in this place. Chris Puplick is known for his prolific and carefully researched contributions on diverse subjects, and Laurie Neal is known for his quiet, thoughtful and careful contributions, particularly on education and rural affairs. Last, but not least, Mr President, is your own fair, impartial and, if I might say, gentle conduct in your occupancy of the presidency throughout what have sometimes been fairly turbulent times. I know my own somewhat irascible behaviour has at times not made your job easy, but I hope you hold no ill-will for that. We have appreciated your assistance in this place.

I now mention my own comrades, of whom we all have special memories. Reg Bishop, a former Minister for Repatriation and Postmaster-General, brought to this place the experience of years of activity in the trade union movement, in particular in the Australian Railways Union. As the son of a railway man, I claim some affinity. This experience and this desire for careful and conciliatory industrial relations came through only today in Question Time with his obvious desire to ensure that the differences in the present industrial dispute are settled in a calm, unemotional and non-combative atmosphere. I believe that his quiet and thoughtful contributions will be missed.

Jim Cavanagh represents in many ways the parliamentarian par excellence. His contribution as a Minister was considerable, but to many of us his unremitting defence of the rights of individual senators, both in this place and in the party room, his determination to ensure that legislation received proper scrutiny and, expecially, that regulations and ordinances did not impinge on civil rights, were great contributions. Many of us sought and still seek Jim's advice on legislative and procedural matters, and we will indeed miss him.

Ron McAuliffe is a colourful character. He is a fair and good-humoured chairman of our parliamentary caucus. I was first associated with him as Chairman of the Public Accounts Committee when he was a meticulous and very fair Chairman. His ability to defuse a tense situation with a joke, both in this Parliament and especially in the party room, will be sadly missed. As someone said the other night, our loss will be rugby league's gain.

Jean Melzer came into the Parliament with me. As innocents abroad, she moved and I seconded the adoption of the Address-in-Reply, and neither of us had a clue on what it was all about. She has contributed to this place a deeply felt concern for the disadvantaged in the community and particularly for the rights of women. In her prolific contributions in committee, she was always undaunted by so-called experts who had inflated ideas of their own importance. My association with Jean has led me to admire her determination and her sense of humanitarian concern. I am distressed that she will not be back and by the circumstances which have led to her not coming back, but I hope she will be back eventually. Jean probably knows more about me than is good for me, and I had better leave it at that.

John Wheeldon, whose ability as a speaker is the envy of everyone in this place, whose encyclopaedic knowledge of foreign affairs and defence has caused me and, I am sure, others much wonder, will also be missed. His vigorous and determined efforts to bring to the attention of this country the injustice and the futility of our Vietnam involvement is the thing for which I first knew him and for which I will always remember him. We wish John Wheeldon well.

Last, may I come to my friend and comrade Justin O'Byrne who, as many of you know, comes from the same town as I do. Some of you will never forgive him for the fact that I would not be here if it were not for Justin O'Byrne. He had a distinguished war service. He has had a distinguished parliamentary career. In his 35 years of service in this place I suggest that he has been vilified as much as anybody else has been. He has been condemned from the platform and from the soap box, and indeed he has been condemned from the pulpit. He still maintains his support for his beliefs and has never hesitated to take up unpopular causes, no matter what personal difficulties his support for those causes brought about. Some 35 years ago, when Justin O'Byrne was elected to this place, a distinguished conservative member of what I may call the Launceston establishment wrote a letter to the Launceston Examiner. The final words of that letter were, roughly: 'Senator O'Byrne will find that, with his views, Justin is soon just out.' Justin has been here a long time. The gentleman who wrote the letter is no longer with us. Justin will soon be just out, after 35 years of experience, and I personally wish to thank him for his assistance in various aspects over the years.

We wish all the retiring members well in their retirement. We hope they have a long retirement. We hope that those who wish to come back will return. On behalf of the Labor Party, I wish you all well. I hope that you do not forget us and that you use your abilities to get back here and see us or to bail us up as we come through your various cities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Country Party)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, what a pleasant place this is now that the dust of earlier today has settled. I want, briefly, to endorse the remarks of the previous two speakers and to add my own thoughts and those of my party, the National Country Party, on this occasion when we are losing a number of significant people from this chamber. Jean Melzer and the men who are going out have contributed a great deal to this chamber over many years, cumulatively and individually. They have served long terms in this Parliament. They represent, I am sure, a real cross-section of the community that they serve. Indeed, they represent a cross-section of this Parliament; perhaps the upper end of this Parliament. They will be a loss to us and a gain to the community and societies to which they return.

SPEECH.PARA: Very briefly let me say just a word about them as individuals. Justin O'Byrne is remarkable from many points of view. He was a fighter pilot, a prisoner-of-war, and a very distinguished ex-President of the Senate. As our leader said, he has been longer in this chamber than Senators Neal and Puplick have been on this planet, and that is a very significant achievement. Reg Bishop is an ex-Minister and a delightful companion with whom on one occasion I had the privilege to move around South East Asia and Korea. I found him not only a friend but also a great help in those circumstances. Jim Cavanagh is a strong South Australian like Reg Bishop. When I first came here very briefly 10 years or so ago I though Jim Cavanagh was a forbidding looking gentleman; but, as time goes by I find it is really only a mask, it is not true. He is not really a forbidding character but he is indeed the possessor of a fine mind. His capacity to analyse problems is sometimes, I find, rather amusingly a problem to those who are specifically qualified to do that sort of thing.

I turn now to John Wheeldon. I have enjoyed, as indeed all of us must have enjoyed, his great capacity to speak. We recognise his knowledge, appreciation and perspective of history. We are losing in John Wheeldon a great promoter of whatever it is he promotes from time to time. We are lucky to have been associated with Ron McAuliffe. He has been robust in delivery and in material in debate. I am sure that he will be missed here, but people in Queensland will be glad to have his putting more time into rugby league, something Tony Mulvihill is pretty worried about down south. I had the opportunity of attending a conference in Mauritius a few years ago with Jean Melzer. Jean established herself there, as she has in this chamber, as a very sincere and creditable performer-a good Australian. I believe Gordon Davidson has been an impeccable senator on almost any grounds-the voice, the manner, the clothing, the man. My friend Senator Sim-Mr Foreign Affairs and Defence-is a man of beetling brow and apparent anger, but he is not really that bad at all.

Mr President, you are indeed a gentleman, and we are fortunate to have had you in authority over these years. You are, besides being a distinguished parliamentarian, a miller, a producer of wines and, indeed, a connoisseur. From many points of view you are a legend in your own time. Senator Chris Puplick has a youthful enthusiasm such as I have never seen before and a capacity to express it such as I have never heard before. We are sure that Chris will be back, and it will be a pleasure to welcome him back. In my own corner I refer to my very distinguished friend Senator Ron Maunsell. Ron told me virtually everything I know about this place; I expect honourable senators are about to say 'Well, that's not much', and that is probably true. But I must say it is not his fault. Ron has what I would describe as a marvellous nose for what is going on. If he does not know, well, it certainly has not happened, and if he has not heard of it, it probably never will happen. Ron Maunsell has gone from fighter pilot to bulldozer operator and has been a distinguished and long-serving senator. We are sorry to see him leave us. Finally I refer to my friend Senator Neal. Laurie has been here too short a time but it has been time enough for us to recognise his qualities, his sincerity and his capacity. I think for an ex-lecturer in political science to come into this chamber and to see all the pages of his textbooks really shredded is quite an achievement; it takes a lot of courage to do that sort of thing. I asked Laurie a few weeks ago to act more or less as host to our new senator from Queensland, Senator Florence Bjelke-Petersen. He has done that job extremely well, althought I get the impression that conversationally he has not had to contribute very much. Finally, I give a thought for my old friend Glen Shiel who is not here now but whose presence in many senses will be missed in this chamber and particularly even more so on the tennis court when the Senate is battling with the House of Representatives. So, Mr President, it is with those very brief thoughts that I wish all these retiring senators the very best of health and good fortune.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Byrne Sen The Hon J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, Senator Durack, Senator Grimes and Senator Scott, I am indeed thankful to you for the eulogies you have directed to me in particular but especially to the retiring senators with whom I have had the great honour of serving over various periods of years. Time will prevent me from reiterating many of the well-deserved tributes that have been paid to the honourable senators who are retiring, but I say on my own behalf that it has been a great privilege and a very rewarding experience for me to have spent half my lifetime in the Senate. It has been rewarding because I have had the honour of serving in two Labor governments from 1947 to 1949 and from 1972 to 1975. That period, as I have said, has given me tremendous pleasure and satisfaction.

SPEECH.PARA: The thrust and parry of politics I will miss very much, and I will miss the comradeship that flows right through the whole of the membership of the Senate. There have been times of great trauma and conflict but there have been times of great humour. I think it is that overall scene that has made it such an interesting place. I have found this to be a grand place to get to know and to learn the value of each individual person who comprises the Senate.

I pay a tribute to and thank the people of the Labor Party in Tasmania and the electors of Tasmania for paying me the great honour of representing them here over so many years. Now that I am relinquishing the mantle of the father of the Senate to the very capable hands of Senator Douglas McClelland I wish to say how much I appreciate the service that he has given to the Senate too. I might say, incidentally, that the new mother of the Senate is the very distinguished Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, and I welcome her into the motherhood.

I have seen a great improvement in the Senate in my time. When I first came here Dame Dorothy Tangney was feted and respected very highly. She was joined by Dame Annabelle Rankin in the 1946 to 1949 period. But we have seen in the Senate the number of members of the important side of the community lifted to nine, and I think any honourable senator who spends as much time as I have in the Senate will possibly see at the end of his or her career 50-50 representation of men and women in the Senate. Senator Grimes mentioned that it was said that I would be 'just in' and 'just out'. I was the youngest senator in this place when I was elected, and people would say to me: 'What do you expect to achieve in the Senate. How are things going there?' I would say: 'Well, one ambition I have among many others is to become the oldest senator'. Longevity and survival are among the secrets of parliamentary life and I have been very glad to have served those years.

People of varying philosophies have been sent here. Underlying our wish to come here has been the desire of us all to serve our country well and faithfully according to our convictions. If I can speak on behalf of the retiring senators I think they in particular have all made a splendid contribution and the country itself is richer for their contribution here. We learn to respect our opponents, and we also get to learn to like them. It is on an occasion such as this that one has the pleasure of recognising and recalling the goodness in men and women in the Senate with whom one has sometimes disagreed, but one also gives credit where credit is due.

Before I conclude-my time is limited-I would like to pay a tribute to you, Mr President, for the impartial and tolerant way in which you have presided over the Senate, and also to the officers of the Senate for the wonderful help that I have received personally and we all have received from them over the years. I pay tribute also to those devoted and dedicated people who have reported our speeches and made many of our speeches; some of my best speeches have been made by the Hansard reporters. I thank also the people who serve us so well in the Library, the attendants, the wonderful people who put up with us in the dining room and in the refreshment room, the Australian Broadcasting Commission staff who look after the presentation of our speeches and our image to the people outside, the transport drivers who have taken us to and from this place with great dedication, and the officers of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association and the Inter-Parliamentary Union. I thank them personally for the wonderful, devoted service that they have given, not only to me but also to the institution of the Senate.

I wish those who are retiring good health and happiness in the future. To those who remain in the Senate I say that the future is in their hands. Having seen the tremendous changes that have taken place in my lifetime-indeed we suffer from future shock; the scientists have got ahead of the humans-so many adjustments will have to be made that the future will have to be very delicately handled. I am sure it will be in very good hands. I say farewell to you and I thank you all for the friendship and the comradeship that I have enjoyed over the many years of my incumbency as a senator for Tasmania.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Davidson Sen G.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, Senator Durack, Senator Grimes and Senator Scott, like all of us who are leaving this place today, we are moving in something of a pattern of recollection. I am very grateful for the sentiments which have been expressed today and I would like to add my thanks for the many tokens, gestures, cards and personal references which have been made during these last few days. Public life, like all life, does not end simply because a certain date has been reached. The influence of years and the influence of achievements lives on. As we retire today we hope that any contributions that have been made will have their relationship to the things that will be done in the future. We are very grateful for so much that has been done for us. Senator Justin O'Byrne has outlined some of the friendships that we have with people who are part of this institution. I am glad that he has mentioned the people at the table, the attendants, the car drivers, the people in the dining and refreshment rooms and all others who have helped us in our duties.

SPEECH.PARA: I think especially of the number of Prime Ministers under whom it has been my privilege to serve. I think also of leaders in this place. I recall a series of Presidents and Whips and others who have all been part of one's life, part of one's public affairs and part of one's duties as one endeavours to carry out one's responsibilities as a senator. I had the privilege of being appointed to this place in September 1961 to replace the late Senator Rex Pearson of South Australia. In October 1961 I made my maiden speech. As everybody must surely know by now, it was all about River Murray water, a subject from which I seem to have been unable to escape ever since. In the course of my introductory remarks that day, Mr President, I said this:
Being a senator is a very great privilege which I value. I trust that . . . I may be able to exercise the appropriate measure of responsibility and serve as a senator should.

I shall always be grateful to Senator Don Willesee, who followed me that day, who made some very generous and very helpful remarks. I have stood by this line-to serve as a senator should-and it is not for me today to comment on that. Over the years it has been something of a maxim which, among others, has been in my mind as a kind of a guideline and help. When one has had the privilege of being a senator for this length of time there are a great number of activities with which one has been involved, and it would take too long to turn to them today.

There are three or four areas to which I would, if I may, like to refer. I want especially to refer to the Parliamentary Library because I have had the privilege of being a member of the Library Committee ever since I was appointed to the Senate. I recall the contributions of men like Sir Harold White, Alan Fleming, Leslie Moore and Harold Weir. I refer also to the way the Library has developed over the years and how it has upgraded its program, including the establishment of the Legislative Research Service. I pay my tribute to all those people who work sometimes under very difficult circumstances and who have been so good and have rendered assistance so many times.

The Attorney-General (Senator Durack) mentioned the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association. That has been one of my interests, one of my pleasures and one of the areas in which I have had the opportunity to extend myself. Apart from that I want to pay tribute to men like John Ferguson and Alistair MacDonald. They are the flag carriers for this very important international and historic organisation which is involved in a great range of Commonwealth areas of importance and significance politically and in terms of parliament. I want to thank the Senate today for the very great privilege it bestowed upon me in electing me to be its representative on the Council of the National Library of Australia. This has been of the greatest personal pleasure and satisfaction. Since 1973 I have been a member and, if I may presume to say so, since 1976 I have been its Deputy Chairman. I had the privilege of presiding over the Commonwealth Immigration Advisory Council for six years, at a time when there was an extensive integration program going on and it had an involvement in Australia's population development. I have also been associated with the Parliamentary Christian Fellowship, to which reference has already been made. Reference was also made to its meaning to those who belong.

I wish to thank you, sir, and your predecessors for the experience of being one of your Temporary Chairmen. Reference has been made to this already today. It is a very great privilege, if I may put it this way, to represent you or the Chairman of Committees and to preside, from time to time, over the deliberations of the chamber. This leads me to make special reference to you, Mr President, because you are not only my fellow South Australian, not only are you my colleague in public and political circles in South Australia, but also you are a man of great distinction. As others have said before me today, you have presided over our assemblies with a grace, courtesy and impartiality that we shall long remember.

As far as the Senate committees are concerned, I mentioned them often and as late as yesterday. I have only to reiterate here my appreciation of their value and my counsel to the Senate is that it look after the Senate committee system because I believe that system is going to be one of the greatest strengths of this important house of parliament.

So, Sir, we take our leave, with a rich recollection of the Parliament and all that it represents. I trust that the Australian national Parliament will always preserve the rich fabric of its life and style. Parliament must be the place which gives full play to debate to argument and to comprise, while the tension is such that the sound is strong and definite yet where the final tone represents the blend of the voices of the people. Above all, the high court of Parliament-I use the term advisedly-whether in this chamber or in one of its committees, remains supreme.

May I take a moment as I close to remember the place where it all began-the Liberal Party in South Australia and the South Australian people who bestowed upon me the privilege of representing them here. May I remember my family home and the community of Strathalbyn in South Australia. There I started my career in public life, believe it or not, 40 years ago. There have been so many influences, so many opportunities. I am indeed profoundly grateful. I think also of what happened later in the Adelaide suburb of Glenelg, with more associates of value, in my own home and of the role played in my public life by my own wife over all these years. I thank her and I thank honourable senators for their references to her.

Mr President, the motto of the Davidson clan is sapienter si sincere-wisely if sincerely. On those occasions when I do call it to mind it has been a good guideline to help me to endeavour to remain close to that which I affirmed in this place and on this very spot 20 years ago, and that is to serve as a senator should. God bless you all, and my thanks for all that you have done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cavanagh Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a brief few minutes to thank those who have spoken in admiration of me and my work in the Senate. I particularly thank Senator Carrick for his statements yesterday and the letter he personally wrote to me and senator Button for his remarks last evening. Mr President, possibly the most cruel word in the English language is the word 'goodbye'. And now we have reached that stage where we get a few kind words, perhaps a parting glass and a hand that waves adieu, and from your sight I soon shall pass and from your memory too. Over the years I have become endeared to the Senate. When I first came here many remarked: 'If only he had a university education or if only he had studied law what a great man he would be'. I much liked this. I could not have found a nicer way or more diplomatic way of saying: 'You are no good as you are but there are possibilities for you'. But with all my limitations, Mr President, I have done my best through the campaign. If I had a forbidden face-or forbidding face, I think it was-it could well have been contributed to by my period on earth. I have lived through the most depressing time the world has known. I lived through the only two world wars we have experienced. I was a victim of the greatest depression the world has seen and I also suffered as a result of the greatest constitutional crisis Australia has seen. Mr President, we went through all those times and now, as I have said, it is time to say goodbye. I realise I fought politics hard; I was not at all times kind to my opponents in debate. The only thing I can say in conclusion, to use the words of Henry Lawson, is:

SPEECH.PARA: I was human, only human, and if in days misspent,
I have injured man or woman, it was done without intent.
If at times when stumbling blindly, heavy heart and aching brow,
If I said a world unkindly, then I am sorry for it now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sim Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have always believed in short speeches. I have been allotted five minutes but I will not take that long. Somebody said-I am not sure who it was, and I do not even know whether he said it!-words to the effect: Curse my enemies and bless my friends. I hope I leave this place without having to curse anyone and only to bless my friends on both sides of the chamber. I have enjoyed my nearly 17 years in this place; it has been a challenging and interesting experience. I have enjoyed the friendship of many people from all walks of life, but, above all, I mention my political opponents. I will not name them all, but I look across and see perhaps some of my closest friends sitting on the opposite side of the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: I particularly enjoyed my long experience, as has been mentioned very kindly and generously by many people, with the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence. This has been a concern which I have found tremendously challenging and tremendously interesting and in this, my last speech in the chamber, I pay tribute to those who, over some 10 years, have served on the Committee with me. They have all been my personal friends; their support and loyalty have always been given so freely. I am afraid that some of my present friends-as I look across the chamber I note that Cyril Primmer is not here at the moment, but I link him with Gordon McIntosh and Kerry Sibraa-have been through a tremendous experience over the last fortnight. I think we have had too much to eat-I will stop there-at the many farewells which my friends have been so generous to give me.

I thank Senator Primmer, the Deputy Chairman of that Committee for many years, for his great loyalty and his great support. I thank Kerry Sibraa who has spoken so generously about me in this place. I do appreciate the generosity of his remarks and support. Above all I mention my little Western Australian Scot, Senator Gordon McIntosh for his support. I look across and I see my old friend Reg Bishop. Reg and I have a pact; we say nothing. So, thank you so much for the generosity you have shown me and for all the friendships. I will miss them, but I shall remember everyone with kindness and generosity. I do not guarantee to listen to you.

To you, Mr President, may I say that I have enjoyed your long friendship and your continuing generosity. I pay tribute to you for that friendship, that generosity, and the work that you have done as the Presiding Officer in this chamber. You are a man of great impartiality. You are a gentleman in every sense of the word and a man of great tolerance. Perhaps some of us should learn to have the tolerance that you have. To Senator Carrick, to Senator Durack who is a friend of long standing from Western Australia, to my other Western Australian colleagues over many years and my other colleagues on my side of the House, I say thank you for your friendship and your support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Durack), Senator Grimes, the Acting Leader of the Opposition and Senator Doug Scott, firstly, I say that I appreciate very much the comments which have been made, certainly under very special circumstances. Those who have spoken have had, I suppose, a good relationship with honourable senators on this side of the Senate. In particular may I remark on what Senator Sim has said today. What he has said highlights one of the advantages of the committee system of the Senate. His very brief remarks, and an occasional mistake, remind me of another occasion when Senator Button kept referring to Senator Sim as Senator Slim. The President at the time kept saying to Senator Button, 'You mean Senator Sim, senator', and he said, 'Yes, I said Senator Slim'. Some of the honourable senators in the place who must evoke that sort of comment from me about the advantages of the committee system are Senator Sim and also the ex-President, your predecessor, Mr President, Senator Sir Magnus Cormack.

SPEECH.PARA: Two very active conservative Liberal Party supporters in the Senate often disturbed this side of the chamber. If one got them on a committee one found that they were remarkable people in that they tried to reach agreement with the group. As a result of that, if one likes to read the recommendations which those committees made one will find they are remarkable for their unanimity of opinion. That is one of the things which the Senate can continue to do. The other thing, I suggest, is that governments have to be more aware of what the Senate committees recommend. I share with Senator Peter Sim and also with Sir Magnus those great moments in the committee where, although we might have differed, we were able to reach recommendations which were public, which became important, but which unfortunately did not always become the policies of the Government. I think we have to try to see-or those who are here have to-that the Senate performs a duty in that respect in the future. Of course, after 30 June that may happen. There will be a new Senate and a new power in the Senate, and we will be looking at the Senate to see whether it will perform its duties perhaps more than it has done in the past.

That brings me briefly to the role which most of us have played. I know the South Australians here, as Senator Scott has expressed the point, have always argued that we were strong South Australians, and so we were. We were also strong Australians and we were able to combine the appreciation of the State's performance. Many of us moved motions in support of our State on lots of matters, not only the Murray about which Senator Davidson talks but also about roads, railways and industry. We were able to do that and at the same time remember that the Commonwealth of Australia is a major consideration in this country. The Westminster system did not perform well or at least we did not use the system as well as we might have done. Let us hope that in the future we can reach the objective in a more classical way than we did in the past.

I share with those honourable senators who have spoken the appreciation of all the people who have supported us-Hansard, the Parliamentary Library, the people who service the place, the attendants, the drivers, the people in the Refreshment Rooms-they have been wonderful-the Senate staff and the parliamentary officers who do all the things for us. They are remarkable for doing all those things. Finally, I just want to say that of course not many people become or are able to become a Minister in a government. As Senator Grimes has said I am an ordinary railwayman who became a trades hall secretary. I never thought that I would become a Minister of the Crown. I was a Minister of the Crown. I worked with people like Lance Barnard, who was the Minister for Defence, and I was his assistant. As Senator Durack has said I was able to do an important job in the Postmaster General's area, which made a remarkable change in communications in Australia. I want to thank firstly my party, for having allowed me to come here. A senator whom honourable senators might remember, Senator Clem Ridley, was the person who first reminded me that it was about time that I moved from the trade union movement to the Senate. So that is how I came into the Senate.

Without one's family it is not possible to do anything. I have been in that sort of job for nearly 40 years now and if it were not for our wives and family it would not have been possible to do the sort of things we have done. I wish all honourable senators well and I hope, Mr President, that we can share your hospitality in other areas and that we might be able to taste again that very wonderful beverage that you are going to market in the near future. Thank you, senators, for your thoughts.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Durack, the Acting Leader of the Opposition, Senator Grimes, Senator Doug Scott of the National Country Party and honourable senators, many thoughts crowd on my mind this afternoon. I consider myself a most fortunate man to have sought to serve in this place with you all. It has been a magnificent experience with a magnificent body of men and women. I have listened to the tributes you have paid to those good colleagues who are retiring, and I thank you for reference to my own humble efforts. There is something about this place and moments such as this typify the marvellous spirit of which I speak. All I can say is thank you very much to all of you. I am deeply mindful of the splendid co-operation that I have received from my personal staff, the leaders of the parties in this place, the Ministers, the Whips and the members of the Senate as a whole.

INTERJECT.PARA: I pay warm tribute to the dedicated and tireless services of all personnel within the Department of the Senate, from the Clerks office through the whole gamut of service in the Department. In the service departments of Hansard, Library and Joint House that same degree of splendid service and co-operation has prevailed. The ramifications of service go outside the immediate building to the gardeners, the police force, our transport officers and drivers and so on. I thank them all most heartily.

I have said before in this chamber that the institution of Parliament-the institution of the Senate-is at all times greater than any member of it. It matters not what we are in the scheme of things here; we are all custodians of the system pro tem, even though some of us have been privileged to be members of parliament for quite a long while. For instance, Senator Justin O'Byrne, my friend, the father of the Senate and the Parliament, has served here for some 35 years, half of the allotted span of three score years and ten. I pay tribute to him for his great service, as I do in like measure to all my retiring colleagues. For the time being and in a long progression we are all incumbents of a system which is basically the Westminster system as it has stood for some 700 years and, in our institution here, since the turn of the century.

In wise councils of generations of senators we have achieved a great progress in the effectiveness of this chamber. In the past decade magnificent benefits have accrued to the chamber, the parliament, the state and the nation through the development of our committee system. May this place ever respect the past, but build on it to meet the challenges of a progressive society. May it never weaken but ever strengthen the democratic institution. Again may I thank you all for your many kindnesses and wish each of you well indeed for the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wheeldon Sen The Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I join with my colleagues in thanking for their kind words those who have spoken so well of us. I also thank all those who have been of assistance to me and other senators while we have been members of the Senate. I have shared their experience of fine treatment from the parliamentary staff, the Library and others. The only aspect of parliamentary life in which I have not shared is that which has been referred to by Senator Davidson, that is, the Federal Parliamentary Christian Fellowship. I must confess that so far I have not attended any of its gatherings, and indeed after today it will be too late in any case. Many of us who for conscientious or other reasons felt that we were unable to join that organisation heard about the good times they had together and were envious of them. In fact, His Honour Mr Justice Murphy, while a member of this Senate, and I engaged in a quite serious endeavour to establish a Federal parliamentary fellowship of atheists, agnostics, Jews and scientologists to cater for those of us who felt excluded.

SPEECH.PARA: When I first came into the Parliament, like most of us I suppose, being human, I used to achieve a certain small measure of ecstasy at seeing my photograph in a newspaper, even if the story which appeared alongside it consisted of a garbled account of something I had said or an allegation that I had been at a secret meeting plotting the overthrow of the leadership of the Labor Party when I had been in a different city from that in which the meeting took place. In fact, one often achieved a certain thrill at seeing one's face on a television screen while one was being asked silly questions by a disc jockey with ideas above his station. But as the years pass the charm of that tends to wear off. I remember that at the height of one great controversy, when I think I was being accused of being an agent of the Chinese Communist Party-which some suggest I still am-a near neighbour, a prominent businessman, asked me whether I could take up some matter with Sir Charles Court because he knew that I was a Liberal member of the Legislative Assembly and would undoubtedly have great influence on him.

Mr President, I think one should stay in the Parliament only if one feels either that one is accomplishing something of very great significance, or is about to accomplish something of very great significance, or if one is in a position to struggle better inside the Parliament than outside the Parliament for some cause in which one believes. In my own case, I do not feel that any of those three things apply and I intend to undertake activities elsewhere. However, this is not because I do not believe in and respect the institution of Parliament. Whatever faults it may have, whatever misfortunes we may have experienced, I do not believe there is any better system of government anywhere in the world than the parliamentary system of a freely elected democratic parliament in which the members are representatives of the people who elect them.

Certain things have happened recently and I do not want to discuss again the merits of the matter that happened in 1975, which rightly or wrongly have caused a number of Australians to have some doubts about the efficacy of the parliamentary system. Some of the attacks on Parliament-very minor ones compared with what has happened in other parts of the world-I think are a result of what happened at that time. I do not think that those of us on this side of the House or anybody else should belabour those matters but should endeavour to see that respect for Parliament is restored. For as long as there are gerrymandered electorates, for as long as there is violent personal abuse and constant criticism of the bona fides of people with whom one politically disagrees, I do not believe that there will be respect for Parliament. With only a very small number of parliamentary democracies throughout the world, I think that this would be a most serious matter.

I have tended to be more interested, I suppose, in foreign affairs than in other matters since I have been in this Parliament, and this has been so because I believe that an interest in foreign affairs is not something which should be just a side issue. We cannot have a successful domestic policy unless we have a successful foreign policy. Czechoslovakia, Denmark, Norway and Holland were all admirable countries in the 1930s, in many respects leading the world in social reforms and a long way ahead of where most of the world is now. It did them no good when they were conquered by nazism, and I believe that, however excellent our policies may be on social welfare finance, agriculture or anything else if our country is under serious threat from some other source then it is all to no avail whatsoever.

I spent the first half of my period in the Parliament-a period of eight years-involved in the struggle about the participation in the Vietnam war. I took that position because I was opposed to anybody's imperialism, to anybody invading another country, and I believed that the Americans had no business inside Vietnam. At that time, and at the time when I first became interested in politics, one tends to forget, I suppose, that a very large part of the world was still in Western colonialist hands. Even countries such as India, which is now a mighty country, were part of the British Empire. Most of Africa, large parts of Asia, and the Caribbean were foreign colonies. This is no longer the case. I believe that the menace now comes from another area. I believe that there is a foreign power which has shown by its actions that it is a colonialist power, that it is determined upon the destruction of the institutions which are represented by this Parliament. I think that this calls for solidarity among democratic countries throughout the world.

So far as detente is concerned, insofar as it means that there is a relaxation of military tensions I believe it is desirable, but I think that a number of Western leaders have had a mistaken approach to this matter. They should have noted what Mr Brezhnev has said-that military tension should be coupled with a continuation of the ideological struggle. If one continues the ideological struggle then one is doing only what Mr Brezhnev has invited us to do. If I may comment on one passing side issue which may give us an opportunity to do that sort of thing, I notice that a delegation of the World Council of Churches will shortly be visiting Australia. Even the most fervent admirer of the World Council of Churches would acknowledge it is much more of a political than an ecclesiastical organisation. One of its members is a clerical gentleman from East Germany-the German Democratic Republic-who is coming to this country to inquire into Aborigines. I do not think that one needs to be either malicious or psychic to know precisely what sort of report he will be bringing down. I do not believe that he should not be allowed to come here. I think that people like that should be welcomed, but I believe that when he does come here he ought to be asked questions. If he is so interested in civil liberties in this country, he ought to be asked what he has done about the rights of Uniat Catholics, the rights of Jews, the rights of Baptists, the rights of Lutherans within the Soviet Union, why it is that he has a wall around his country which nobody is allowed to leap, why it is that within his country and other associated countries political parties such as the fraternal parties of the Australian Labor Party are illegal.

These are the great issues which confront this country, and I do not mention them lightly. I believe that the appropriate place for them to be dealt with is in a Parliament such as this. I believe that there are people in this Parliament who are capable of dealing with them, and I wish them well in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maunsell Sen C.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Durack, Senator Grimes and my old friend Senator Doug Scott for their kind remarks. I also thank the two leaders who spoke earlier in the week and the many friends in this place who have delivered their kind wishes personally. My time is limited, so I will confine myself to speaking about what I regard as the most important thing I have experienced in this place, and that is the many friendships I have made not only on both sides of the House but also among the people who are associated with the Senate. I refer to the staff Justin O'Byrne mentioned-the staff of the Parliamentary Refreshment Rooms, the drivers, the Clerks, every one of them. They have always been helpful and willing to do what they can to make life here as pleasant as possible, despite the circumstances that long hours and heavy debates have brought upon us from time to time. I will certainly remember the many kindnesses extended to me.

SPEECH.PARA: That goes even a little further than has been mentioned here. I have made many friends in the Press Gallery. Whilst they have not always been helpful-my friend John Wheeldon has mentioned a few instances-I have certainly made some friends among them. When I come back to this place again and see you all working long hours and getting very serious at different times in debate about different matters I will be able to sit on the sidelines with my other colleagues and say: 'I still have many friends here and it is always a pleasure to come back and see them'.

I hope that the Senate will continue its role as a House of Review, not as a States' House. It has only operated as a States' House when the South Australians, the Tasmanians or even the Queenslanders have raised specific issues, but they have never been in agreement; they have always been against one another. I believe that the Senate has a role to play as a House of review and I believe that it has to improve its review of legislation. I would hope to see the day when the House of government and the House of the people, as I regard the other House, brings down the legislation and this House really puts a fine toothcomb through it so that the legislation which results is to the benefit of this nation.

I thank everyone here for the great friendship I have experienced over the years. It is one of the things that I will miss. If anyone here gets a bit tired of the climate in the southern areas and decides to go to that beautiful place called Cairns I will make him welcome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McAuliffe Sen R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having seen the very aggressive curtailment of debate on the Freedom of Information Bill, having heard an expose on the direction in which we should be going in relation to foreign affairs, and having in mind that there are another 18 senators' names on the list of speakers to take part in the debate before the Parliament rises at 4.30 p.m., I say that there may be some merit in what the late Eddie Ward once said to a former Prime Minister, Sir Robert Menzies, when tributes were being made to a deceased comrade. After hearing six or seven speeches he leant across the table and said: 'All I want you to say about me when I'm gone is that he was loved by all'.

SPEECH.PARA: Addressing myself to what is before us today, I want to say how deeply honoured I am to have been a member of the national Parliament. I am ever mindful at this moment of the thanks I owe to the party that I represent, the great Australian Labor Party, its branch membership and the electorate of Queensland who on three occasions returned me to the Parliament as a senator for Queensland. During my period in the Senate I have made some good friends, and I will cherish those warm friendships for the rest of my life. I value highly the experiences I have gained here. I suppose I share the same inward ambitions or thoughts of all the retiring senators who hope that, as a result of their service in and their contributions to this Parliament, they have made a small scratch on the mirror of time. That is all I hope that I have achieved. By way of final word I wish my colleagues who are also retiring a long, useful and happy retirement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, friends and colleagues, I hope that after I have spoken for the last time today it will not be said of me that nothing in his political life so became him as the leaving of it. As I recall my Shakespeare, that was originally said of the thane of Cawdor in the process of his being hanged. While the price of losing an election may be high, it is not yet that high here. I hope that, pre-selection committees and electors willing, this may be not so much a farewell as an au revoir.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to recognise, Mr President, the manifest kindnesses shown to me here-thanks to Frances and John, David, Bobbie, Barbara, Reina and all the other staff in the Library; the ladies in the dining room; the gentlemen in the bar; the drivers and the transport officers; Jan and the Senate Records people; to ministerial staff, especially those of Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle; the Whip, Cedric the head gardener; the attendants; the Clerks; the staff of the Department of the Senate and its committees; senior public servants such as my friend, Professor Ovington; even the Press, without which there could not be a free and continuing democracy; my own staff; and especially my own secretary, Margot.

I thank my party colleagues in New South Wales. They took a risk with a young 29-year-old Liberal radical. They have supported me, they have worked with and for me. I have had particular support from my general secretary, Greg Bartels, and my State President, David Patten. I hope that they have been satisfied with my performance, and that if they have judged me they have not found me wanting.

It is an invidious task to try to thank one's own colleagues. I mention a few, but I do not mean to exclude any: You, Mr President, for your courtesy and kindness; Ministers and Whips; Neville Bonner whom I single out because he more than any one signifies the strength and the decency of our political system, who with all the cards stacked against him, but with personal courage and integrity entered a political and parliamentary system that was open enough and free enough to see him today starting his second decade of service here; two South Australians Gordon Davidson and Harold Young who are friends, whose treatment of me is delightfully paternal without ever being paternalistic, two Victorians, Austin Lewis, as good a travelling companion as one could want, and Alan Missen whom I use as a touchstone when I am tempted to stray from the paths of genuine liberalism; my leader, John Carrick, for his advice and guidance; my Whips and old friends Bernie Kilgariff and Andrew Thomas; but perhaps above all my occasional flatmate, former employer, sometime physician and always friend, Peter Baume. Friendship is not capable of verbal expression. It simply is.

I was not the youngest senator to enter this place, only the second. That in itself is an exceptional honour. I am, however, the youngest to leave it. Like all those who come here, I leave with more undone than done. What I have done I hope has been well done. At least on whales, broadcasting, films, freedom of information, human rights, patents, education and environment, I hope that my intervention has been successful and has been to the real benefit of the people of Australia.
For Parliament the road ahead is not easy. I understand it was not meant to be. I draw attention to the words of Reinhold Niebuhr:
The temper and integrity with which the political fight is waged is more important for the health of a society than any particular policy.

I hope that temper and integrity which do exist here will be maintained. The democracy we have in Australia is not perfect. No scheme designed by man or indeed by woman can be. Compared with the alternatives in this sorry world however it is worth fighting for and certainly still worth dying for. From my side of the chamber I venture to say only this: Solutions lie not in tempering true liberalism with even heavier doses of crude pragmatism but rather in watering down that pragmatism with ever greater doses of true, caring, intelligent liberalism; accepting the principle of compromise but rejecting the compromise of principle; accepting that like Christianity liberalism has not failed, it has simply never really been tried.

I conclude by paying tribute to the unsung heroines of this place-our wives. I was married after I became a senator. To that extent I have not had a conventional married life; I have never had the full degree of personal privacy--

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about your unconventional married life.

—You would understand it if you were my age. I have never had the degree of personal privacy enjoyed by other Australians; I have never been free of the telephone or the strains of public life. Let me simply say that in such circumstances one manages to stay sane and human, one can be an effective parliamentarian and an effective servant of the public only if one is supported by an exceptional woman whose love and understanding seem without limit. I have been more than fortunate. Of all the things that have blessed me during my life, the greatest is to have had a partner Francesca to whom, on the public record, I pay, without embarrassment or shame, my tribute and express my reciprocal love and gratitude. So thank you honourable senators. When you re-assemble on 18 August for the Budget I will lift my glass to you all from a hotel balcony in Rome, and you will know that some little part of me will be here. To your immense relief and joy, it will not be the part that still talks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Melzer Sen J.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I feel at a complete loss now. I knew that what I needed all this time was a good woman at home. Perhaps if I had had a woman at home I would not have been leaving at this stage in my career. I learnt early that there was a lot more to politics than just this place and I learnt early-despite what some of my colleagues have said about the fine and fiery debates that have gone on in this place-that it did not really matter what I said in here and that if I stood up and made a speech that Disraeli would have been proud of it would not have won one vote on the other side of this chamber. So I learnt that if one was going to express fine sentiments one ought to express them outside this place.

SPEECH.PARA: At one stage I was pulled up short by Kathy Martin, I hope my friend, when she said in a debate here 'There's one thing about Senator Melzer-you could set her speeches to music'. I realised what I was doing. It was all fine flowery purple prose, and that was not what this place was about either. But then my colleague from Victoria pulled me up the other night and said that, in his opinion, Melzer tried to solve all the problems with money. I must say that either I was very lacking in the ability to express my opinions or that he, as usual, was not listening properly. I am very well aware that one cannot solve the problems by throwing money around, but I feel very deeply that one can spread the money in quite different directions sometimes from the direction it is being spread at the moment. I looked with Don Grimes the other day at the first speech I ever made here. I realised that much has happened in that seven years. One of the things I said was that I believed the function of government was to protect the weak and the disadvantaged and to foresee future needs and problems. I still believe that very deeply. It is not a matter of just throwing money at problems; it is a matter of governing. In my opinion it is a matter of using the resources of a country for the people of that country.

One of the groups in the community very close to my heart is the women of Australia. I believe that in many ways Parliament has passed their problems by. This has not always been because parliamentarians are uncaring male chauvinist pigs but because parliaments of Australia in the main are male dominated and are not always in a position to appreciate the problems of women because the members are not women. I think, as I watch parliament progress I will find more women in Parliament. As I travel around Australia I find that the women of Australia are on the move. More and more of them are seeing themselves now as people who can be public people and people who can make decisions. They see themselves as parliamentarians, and once they never ever saw themselves in that role. So I look forward to the day, which I do not think is so far away, when at least half of the senators of Australia will be women.

I go out of here to find a job. I suspect that I will be back in the position I was 10 years ago, doing the ironing and furiously interjecting on some incompetent senator who is not taking up a matter properly. I can see myself again making magnificent political speeches to the kitchen sink as I listen to what senators are saying. I will remember the people I have met here with a great deal of warmth and pleasure. I will remember my comrades on this side of the House who are, I must say, as close to me as my family is in many respects because of the support, warmth and comradeship that has flowed. But I must say that I have discovered that some honourable senators opposite, who I always imagined had two heads or horns and a tail, underneath are warm, caring human beings. They are a little misguided and take the wrong path at times. Nonetheless, I treasure the friendships that I have made in this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal Sen L.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, Senator Durack, Senator Grimes, Senator Scott, thank you for your kind and generous remarks this afternoon. Mine has been a lightning-like term in the Senate, and I go back to shred textbooks and to rethink a lot of the thoughts that I had before I joined this illustrious institution. Collectively, those who depart today have served almost 170 years. What an immense achievement this is. However, during my time here I have gained an immense experience, a tremendous appreciation of differing human values and experiences, ideals that I will look to in the years ahead. My stay has indeed been short, but while visibility in the chamber, I believe, is the high point of the parliamentary experience, I have gained great satisfaction from working in the committees. The committees have a great bipartisan nature, and I think it is in those areas that the Senate's strength in the years to come will ever increase.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, I am mindful of the time. I thank all senators, and especially you for the kindness, generosity and indulgence shown to a newcomer to this place. Whilst my stay has been short, I have gained much. I thank especially my National Country Party colleagues for their help and assistance, and the Liberal senators for their guidance as well. Today is a significant point in the history of the National Party in Victoria. My party has had an unbroken representation in this place since the early 1920s. Victoria has been represented by National Country Party senators since the 1920s when Senator David Andrew joined the Senate in 1925. Today I will be the last National Country Party senator for Victoria to address the Senate. However, let us hope that this will not be for too long and that the party in Victoria will again strive to gain representation in this place.

I express my thanks especially to the people who made this Senate work; to the parliamentary officers, the attendants, the clerical staff, the drivers, the Library people, Hansard-in fact everyone who works in and around this building. We depend so much on them. I thank the National Party of Victoria for having confidence in me as a young person to represent it and the people of Victoria in this place. It has been a daunting challenge. I hope I have managed to contribute something. I thank also, my family for their trust, guidance and confidence in me. In conclusion, I trust that my fellow senators, those retiring and those continuing, will enjoy very good health-a necessary requisite for duty in this place-and happiness. I think it is from serving the nation that true happiness can be achieved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McClelland Sen The Hon D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, at the outset I have been asked by a number of my colleagues to say that, had time allowed, they would have very much liked to place on record their affection for those who are leaving us today. Further, I should say that last night the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Button, advised us that our former colleague, former Senator Pat Kennelly, rang to wish all of his colleagues well.

SPEECH.PARA: Sir, at the dinner held by senators last Wednesday week I had the honour as the pro tem father of the Senate, soon to take that mantle from my colleague Justin O'Byrne, of saying farewell to our retiring colleagues. Might I say again, as I said then, that the Parliament is losing 12 great Australians-eleven great men, very fine men, and a lovely, charming lady. Because I am restricted to some minutes, I want to pay a tribute to my three former ministerial colleagues of the Labor Government. I do it in a completely apolitical way and merely because of their humility and modesty. I do so with no slight in any way to you, Sir, as a distinguished President, to my illustrious colleague, Senator O'Byrne, or to all of our other esteemed colleagues who are retiring. You have all given great service to the Parliament and in so doing have brought great credit to yourselves in your service to your party, to the Parliament and to Australia.

As I have said, I particularly want to place on record my knowledge of what Senator Bishop, Senator Cavanagh and Senator Wheeldon achieved, or set out to achieve, in the short time that they were Ministers of the Crown in the Labor Government. Reg Bishop, Jim Cavanagh and I entered the Parliament together in 1962. We became Ministers in 1972. The three of us have always been very good mates. Amongst other portfolios that Senator Bishop held, he was the Postmaster-General in the Labor Government. Naturally, I, as the Minister for the Media at that time, worked very closely with him. Senator Bishop was responsible for the establishment of Australia Post and Telecom Australia, two very successful and highly profitable public enterprises. Reg Bishop worked with me in the establishment of ethnic broadcasting and public broadcasting in Australia. Between us, we achieved the introduction of frequency modulation broadcasting in Australia. He was able to persuade his Cabinet colleagues at the time to abolish television viewers' and radio listeners' licence fees.

Jim Cavanagh, like Reg Bishop, is the old trade unionist. He was a most compassionate, warm, human and understanding Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. He had a most sympathetic understanding of underprivilege and deprivation. He worked night and day at that portfolio. As Minister for Police and Customs, he proposed the amalgamation of all Commonwealth police forces. The fact that that has since come about is to Senator Cavanagh's great credit. If I might say so, the late Senator Dame Ivy Wedgwood once described Jim Cavanagh to me as the closest being she has ever seen to Ben Chifley. That is the greatest compliment that can be paid to any Labor man.

But for Senator Mulvihill and Senator Gietzelt, I have known Senator John Wheeldon longer than I have known anyone else in this chamber. He and I became friends in the mid-1950s when we were both young men in the Labor movement. In the 18 months that he was Minister for Repatriation and Compensation he was a very successful Minister. His proposal for a national compensation scheme was one of the most visionary proposals of the Labor Government. On repatriation matters, he fought keenly for the rights of Australian ex-servicemen, becoming affectionately known by his Cabinet and ministerial colleagues as 'the little digger'.

All of the senators who are retiring have made great contributions to Australia's political life. All of them have served their country with honour, credit and distinction. The whole nation, particularly those who remain in this Senate, will miss them very much indeed. On behalf of everyone, I wish them good health and a long, enjoyable and satisfying retirement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young Sen H.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Might I say at the outset that because of the time limit many of my colleagues who will be unable to speak have asked me if I would speak on their behalf. Also because of the limitations of time it will not be possible to deal with the 12 retiring senators as we would like to do on this occasion. Amongst those 12 honourable senators we have some most distinguished people who have given great service to this Senate chamber and the Parliament and we have the longest serving senator, and also the baby of the Senate, if I might say so when I refer to Senator Puplick. I appreciate very much that many of our colleagues have to catch the aircraft shortly but I do wish to say to those who are retiring: 'Thank you very much for your friendship. Thank you for your contributions. We all trust that you will have a happy and rewarding retirement'. In particular I say to those who are leaving this place not because of choice: 'We wish you many happy returns'.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate stands adjourned until Tuesday, 18 August 1981, at 3 p.m., unless otherwise called together in accordance with the resolution agreed to this day.
