ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Commonwealth Committee on Occupational Safety and Health

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 13 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) As a result of the Review of Commonwealth Functions, is the Commonwealth Committee on Occupational Safety and Health in Australian Government Employment to be abolished.
(2) What were the functions of that institution.
(3) Was it performing its functions inadequately in any way and, if so, in what ways was it inadequate.
(4) What action is proposed to take over the functions originally performed by the Commonwealth Committee on Occupational Safety and Health in Australian Government Employment.
(5) As a result of the action, what Government services can be expected to be affected, and in what way will they be affected.

(6) As a result of the action will any information which was available in the past not be available; if so, what is the nature of that information, and in what ways has it proved useful when it was available.

(7) As a result of the Review will any informed advice or co-ordinating capacity which was available in the past not be available; if so, what is the nature of that informed advice or co-ordinating capacity, and in what ways has it proved useful when it was available.
(8) What is the estimated saving in abolishing the Commonweath Committee on Occupational Safety and Health in Australian Government Employment.

(9) What is the estimated short and long term cost of not having the services of the Commonwealth Committee on Occupational Safety and Health in Australian Government Employment available to the Government and the community.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science and Technology has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) The Committee, with representatives from Commonwealth Departments, State Labour Departments and appropriate employee organisations, was appointed to administer the Code of General Principles for Occupational Safety and Health in Australian Government employment. The Department of Science and Technology provided the secretariat and chaired the Committee's working parties.

(3) No. Thirty-seven Codes of Practice have been approved by the Committee since its inception as recommendations to be applied by Head Officers of all Departments and Instrumentalities. Thirteen others await ministerial approval and others are in draft.

(4) The Physical Working Environment Branch of my Department is to be transferred to the Department of Industrial Relations. The Minister for Industrial Relations will be considering alternative ways of handling the work of the Committee on Occupational Safety and Health.

(5) None. The Code of General Principles has not been repealed and Head Officers of Departments and Instrumentalities continue to have responsibility for implementing the Code and its attendant Codes of Practice.

(7) To what extent the advice and co-ordinating function provided by members of the Committee will be available, in the sense that the Committee provided opportunity for debate, will depend upon the result of the consideration to be given by the Minister for Industrial Relations. This advice, contributed by participating Departments, the Public Service Board and the peak union councils, comprised both technical information and relevant experience of the Committee members. It was useful in framing the Codes of Practice (see answer to question (4)).
(8) The amount of saving, if any, will depend upon the result of the consideration to be given by the Minister for Industrial Relations (see answer to question(4)).

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: National Consultative Committee on Occupational Safety and Health

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 13 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) As a result of the Review of Commonwealth Functions, is the National Consultative Committee on Occupational Safety and Health to be abolished.
(2) What were the functions of that institution.
(3) Was it performing its functions inadequately in any way and, if so, in what ways was it inadequate.
(4) What action is proposed to take over the functions originally performed by the National Consultative Committee on Occupational Safety and Health.
(5) As a result of the action, what Government services can be expected to be affected, and in what way will they be affected.

(6) As a result of the action will any information which was available in the past not be available; if so, what is the nature of that information, and in what ways has it proved useful when it was available.

(7) As a result of the Review will any informed advice or co-ordinating capacity which was available in the past not be available; if so, what is the nature of that informed advice or co-ordinating capacity, and in what ways has it proved useful when it was available.
(8) What is the estimated saving in abolishing the National Consultative Committee on Occupational Safety and Health.
(9) What is the estimated short and long term cost of not having the services of the National Consultative Committee on Occupational Safety and Health available to the Government and the Community.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science and Technology has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes, but as the Committee was established on the initiative of the States, the Minister for Industrial Relations will be considering with them how or whether the Committee's functions should be handled.
To enable more consultation on principles, practices and standards to take place at national level;
to promote research on occupational safety and health matters;
to deal with other matters referred from time to time by the Conferences of State and Commonwealth Health and Labour Ministers.
(5) No Government services are expected to be affected.

(6) As stated above, the Committee had not met. No information has been generated, therefore, that does not already exist in sources such as the State Labour and Health Departments, and the Commonwealth Departments of Science and Technology, Health and Industrial Relations.
(7) Occupational safety and health will continue to be of concern to the regular meeting of Commonwealth and State Ministers (and their senior officers) with responsibilities in the subject area.
(8) The Commonwealth was to provide the secretariat (1 class 10 position) for the Committee plus some limited travel and accommodation. Little cost had been incurred as the Committee had not met.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 13 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) As a result of the Review of Commonwealth Functions, is the Australian Inventions Advisory Committee to be abolished.
(2) What were the functions of that institution.
(3) Was it performing its functions inadequately in any way and, if so, in what way was it inadequate.
(4) What action is proposed to take over the functions originally performed by the Australian Inventions Advisory Committee.
(5) As a result of the action, what Government services can be expected to be affected, and in what way will they be affected.

(6) As a result of the action will any information which was available in the past not be available; if so, what is the nature of that information, and in what ways has it proved useful when it was available.

(7) As a result of the Review will any informed advice or co-ordinating capacity which was available in the past not be available; if so, what is the nature of that informed advice or co-ordinating capacity, and in what ways has it proved useful when it was available.
(8) What is the estimated saving in abolishing the Australian Inventions Advisory Committee.
(9) What is the estimated short and long term cost of not having the services of the Australian Inventions Advisory Committee available to the Government and the community.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science and Technology has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) The Australian Inventions Advisory Committee considered applications to the Assistance to Inventors Scheme and, as appropriate, provided evaluations of inventions and recommended to the Minister for Science and Technology that grants be awarded to assist the development of worthy inventions.
(3) The performance of the Advisory Committee was entirely satisfactory.
(4) The Advisory Committee functions are being performed by the Department of Science and Technology.
(5) No Government services will be affected.
(6) All the information which was available in the past will still be available.

(7) Advice to the Minister and to inventors will no longer be available as consensus of opinion of a group of expert individuals. Rather a range of different views will be available which the Department of Science and Technology will have to assess and evaluate.
(8) There will be a saving in departmental expenses of approximately $1,700 a year.
(9) There is no identifiable cost, either to the Government or to the community, arising from the abolition of the Advisory Committee.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 13 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) As a result of the Review of Commonwealth Functions, is the National Employee Participation Steering Committee to be abolished.
(2) What were the functions of that institution.
(3) Was it performing its functions inadequately in any ways and, if so, in what ways was it inadequate.
(4) What action is proposed to take over the functions originally performed by the National Employee Participation Steering Committee.
(5) As a result of the action, what Government services can be expected to be affected, and in what way will they be affected.

(6) As a result of the action, will any information which was available in the past be not available; if so, what is the nature of the information and in what ways has it proved useful when it was available.

(7) As a result of the Review, will any informed advice or co-ordinating capacity which was available in the past be not available? If so, what is the nature of that informed advice or co-ordinating capacity, and in what ways has it proved useful when it was available.
(8) What is the estimated saving in abolishing the National Employee Participation Steering Committee.
(9) What is the estimated short and long term cost of not having NEPSC available to the Government and the community.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science and Technology has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) NEPSC was established in 1978 in accordance with the Commonwealth Government's policy on employee participation. Its functions were to:

develop and recommend policies appropriate to Government, employers and trade unions, designed to develop a greater understanding of concepts of employee participation and to encourage their implementation;
identify and develop measures for stimulating action in both the public and private sectors;
identify and develop guidelines for appropriate training, research and dissemination of specific ideas, information and programs.

More specifically, the Committee has worked on identifying major barriers to employee participation; publishing information appropriate to organisations interested in developing participative practices; developing means for bringing together key individuals and organisations; and advising the Government on a range of programs.

(3) The Committee has performed its functions in a most satisfactory way. Its work has demonstrated the advantages to be gained from a tripartite consensus approach and its impact has been significant.

Of particular note has been its production of 2 booklets-'Employee Participation: A Broad View' and 'Employee Participation: Ways and Means' as significant joint statements by Government, employers and trade unions in an area where there has previously been little consensus.

(4) The abolition of the Committee is part of a move to rationalise the Government's activities in this field. Accordingly, the activities of the Human Relations Branch, which has prime responsibility for this subject area, are to be reduced and transferred from the Department of Science and Technology to the Department of Industrial Relations. Consideration is being given to having the work of NEPSC handled by a sub-committee of the National Labour Consultative Council.

(5) As part of the rationalisation program already referred to, a review is to be undertaken by the Public Service Board of the functions of the Human Relations Branch and this will include the work it has carried out in conjunction with NEPSC.
(6) This will depend on results of the review (see 5 above) and subsequent decisions to be made by the Minister for Industrial Relations in association with NLCC.

(7) The Human Relations Branch currently responds to a large number of requests from the industrial and commercial community for advice and assistance and acts in concert with the States, as a national clearing house for information in the subject area. While there will be a reduction in these activities, the extent to which they will continue will depend on the decisions taken in respect to the reduced functional areas (see response to question (5) above).

(8) The disbanding of NEPSC and its possible re-establishment within the NLCC framework will make for an effective and comprehensive approach to the general issue of employer/employee relations. It is difficult to quantify in any precise way the effect of such an arrangement.

(9) Because of its tripartite, consensus approach, NEPSC has made a significant contribution to the development of employee participation in this country. The quality of Government programs and services to the community would suffer without this approach. Accordingly, and as stated above, the intention is to continue to develop this tripartite, consensus approach under the auspices of NLCC.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce, upon notice, on 13 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Australian Government Clothing Factory to be sold to the private sector.
(2) What money is expected to be raised by this decision.
(3) Will the government receive any advice as to when to sell the Australian Government Clothing Factory so as to achieve the best price.

(4) Will sale of the Australian Government Clothing Factory be delayed if it appears that the Commonwealth is not in a position to receive the best price, as is consistent with sound business practice.
(5) What investigations have been made concerning the prices which consumers will pay for the services of the Australian Government Clothing Factory as a result of its sale.
(6) Can the Minister assure the Parliament that prices will not rise, with consequent adverse affects on inflation as a result of the sale of the Australian Government Clothing Factory.
(7) What assurances can the Minister give that services to the public will not deteriorate as a result of the sale.
(8) Will the proposed sale increase the efficiency of the Australian Government Clothing Factory.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) At this stage the Government has decided only to offer the Australian Government Clothing Factory for lease or sale as a going concern. The decision was taken in implementation of the Government's policies of restraining public sector outlays, of placing greater reliance on private industry for the production of stores for the Armed Services, and of not being involved in activities which are capable of being performed adequately by the private sector. Formal registrations of interest are currently being invited for the lease or purchase of the Factory as a going concern. A final decision will not be taken until offers have been evaluated.

(2) The Government will be seeking a fair return for the Factory which should reflect not only its assets, but also its performance and capabilities. An independent valuation of the Factory as a going concern is to be obtained and offers received will be examined against that valuation.
(3) and (4) The Government's decision on whether to lease of sell the Factory, and when any such arrangement should commence, will depend on the offers received and careful evaluation of the details.

(5) and (6) The Factory currently supplies about 50 percent of the Armed Services' needs for clothing items, the rest being supplied by private industry. There is therefore a good knowledge of existing industry prices. Any new arrangement would require the Factory to continue to be competitive in terms of prices, quality and delivery.

(7) The main function of the Australian Government Clothing Factory has been to provide a wide range of clothing and accoutrements for defence and other Government customers; this function is already shared with industry. I would not envisage any deterioration in the Factory's services.

(8) With the modern facilities already in operation at the Factory, private enterprise should be in an excellent position to introduce private sector expertise and further improve output and efficiency.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce, upon notice, on 13 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Ordnance Factory, Bendigo to be sold to the private sector.
(2) What money is expected to be raised by this decision.
(3) Will the government receive any advice as to when to sell the Ordnance Factory, Bendigo so as to achieve the best price.
(4) Will sale of the Ordnance Factory, Bendigo be delayed if it appears that the Commonwealth is not in a position to receive the best price, as is consistent with sound business practice.
(5) What investigations have been made concerning the prices which consumers will pay for the services of the Ordnance Factory, Bendigo as a result of its sale.
(6) Can the Minister assure the Parliament that prices will not rise, with consequent adverse effects on inflation as a result of the sale of the Ordnance Factory, Bendigo.
(7) What assurances can the Minister give that services to the public will not deteriorate as a result of the sale.
(8) Will the proposed sale increase the efficiency of the Ordnance Factory, Bendigo.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) At this stage the Government has only decided to offer the Ordnance Factory Bendigo for sale as a going concern. The decision was taken in implementation of the Government's policies of restraining public sector outlays, of placing greater reliance on private industry for the production of stores for the Armed Services, and of not being involved in activities which are capable of being performed adequately by the private sector. Formal registrations of interest in the purchase of the Factory as a going concern are currently being invited from prospective buyers. A final decision on the future of the Factory will not be taken until offers have been evaluated.

(2) The Government will be seeking a fair return for the Factory which should reflect not only its assets, but also its performance and capabilities. An independent valuation of the Factory as a going concern is to be obtained and offers received will be examined against that valuation.
(3) and (4) The Government's decision on whether to sell the Factory, and if so when, will depend on the offers received and careful evaluation of the details.

(5) and (6) Operations of the Factory are currently subsidised with Government funds. A private owner of the Factory would be able to engage in an extended range of work for the private sector. I am confident that with an expanded workload the Factory will be competitive.

(7) The Ordnance Factory Bendigo has for many years provided support to private industry and overseas customers in heavy engineering and fabrication work. The Factory has developed special skills and has proved that it is capable of meeting stringent requirements in precision engineering at competitive prices. I therefore have every confidence that the Factory will continue to provide important services to customers requiring heavy engineering products. Moreover, with the current and potential large-scale mineral development projects, there will be opportunities for a private sector owner to use the Bendigo facilities to greatly expand activity in support of such projects. The factory will also have continuing opportunities to engage in defence work.

(8) It is expected that a private sector owner should be in an excellent position to make more efficient use of the Factory's currently under-utilized facilities so increasing the efficiency of the factory.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 13 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Does the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs monitor the level of Australian ownership and/or control of companies manufacturing groceries, toiletries and small household items in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 14 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Fleming Report been suppressed rather than placed on the files of Vietnam veterans making claims in relation to herbicides; if so, (a) why has the report been suppressed; and (b) why has the Repatriation Commission not acted 'according to substantial justice', as required by the Repatriation Act, by making determinations when not all relevant evidence is on file.
(2) How can the Commission be satisfied 'beyond reasonable doubt', that there are 'unsufficient grounds for granting the claim' when it is known that not all relevant evidence is on file.
(3) Has the Repatriation Commission contravened Sections 24AB (1) and 47 (2) of the Act in its treatment of the herbicide-related claims of Vietnam veterans.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The so called 'Fleming Report' is a compilation of extracts from scientific and other articles which were obtained from Mr John Evans of Melbourne, an adviser to the Vietnam Veterans Association, and which, in his opinion, supported the Association's claims. Subsequent independent evaluation of the compilation indicated that the compilation did not present an adequate up to date and comprehensive coverage of the Scientific literature on the subject. However, copies of the full texts of the reports and articles quoted by Mr John Evans together with a number of other scientific reports have been distributed to Departmental Medical Officers dealing with claims of health effects from contact with toxic chemicals in Vietnam.

(2) The facts are that the Department has been gathering information on the long-term effects of herbicides on human health since well before December 1979 when the herbicides controversy arose in Australia and has been circulating this information thoughout the Repatriation system. My Department seeks to ensure that all relevant scientific evidence is taken into account by Departmental Medical Officers when giving opinions under the terms of section 48 of the Repatriation Act, by providing them with copies of published articles dealing with the possible toxic effects of herbicides and other toxic chemicals. Repatriation Boards and delegates of the Commission are well aware and have been reminded that all of this material is available to them whenever they think it could be relevant to a particular claim.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 27 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister received a submission for funding independent counselling services prepared by the Vietnam Veterans' Association.

(2) Has the Minister made any decision on the proposal put to him by the West Australian Vietnam Veterans in February 1981; if not, what is the reason for the delay and when can a decision be expected.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) A proposal has been received from a Mr F. Donovan who, I understand, represents an organisation recently set up in Western Australia and called the 'Vietnam Veterans' Family Association'. The proposal, along with the Vietnam Veterans' Association request, is being considered in the general context of the provision of a counselling service for Vietnam veterans. A decision will not be made until I have examined, on-the-spot, the arrangements made for counselling services in the United States. In the meantime an interim service has been established, manned by professionally qualified counselling officers located at central points in the Department of Veterans' Affairs.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 5 June 1981 (Hansard, page 886) Senator Douglas McClelland asked me without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is it a fact that, because of the shortage of available repatriation boards in New South Wales, a number of the applications for war widows' pensions that have been lodged in my State have had to be sent to Western Australia for determination? Has this process been holding up consideration of applications for war widows' pensions in New South Wales? Why is it that boards are not available to handle the work in New South Wales? Will the Minister take early action to see that the position is rectified?
The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:
There are delays in the determination of claims by Repatriation Boards in Sydney but these have arisen because of processing problems.

There are normally four Repatriation Boards operating in New South Wales but a fifth Board has been operating for some time to assist with the backlog of cases. The fifth Board is normally programmed to assist in relief work on other Boards but is being used full time at present to assist with the New South Wales workload. In addition, the Governor-General has recently approved the establishment of three additional Boards throughout Australia for a short term to provide additional resources. Most of these will be applied in New South Wales.

The transmission of cases interstate is a normal procedure and is done not only to assist Boards in the larger States but to supplement the work of the Boards in States such as Western Australia, where the local work level is not sufficient to sustain a full time Board. The transmission of these cases interstate will continue, therefore, even after the present problem is resolved in New South Wales.

I am concerned about delays being encountered in the Repatriation determining system and I have discussed the problem with the Repatriation Commission. The Commission is taking action to improve the workflow, particularly in New South Wales, and will continue to monitor the situation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 11 June 1981 (Hansard, page 3020), Senator Evans asked me a series of questions without notice concerning aspects of the activities of Asia Dairy Industries (H.K.) Ltd. and other matters:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Is it the case that more than six months have now elapsed since the Australian Federal Police completed its report on aspects of the activities of Asia Dairy Industries (H.K.) Ltd., the Australian Dairy Corporation and its Chairman, Mr Webster, and forwarded that report to the Minister for Primary Industry?
(2) Is it the case that that report was subsequently forwarded to the Attorney-General's Department for comment as to the possibility of a prosecution being launched?
(3) When did the Attorney-General's Department complete its consideration of that report?

(4) Is there any justification of which the Attorney-General is aware for further police investigations of the kind to which (Mr Nixon) referred yesterday in the House of Representatives to justify his failure to make a promised statement on this matter?
(5) Finally, will there ever be an 'appropriate time', to use (Mr Nixon's) own words, for the making of a statement and the tabling of documents in this matter?
The answers to the honourable senator's questions are:

(1) No. I understand that the Australian Federal Police reported to the Department of Primary Industry the virtual completion of its investigations on the matters to which Senator Evans has referred on 11 March 1981.

(2) Yes, on 13 March 1981. On 27 April 1981 my Department asked the Australian Federal Police to undertake certain further enquiries in relation to these matters and to provide certain additional material. The additional material requested by my Department was provided on or about 8 May 1981.

(4) I understand that in the last few days the Australian Federal Police advised the Department of Primary Industry that, contrary to Department's earlier belief, there remain aspects of one matter to be investigated. This matter is in the hands of the Police and it is, therefore, a matter for them to determine whether there is any justification for the further investigation they propose to undertake. I think it is proper that a statement on this matter should be deferred until the investigation is complete.

(5) The Minister for Primary Industry has announced that when all investigations have been completed he will make a detailed statement and table relevant papers. I understand that that remains the Minister's intention.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Subsidised Interest Rates on Housing Loans

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 5 December 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many employees, including employees of the Government in organisations such as the Reserve Bank, receive assistance with their housing through subsidised interest rates on housing loans.
(2) Is the interest rate paid by such employees sometimes as low as 3 per cent.
(3) What would the annual value be to the employee of a $100 000 housing loan on which he only paid 3 per cent interest.
(4) Is tax charged on the basis of such benefits.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Some employees of financial and other institutions would receive such assistance but the number is not known.

As far as I am aware no civilian employees directly employed by the Commonwealth Government receive such assistance by virtue of their employee status. However, serving Defence forces personnel are eligible, subject to certain qualifying requirements, to borrow for housing purposes under the Defence Service Homes Scheme at the standard rates of interest applicable to such loans.

I am advised that employees of three Commonwealth authorities within my portfolio-the Reserve Bank of Australia, Commonwealth Banking Corporation and the Australian Industry Development Corporation-are eligible, subject to certain qualifying requirements, for housing loans at concessional interest rates that are in line with rates charged to bank employees generally for such loans. Officers of these authorities are employed by the respective bodies and are not employees of the Government.
(2) No, in the case of the Defence Service Homes Scheme and the three authorities referred to in (1) above. Otherwise, I have no information on this matter.
(3) For income tax purposes the value to an employee of a benefit of the kind described would be a matter for determination in each case in the light of all the relevant facts.
(4) Where there is a benefit to an employee, section 26 (e) of the Income Tax Assessment Act would require the employee to include the value of such benefit in his or her assessable income.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 5 December 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Which of the following documents, which were included in 'An Inside Dopester's Index of One Hundred Examples of Secrecy', an appendix to the book Secrecy: Political Censorship in Australia by Jim Spigelman (Angus and Robertson, Sydney, 1972), have now been published: (a) No. 16-Departmental internal manual; (b) No. 32-Departmental surveys of pensioners (1965); (c) No. 33-Departmental survey of accommodation of aged pensioners; (d) No. 34-Departmental studies of economic benefits of rehabilitation programmes; (e) No. 35-Interdepartmental Committee survey of facilities for handicapped children; and (f) No. 36-Independent consultants' report on mentally and physically handicapped.
(2) Which of the above-mentioned documents have now otherwise been made available.
(3) Which of the documents so far not made available would the Government now be prepared to make available either unconditionally or on any, and if so what, conditions.
(4) Which of the documents so far not made available does the Government continue to refuse to make available, and why.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) (1)-(4) The departmental Manuals of Instructions relating to the conditions of eligibility for pensions, benefits and allowances include information concerning the conditions for eligibility as well as information of an operational kind and procedures which, if published, could facilitate fraud. For these latter reasons the manuals have not been made available to the public. However, the Department is aware of the need for the public to have access to information concerning conditions of eligibility for pensions, benefits and allowances and is working towards the production of a manual which would meet the requirements for publication under the Government's proposed Freedom of Information legislation.

(b) (1) The 'surveys' presumably refer to the document entitled 'Statistical Survey of the Characteristics of Age, Invalid and Widow Pensioners in New South Wales, February 1965' and, possibly, the Supplementary Statistical Tables, prepared by the then Department of Social Services. The report from this survey was not published.

(2) Copies of the report from the survey were provided to several Government Departments in 1965 and 1966. In 1969, copies were provided to some other organisations and individuals including the Parliamentary Library and the present Leader of the Opposition.
(3) The document is available on request without conditions.

(c) (1)-(4) There was no formal survey report. On 1 March 1973 certain statistical tables in respect of pensioners in Victoria receiving supplementary assistance at December 1970 became available on request.

(d) (1)-(4) My Department has no knowledge of a departmental study called ''economic benefits of rehabilitation programmes''; however, in 1972 a longitudinal cost benefit study of rehabilitation services was undertaken. The findings of this study were published in Rehabilitation Digest No. 4 of 1975.

(e) (1)-(4) Despite a considerable research effort by my Department, this Report has not been able to be identified. Footnotes to Mr Spigelman's book do not assist in identification. I am unwilling to instruct my Department to continue the search further.

(f) (1)-(4) A copy of this report, 'Rehabilitation Services in Australia, Report on 1969 Review by Joseph Griffith', February 1970, is held in the Department of Social Security library. A copy is available on request.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 24 February 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When will the Prime Minister's 1980 election promise of full tax deductibility for home insulation costs for a person's first home become operative.
(2) What guidelines will apply, and what are the specifications for eligible insulating materials and eligible buildings.

(3) Has the Government sought or received representations on this matter from any manufacturer of thermal home insulation either before or after 1 October 1980 and in particular, have representations or approaches or advice of any kind been received from Sir Andrew Grimwade, Chairman of Australian Consolidated Industries; if so, (a) on what date or dates were such approaches made; and (b) what was the nature of all such approaches.

(4) Has professional advice been sought from and or supplied by: (a) the Department of National Development and Energy; (b) the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation; or (c) private professional consultants, as to whether thermal domestic insulation necessarily leads to energy savings; if so, did any expert advice received indicate that domestic thermal insulation may result in additional energy usage by causing larger areas of the home to be continuously heated.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Provisions to implement this initiative are contained in the Income Tax Laws Amendment Bill 1981.

(2) The concession applies to the cost of insulating dwellings purchased under contracts entered into on or after 1 October 1980, or the construction of which by the taxpayer commenced on or after that date.

A condition of eligibility is that the dwelling is or is to be the sole or principal residence of the taxpayer in Australia, and neither the taxpayer nor, in the case of a married couple, his or her spouse previously owned and used as a residence another dwelling in Australia.

The concession extends to the cost of thermal insulation materials and their installation. Materials or substances that have, in whole or in part, a structural function or a decorative function and any materials of substances that are used in connection with such a material or substance are outside the definition of thermal insulation materials for this purpose.
(3) I am advised that the following representations have been received:
Firstly, a representation from the Victorian Chamber of Commerce to the Minister for Housing and Construction on 17 September 1980.
Secondly, a representation from Australian Consolidated Industries Ltd to the Department of Housing and Construction on 18 September 1980.
Thirdly, on 12 December 1980 officers of the Department of Housing and Construction had discussions with representatives of the Fibreglass Insulation Manufacturers of Australia.
The nature of these representations were as follows:

Firstly, the Victorian Chamber of Commerce discussed with the Minister for Housing and Construction the question of incentives for the insulation of private dwellings raised in a paper by Australian Consolidated Industries. This paper suggested the Commonwealth Government implement a national incentive scheme for the insulation of private dwellings.
Secondly, representatives from Australian Consolidated Industries Ltd also discussed this paper with officers of the Department of Housing and Construction.

Thirdly, representatives of the Fibreglass Insulation Manufacturers of Australia discussed with officers of the Department of Housing and Construction and the Department of National Development and Energy, technicalities and issues surrounding the Government's election commitment to provide full tax deductibility for home insulation costs for a person's first home.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: National Committee on Discrimination in Employment and Occupation

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 25 February 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is meant by the word ''resolved'' as it relates to complaints investigated by the National Committee on Discrimination in Employment and Occupation.
(2) Were only 13 per cent of all complaints received by the National Committee categorised as resolved during the year 1978-79.
(3) What reasons underlie the failure of the National Committee to resolve complaints when compared with the number resolved by the respective State Committees.
(4) What explanation can be given for the alarming number of complaints withdrawn, closed or referred elsewhere by the National Committee.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) ''Resolved'' is the term used by the Committees on Discrimination in Employment and Occupation in recording those complaints where discrimination was found by the Committee to occur, and the Committee has been able through conciliation to achieve a change in practice by the party complained against.

(3) The National Committee receives those complaints which the States/NT Committee can not resolve as well as those complaints which have national implications. These complaints usually require extensive investigation and representation. Remedial action by the responsible organisation can involve legislative changes and the complaint is not regarded as resolved until these changes have been made.
(4) It is not considered that the number of complaints withdrawn, closed or referred elsewhere represents an alarming situation.

ANSWER.PARA: In the previous Parliament the honourable senator asked a similar question (No. 3086 of 20 August 1980), to which my predecessor, the Hon. R. I. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 3 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the estimated total cost of fares, accommodation, security and administrative expenses for the proposed visit of Prince Charles to Australia in April 1981.
(2) How many persons will accompany Prince Charles for all or part of the visit and what are their names and positions.
(3) How much of the cost will be met by:
(a) The Commonwealth Government;
(b) The British Government;
(c) State Governments;
(d) Other organisations and
(e) Prince Charles.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government has adopted a practice, out of courtesy to the visitors, of not publishing the individual costs of visits by guests of the Government. The funds are appropriated by Parliament and expenditure brought to account in the previous year is recorded in the annual Appropriation Acts.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 4 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What action has been taken to plan the development of public television in Australia.
(2) In which spectrum band, UHF or VHF, will public television be located.
(3) What financial assistance will be made available to public television licences.
(4) When, and for what areas, will licence applications be called.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Planning guidelines for the introduction of public television, which will provide a framework for the development of planning proposals for public television services are currently being considered by Government and will be announced shortly. These quidelines have been developed by the Department of Communications in consultation with relevant government departments and authorities, the Public Broadcasting Association of Australia and potential public television groups.

(2) Public television programs may be provided by public television corporations broadcasting on an existing station (Australian Broadcasting Commission (ABC), Special Broadcasting Service (SBS), or commercial) which will usually be in the VHF band. In general, VHF channels will not be available to public television licensees, but UHF channels will be provided.
(3) The Government is currently examining the question of government funding for public television.

(4) When any new radio or television service is to be introduced, the Government follows a set of procedures designed to ensure a logical approach to planning and an effective use of the radio frequency spectrum. This procedure is as follows:

(a) the Government announces Planning Guidelines for the new service; these usually set out the policy framework within which development is to take place and indicate special factors regarding timing, location, frequency planning and so on;
(b) a draft planning proposal is prepared by the person or organisation interested in acquiring a licence or, in some circumstances, by my Department;
(c) the draft planning proposal is circulated within the broadcasting industry for comment;
(d) as Minister, I consider the comments received and, where appropriate, the Department's responses to the comments and may then decide to invite applications for a licence;

(e) the applications are examined at a public inquiry by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal which may then grant a licence that has those specifications which are my responsibility as Minister to determine attached as licence conditions.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: National Committee on Discrimination in Employment and Occupation

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 5 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are delays of between six to nine months normally experienced by complainants whose cases are being investigated by the National Committee on Discrimination in Employment and Occupation.
(2) What reasons underlie the slow rate of investigation by the National Committee.
(3) What action will be taken by the Government to remedy this situation so as to ensure that complainants have their cases dealt with more promptly.

(4) What consideration has the Government given to absorbing the National Committee into the proposed Human Rights Commission as a means of ensuring that complaints are dealt with more quickly and effectively.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The National Committee on Discrimination in Employment and Occupation investigates all complaints involving a national policy or practice in the Government or private sectors, as well as those unresolved complaints referred to it by the State Committees. Most complaints referred to the National Committee are resolved quickly. Some complaints, however, are of a complex nature and require lengthy negotiations. These complaints often lead to the consideration of policy issues because of their implications on a national scale and raise questions concerning legislation. The resolution of such complaints takes a considerable time.

(3) The National Committee is now meeting more regularly than previously. In addition, additional staffing resources have been provided to the National Committee Secretariat since the start of the current financial year.

(4) The Government has decided that the National and State Committees on Discrimination in Employment and Occupation are to remain the vehicles for the handling of employment discrimination complaints.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 31 March 1981:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 20 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) On what basis is import duty levied on (a) Scottish kilts; and (b) the tartan material from which kilts are made.
(2) Are kilts or the tartan material from which they are made subject to any quantitive import restrictions; if so, what are the details.
(3) What Australian industry is considered to be protected by these measures.
(4) Is there an Australian tartan kilt industry; if not is this evidence that the protection policy is not working.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The specific basis for duties on kilts and authentic clan tartan fabrics is specified in the Australian Custom Tariff, and is as follows:

(a) Scottish kilts are subject to a tariff quota which limits the volume of goods imported at quota rates of duty before additional duty is payable. Tariff quotas were introduced for these goods following Government consideration of the Industries Assistance Commission report of 29 January 1975 titled 'Textiles Authority-Apparel-Section 2'. Accordingly, for certain outer garments including kilts, a ceiling level of 5,558,400 garments may be imported between 1 March 1981 and 31 December 1981 by quota holders at the duty rate of 51.5 per cent. Any goods imported other than by quota holders, or in excess of the ceiling level are dutiable at the rate of 39 per cent and $12 per kilogram.

(b) Woollen fabrics, including authentic clan tartan fabrics, are also subject to a tariff quota which limits the volume of goods imported at quota rates of duty before additional duty is payable, Tariff quotas were introduced for these fabrics following Government consideration of the Industries Assistance Commission report of 19 July 1977 on 'Certain Spun Yarns and Wool Textiles and Other Goods'. For woollen fabrics and wool fabrics containing silk or polyester, a ceiling level of 2,000,000 square metres may be imported between 1 March 1981 and 31 December 1981 at the duty rate of 34 per cent, or, if higher $0.50 per square metre if having a weight exceeding 153 grams per square metre, or 34 per cent for fabric up to and including 153 grams per square metre. For any of these fabrics imported other than by quota holders or in excess of the ceiling level the respective duty rates are 34 per cent plus $2.50 per square metre or, if higher, $3 per square metre for fabrics exceeding 153 grams per square metre or 34 per cent plus $2.50 per square metre for fabrics up to and including 153 grams per square metre.

On 15 August 1980 the Government announced new assistance arrangements for the textiles clothing and footwear industries following the Industries Assistance Commission's reports of April 1980 on those industries. From 1 January 1982 clothing subject to quota, including kilts, will be dutiable at 50 per cent within quota and new quota arrangements will apply so that a proportion of the quota will be sold by the Government at a premium. Clothing imported outside of quota will attract an additional duty of $15 per garment. Wool fabrics, including authentic clan tartan fabrics, will be dutiable at 50 per cent for two years from 1 January 1982 and 45 per cent thereafter, and be free of quota.
The duties applicable to imports are fixed by an Act of Parliament and must be levied on all imports unless some legal basis exists which permits an exemption or reduction.

(2) Yes: tariff quotas which limit imports at quota rates of duty have applied to a wide range of clothing and textiles, including kilts and woollen and worsted fabric for kilts, for some time. These quotas are allocated to importers on the basis of historical import performance during a specified base period, to enable an equitable allocation to be made within the limits determined by the Government. Imports in excess of the levels determined involve the payment of an additional penalty duty.

However, provision does exist for the relief from the payment of the penalty duty and the 12.5 per cent special additional customs duty in the case of private importations having a value for duty not exceeding $50 which are imported in the one consignment and are not to be used for any commercial purposes.
(3) Australian manufacture of garments, including kilts, and Australian manufacture of woollen and worsted woven fabrics.

(4) The Department of Business and Consumer Affairs recently enquired into the commercial production of Scottish kilts and authentic clan tartan fabrics in Australia and has established that they are available from several local manufacturers.

Both locally made and imported fabrics are used by kiltmakers. Local producers of authentic clan tartan fabrics have indicated their ability and, subject to receiving orders for reasonable quantities, their willingness to provide any recognised clan tartan fabric within a reasonable period and at a price comparable to that for which similar fabrics may be imported.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cavanagh Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 7 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) By what amount have numbers of employees in the Commonwealth Public Service been reduced since 1975.

(2) Is it planned to further reduce the number of federal public servants, if so, from which departments are further reductions anticipated, and by how much are the staff numbers of each department likely to be reduced.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Between June 1975 and June 1980 the numbers of fulltime Commonwealth staff subject to staff ceilings were reduced by some 10,200. This includes 4370 employed under the Public Service Act.

(2) Further staff savings will be made as a result of decisions arising from the Ministerial Review of Commonwealth Functions. I announced these decisions on 30 April 1981. Precise details on reductions in each department are not yet available but it is envisaged that total savings of 16,000 to 17,000 Commonwealth staff will be made.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 8 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) On how many occasions have Associated General Contractors Insurance Co Ltd, Palmdale-AGCI Ltd and Palmdale Insurance Ltd breached the provisions of the Insurance Act 1973.
(2) What action was taken on each occasion to rectify the breaches.
(3) What penalties, if any, were imposed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Associated General Contractors Insurance Company Limited was not granted an authority under the Insurance Act 1973 and did not breach that Act. A company was authorised under the Act under the name of Palmdale-AGCI Limited which acquired the insurance business of Associated General Contractors Insurance Company Limited. This company subsequently changed its name to Palmdale Insurance Limited under which name it breached the solvency requirements of the Act. This led to the Insurance Commissioner and the Treasurer taking action as prescribed by the Act.

(2) The action taken by the Insurance Commissioner was to request Palmdale Insurance Limited pursuant to section 52 of the Act to show cause why he should not recommend to the Treasurer that an Inspector be appointed in respect of Palmdale Insurance Limited. Following replies from the company the Treasurer appointed an Inspector in respect of the company on 7 August 1979.

(3) The Act does not have penalty provisions for breaches of the solvency provisions of the Act. As Palmdale Insurance Limited complied with the directions issued by the Treasurer pursuant to section 62 of the Act and ceased writing insurance business the need did not arise to consider the penalty provisions provided by section 62.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 8 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What factors contributed to the breaches of the Insurance Act 1973 by Associated General Contractors Insurance Co Ltd, Palmdale-AGCI Ltd, and Palmdale Insurance Ltd.
(2) What reasons can be given for the three companies' eventual failure.
(3) Why did the New South Wales Government refuse to grant Palmdale-AGCI Ltd a licence to carry on workers' compensation business.
(4) Was the Commissioner of Insurance advised.
(5) What was the basis of that advice and the action taken under the provisions of the Insurance Act 1973.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) I refer the honourable senator to my answer to Question No. 630 of today's date. While the reasons are largely a matter of opinion it could be reasonable to suggest that the making of unsound investments and an unprofitable underwriting policy were factors contributing to the breach of the Act by Palmdale Insurance Limited and its eventual failure.

(3) and (4) The reason why the New South Wales Government refused to grant Palmdale-AGCI Limited a licence to carry on workers' compensation insurance business has not been conveyed to me or to the Insurance Commissioner.
(5) See (3) and (4) above and my answer to Question No. 630.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 7 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the current arrangements for reviewing the circumstances of parents receiving the handicapped children's allowance.
(2) How many such allowances have been cancelled since June 1980.

(3) How many allowances paid in respect of severely handicapped children were cancelled because of: (a) a change in the child's medical condition; (b) a change in the child's place of residence; and (c) other reasons.

(4) How many allowances paid in respect of substantially handicapped children were cancelled because of: (a) a change in the child's medical condition; (b) a change in the child's place of residence; (c) a change in the parent's financial position; and (d) other reasons.
(5) At the time of review are the parents advised of their right to appeal.
(6) What is the income test applied in respect of substantially handicapped children.
(7) What arrangements are there for publicising this.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The financial circumstances of parents are not relevant in the case of a severely handicapped child. In cases where the child is substantially handicapped, the parent's circumstances are reviewed annually.
(2) The number of terminations of handicapped child's allowance between 14 June 1980 and 14 December 1980 is estimated to be 1700.

(3) and (4) Certain statistics of handicapped child's allowance have been collected on a manual basis but they are not considered to be accurate. In particular, reliable statistics showing reason for termination are not currently available. It is expected that comprehensive statistics of grants and terminations of handicapped child's allowance will become available towards the end of 1981 following the introduction of a computer based collection.
(5) Parents are advised of their right to appeal when advised of any adverse decision on entitlements.

(6) The Social Services Act provides that a handicapped child's allowance may be granted in respect of a substantially handicapped child if the Director-General of Social Services is satisfied that the person providing care and attention for the child is, by reason of the provision of that care and attention, subjected to 'severe financial hardship'.

A person is accepted as being subjected to 'severe financial hardship' if the family's gross weekly income, after deducting expenses associated with the child's disability is less than $210 (increased by $6 for each child in the family after the first).

The amount of $210 is the sum (rounded to the nearest dollar) of the weighted average minimum weekly award wage payable to adult males for a full week's work (excluding overtime) as at 31 December 1980 ($186.65) and the maximum rate of handicapped child's allowance (616.85), plus $6. This income limit is reviewed each March and September.
The rate of handicapped child's allowance payable in respect of a substantially handicapped child is the lesser of:
the difference between the income limit applicable to the family and the family's gross income after deducting the expenses associated with the child's disability;
the expenses associated with the child's disability; and
the maximum rate of the allowance ($73 a month)

While the income limit, expenses for the child and family income are generally expressed as weekly amounts for convenience, they are converted to monthly figures for the assessment and payment of the allowance.

The criteria for assessing the rate of handicapped child's allowance in these cases have the effect of re-imbursing the family by the amount, up to the maximum rate of the allowance by which the family's income is below the income limit because of the expenses associated with the child's disability.

(7) Information on the income test in relation to substantially handicapped children is not included in present publications. Arrangements will be made to have information included in future publications.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Thomas Sen A.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 28 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: What direct and indirect advantages are granted to Qantas Airways Ltd by the Commonwealth Government or its agencies which are not available to other international airlines or air charter companies.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister of Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Commonwealth has made arrangements for loan borrowings and loan guarantees for Qantas aircraft acquisitions on such terms and conditions as the Treasurer determines and which are subject to legislation. No doubt a number of international airlines receive similar treatment from their own Governments.

The only other incidence of preferential treatment of Qantas of which the Minister for Transport is aware is in regard to Government financed overseas travel, where Department of Finance Directions 14/12 to 14/16 apply.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 28 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Is disaster likely to occur in Northern Ireland, if House of Commons Parliamentarian, Bobby Sands, dies; if so, has the Government applied any pressure to the Thatcher Government to avoid such a disaster and to save the life of Bobby Sands; and if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: I draw the honourable senator's attention to the answer given by Senator Carrick in the Senate on my behalf on 30 April 1981.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 28 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have over 30,000 Australians signed a petition supporting the demands of the House of Commons Member of Parliament, Mr Bobby Sands, for political status for political prisoners jailed in the North of Ireland.

(2) Have British troops killed three young Irish men in the past week who were supporters of the hunger striker; if so, were two run down by a British Army vehicle and one killed by a British Army plastic bullet.
(3) Is the Government aware that in addition to Bobby Sands, at least three other young men on a hunger strike for the return of political status also face death.
(4) Will the Government take a stand on a humanitarian basis to prevent the death of these young men and the unknown numbers of civilians who are inevitably going to die; if Bobby Sands dies.
(5) Does the Government acknowledge that international influence on the Thatcher Government is the only way now left to prevent these deaths in the north of Ireland.

(6) Does Britain already grant political status to many republican prisoners and if Bobby Sands had been convicted before 1 March 1976 would he be accorded political prisoner status; if so, is it only an arbitrary date which has denied the hunger strikers this same right.

(7) Will the Australian Government on behalf of all peace loving and justice seeking Australians urge the intransigent Thatcher government to take the necessary steps to prevent further needless deaths of the Irish Nationalist people.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No record of such a petition can be found.

(2) The situation in Northern Ireland is complex and tragic. The people of Northern Ireland have endured much suffering. In circumstances of continuing civil disturbance some casualties are, unfortunately, inevitable. It is not, however, appropriate for the Australian Government to comment on particular incidents which are under investigation in Northern Ireland.
(4) and (5) I refer the honourable senator to the answer I gave on this subject in the House of Representatives on 29 April.

The Australian Government earnestly hopes that the men concerned will call off their hunger strikes for their own sakes and the sake of numerous other people who may be involved in subsequent outbreaks of violence.

(6) The Government understands that, between June 1972 and March 1976, prisoners involved in para-military organisations in Northern Ireland, who had been sentenced to more than nine months imprisonment for offences relating to civil disturbances were accorded 'special category status'. No prisoners charged with an offence committed after March 1976 have been accorded 'special category status'.
(7) I refer the honourable senator to the answer I gave in the House of Representatives on 29 April 1981.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Neal Sen L.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources, upon notice, on 6 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are there any plans for expanding or contracting the Trade Commissioner Service.

(2) Does Australia have any plans to establish a new trade commission post in the next year; if so, (a) in what country and what particular region will the post be established; and (b) why was that particular region chosen to establish a trade commission.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Trade and Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In common with other areas of Commonwealth employment, the Trade Commissioner Service is required to operate within an approved staff ceiling which has recently been reduced. The Trade Commissioner Service is therefore currently undergoing a period of contraction rather than expansion.
(2) Cabinet has approved the opening of a new trade commissioner post.
(a) The post will be established in the southern region of the United States.

(b) The southern region was chosen because of the considerable economic development that is taking place in that area and the increased trading opportunities that are available for Australia. Many new factories are being built along with related infrastructure and urban development to accommodate the companies and people moving to the region from the northern states. The region has a high level of energy and mineral development. Population of the area is in the vicinity of 54 million and foreign imports amount to more than $46,000m. Australia's current share of these foreign imports is established to be less than 1 per cent.

Australian trade commissioners have undertaken extensive market surveys in the southern states. They have identified good prospects for Australian uranium, steaming coal, agricultural machinery, castings, bulk handling equipment, motor vehicle parts, marine equipment, apparel, foodstuffs, beer and wine. There is a reliable direct shipping service from Australia to the area. There are also prospects of obtaining off-shore contract work particularly in the energy related fields.

The southern states of the United States of America are currently serviced by the trade commissioners in Chicago and New York. These trade commissioners are too far away from the southern states and a new post in the southern region is considered to be necessary to effectively develop the market for Australian products and services.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 6 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Are there any restrictions on live fish imports into Australia; if so, what are the restrictions; and if not, has the Government any plans to introduce restrictions on these imports.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Yes. The importation of live fish and live aquatic invertebrates is controlled under the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations. Live trout and salmon, or their eggs, are prohibited imports under Quarantine Proclamation 86A. Other species posing health risks to this country or fish from particularly high risk areas could also be proclaimed in the future, if necessary.
Sick and diseased fish arriving in Australia can be seized and treated or if necessary, destroyed.
A new system of fish quarantine and a list of freshwater aquarium species allowed continued importation are currently being developed.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 13 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the present stage of the inquiry into agricultural engineering referred to in the first report of the Commonwealth Council for Rural Research and Extension tabled in the Senate on 12 May 1981.
(2) When will the result of the inquiry be communicated to the Senate.
(3) Is the inquiry to be proceeded with; if not (a) was this a decision of all members of the Council; and (b) why was the decision taken.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The report 'Agricultural Engineering Research Development and Extension in Australia' prepared by Professor C. G. E. Downing of the University of Melbourne on commission from the Commonwealth Council for Rural Research and Extension is currently in press.

The Standing Committee on Agriculture (SCA) is to consider a situation statement prepared by members and based on the Downing report. In addition, the Commonwealth Council for Rural Research and Extension (CCRRE) is preparing a separate report to me.

(2) The Downing report will be a public document. However, SCA reports are confidential to the Australian Agricultural Council (AAC). It could be expected that when AAC has completed its consideration I will issue a press release giving details which will be available, of course, to each member of the Senate.
The CCRRE report should be finalised shortly. I will consider then its public release.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 13 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the present stage of the inquiry into poultry research referred to in the first report of the Commonwealth Council for Rural Research and Extension tabled in the Senate on 12 May 1981.
(2) When will the result of the inquiry be communicated to the Senate.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) A joint Standing Committee on Agriculture (SCA)/Commonwealth Council for Rural Research and Extension (CCRRE) working party review on poultry research was considered by SCA in February, 1981. It decided to appoint a high level working party of its Advisory Committee on Priorities in Rural Research and Extension to address in greater depth the question of research and extension priorities and rationalisation in the poultry industry. (2) SCA reports are confidential to the Australian Agricultural Council (AAC). It could be expected, however, that when AAC has completed its consideration I will issue a press release giving details which will be available, of course, to each member of the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 13 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the present stage of the inquiry into pig research referred to in the first report of the Commonwealth Council for Rural Research and Extension tabled in the Senate on 12 May 1981.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

It decided to appoint a high level working party of its Advisory Committee on Priorities in Rural Research and Extension to address in greater depth the question of research and extension priorities and rationalisation in the pig industry.
