QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 13 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What alternatives will be given to unemployed persons under 18 if unemployment benefits are abolished.
(2) Will they be paid an equivalent amount to stay at school.
(3) Will Australian secondary schools be able to cope with an additional 40-50,000 students in years 11 and 12 if they all decide to either continue or return to school.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Education has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2)-As I said in my statement to the Parliament of 4 June concerning Commonwealth education policy and financial guidelines to the Commonwealth education commissions, the Government, in its efforts to alleviate the problems faced by young people, is concerned to ensure that there is an adequate system of financial support for those undertaking education and training. The Government has under review the payment of unemployment benefits to 16 and 17 year olds. The Government's position is that no adverse changes to unemployment benefit will be made unless better alternatives are available to the young people affected and the Government is satisfied that the interests of low income families and other disadvantaged groups would be protected. We will be giving further consideration to the range of allowances for young people in the Budget context.

(3)-The Government would not expect additional enrolments of this order in the schools system as a result of its transition policies which make substantial provisions for the technical and further education sector as well as schools. In addition, despite the Government's expressed hopes for greater retention in secondary schools and the enrolment pressures in the non-government sector, we expect that there will be a continued decline in overall school enrolments due to demographic factors. The Government is confident under these circumstances that the schools systems in the States will have the capacity to accommodate increased numbers of students wishing to undertake transition programs which are developing as a result of the Commonwealth's own efforts and those of the States.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Training and Advisory Centre for Intellectually Handicapped Children

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 13 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is there a proposal to freeze the funds being allocated to the Training and Advisory Centre for Intellectually Handicapped Children, conducted at the Preston Institute of Technology.
(2) Is the Minister aware of the threat to this institution and of the hardship that would result if funds were effectively frozen.
(3) Did the Government cut back aid because it considered the centre was inadequate and if so, in what ways.

(4) Was the centre fulfilling its role; if so, why will the Government's commitment to the International Year of the Disabled be directed more towards funding advertisements than to supporting practical action.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (4) The Education Program for Infants and Children (EPIC) conducted at the Preston Institute of Technology is one of a number of early intervention programs for handicapped children being assisted with subsidies under the Children's Services Program. The Schonell Education and Research Centre has been contracted to conduct a nationwide evaluation of all early intervention programs, including EPIC. The report on this evaluation project has recently been submitted. Following consideration of this report, and a review of the Children's Services Program which will be completed within the next few weeks, my department will be developing guidelines on the assessment and funding of programs of this type, taking into account the quite complex interaction of State and Commonwealth responsibilities in the area of early intervention programs. The EPIC project was originally approved in 1975 as a three-year pilot program. However, pending resolution of the complex issues involved, I have recently approved an extension of funding under the Children's Services Program until 31 December 1981.

I consider that money spent on the national advertising campaign for the International Year of Disabled Persons is of great practical value as it seeks to raise community awareness of the needs of the disabled. This sort of awareness is essential to the success of many programs, including programs such as the EPIC project.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 13 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Did a statement issued jointly by the Ministers for Education and Employment and Youth Affairs in November say that the low retention rate in Australian secondary schools was a contributing factor to youth unemployment; if so, how is this statement equated with the fact that the Australian Capital Territory has the highest retention rate in Australia (69.6 per cent compared with a national retention rate of 34.7 per cent) and yet the ACT has the highest percentage of youth unemployment i.e. 24.7 per cent compared with a national rate of 21.1 per cent.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Education has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: No joint statement of the kind referred to was issued in November last year. However, in a statement issued by the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs and myself on 16 January 1981 announcing the Government's review of opportunities for youth, it was noted that Australia has lower retention rates in secondary schools than most other Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries, and that many early school leavers find it difficult to gain employment.

We stated the Commonwealth's belief that further efforts are called for by both the Federal and State Governments to improve opportunities for youth and that this should be done in two ways. First, by seeing that the economy grows so that more long term sustainable jobs will become available. Second, by ensuring that government and non-government schools and training institutions provide more suitable courses and training effectively the needs of young Australians who now leave school early and who find it difficult to make the transition from school to work.

The availability of employment for young people varies from one location to another, as do retention rates in secondary education. That the ACT is a typical in respect of both employment and school retention rates does not affect the fact that early school leavers experience substantially greater problems in the transition to working life than those who continue their education and that further improvement in education and training for young people is possible. If school retention rates in the ACT were lower, it would be reasonable to expect a higher level of youth unemployment than currently is the case.

As I announced to Parliament on 4 June, the Government is taking special action to increase significantly the resources devoted to transition activities in schools. It wishes to accelerate the development of appropriate transition courses in secondary schools with emphasis on basic changes in curricula relevant particularly to the needs of low achievers. Through these changes the Commonwealth hopes to see more young people who may be 'at risk' in the transition process staying on to complete their secondary education. We are endeavouring to assist the education system to do a better job in serving the needs of all children and in maintaining their interest in formal education. The objective is to improve the basic skills and employment prospects of young people as they leave the education system particularly in the face of a decline in the number of unskilled jobs in the community.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 14 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Department of Social Security had educational testing done to establish the educational standard needed to complete the present unemployment benefit form; if so, what is that standard.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Yes. The unemployment benefit claim form has been subjected to tests which could be described as educational tests. This was a part of a broader program to ensure that the Department of Social Security's forms, leaflets, automated advices and other written communications with clients are as comprehensible as possible.

One method used by education researchers to establish the educational standard needed to comprehend a written communication is to measure its 'readability'. With the aid of an expert consultant, readability assessment techniques have been adapted to provide some measure of the reading skills required for comprehending the department's client communications.

Readability testing of sample materials indicated that leaflets required reading skills of up to fourth year of secondary school and a computer advice series up to the final year of secondary school. Insofar as such techniques can be applied to the non-continuous text of forms, the present Unemployment Benefit claim form has an average readability level of around the fourth year of secondary school.

This form is currently being re-worked for the next re-print and it is expected that it will be possible to devise a form with an average readability level of about the first year of secondary school. The leaflets and the advices now have levels between the last year of primary school and the second year of secondary school.
I would emphasise there are factors other than readability which effect comprehension of written media, and particularly forms-such as layout, type styles and sizes and use of colour.
An improvement in the department's client material should become more apparent as further skills are developed within the Department and more material is progressively reviewed.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 14 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Does the Department of Social Security facilitate the negotiation of a pensioner's cheque by outside authorities by directing the cheques to those authorities, which can then deduct any sums owed by the pensioner; if so, which authorities have this power, and what are the limitations to this practice, which would seem to have serious implications for the dignity and privacy of a pensioner.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: There are some pensioners who, for reasons of security, privacy or some other personal reason request pension cheques to be forwarded to them care of a post office box or some other address that is not their current residential address. There are situations where pensioners have requested that their pension cheques be forwarded to them care of a business address, for example a State Housing Authority. This of course, is the pensioner's prerogative. In these situations, the cheque remains payable to the pensioner.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 26 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Statement on Review of Commonwealth Functions state that the Townsville College of Advanced Education will not receive Commonwealth funding as a separate institution from the end of 1981.

(2) Has the Queensland Government made representations to the Federal Government in relation to retaining the Townsville CAE as a separate Institution; if so, what is the nature of these representations and has the Federal Government responded to the Queensland Government's representations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Education has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Following the Review of Commonwealth Functions, the Government announced that thirty existing colleges with teacher education as their main activity would be consolidated into larger units by incorporation into a multi-purpose or multi-campus college with a single governing body or by integration with a neighbouring university. The Townsville College of Advanced Education is one of these colleges. It is the Government's intention to reach agreement with each State about rationalisation measures by the end of 1981. (2) Consultation is taking place with all State Governments including the Queensland Government on the implementation of the Government's decision. The Tertiary Education Commission will be consulting with responsible State bodies and will be reporting back on progress by 30 June and finally by 31 August in time for necessary legislation in the Budget Sittings.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 27 November 1980 (Hansard, page 112) Senator Teague asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, a question without notice as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: With reference to the pending amendments to tax legislation which will give a substantial and very much welcomed incentive for investment in the Australian film industry. When will that legislation be introdcuced in the Parliament? Does the legislation provide safeguards to avoid the production of third rate films when overseas and local investors are interested only in taking advantage of these tax laws for financial gain, irrespective of the quality of the film produced? If the legislation does not include such safeguards, can attention be given to their inclusion, nevertheless avoiding any odious procedure of bureaucratic censorship?
The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Amendments to give effect to the new concessions for investment in Australian films are contained in the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill 1981 which was introduced in the House of Representatives on 27 May 1981.

The concessions are available to resident investors and contain safeguards against their exploitation for tax avoidance purposes. It is intended that the concession be the subject of future review. At that time its effectiveness in promoting quality productions will be carefully considered.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 11 March 1981 (Hansard, page 487) Senator Hamer asked me a question, without notice, concerning the number of car air conditioning sets in use and the effects on fuel economy. In his question Senator Hamer asked me whether I could consult with my colleagues about encouraging at least one of our manufacturers to design and produce cars which would be more suitable for our climate and which would not require air conditioning.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Industry and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

There are no official statistics collected on the number of new motor vehicles sold with air conditioning equipment fitted nor are statistics available on the after-sale fitment of such units. Accordingly I am not in a position to comment on the extent of installation of air conditioning in new cars or the vehicle population generally.
Australia's climatic conditions are not unique. Most of the vehicle designs sold in Australia are also sold in countries which experience similar or even wider temperature ranges.

Provision of air conditioning has become more common under the influence of industrial awards in vehicles purchased primarily for commercial use. As consumers have become more affluent they have been more able, and more prepared, to meet the cost of extra fittings such as air conditioning which would add to the comfort and enjoyment of motoring.

The matter of the design of vehicles, including adaptation to meet particular Australian conditions, is properly one for vehicle manufacturers to determine in the light of their perceptions as to the demands of Australian consumers and the economics of meeting these demands.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 2 April 1981 (Hansard, page 1036) Senator Evans asked me a question without notice concerning any negotiations which may be taking place between either Mr Rupert Murdoch or Sir Peter Abeles or Mr R. Holmes a'Court and the Government related to the sale of Trans-Australia Airlines and amendments to the Broadcasting and Television Act.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Transport has provided the following information in response to the honourable senator's question, so far as it relates to his portfolio:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 8 April 1981 (Hansard, page 1208) Senator Primmer asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for the Capital Territory, a question seeking information concerning the granting of concessions on electricity charges to pensioners in the ACT. The position is essentially as I indicated in my original reply. It is a fact that the Government has granted concessions on electricity charges to pensioners in the Australian Capital Territory by way of the lesser of $10 or 50 per cent rebate on their quarterly electricity accounts.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for the Capital Territory has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Government has a multiple role in administering and financing the Australian Capital Territory and it is important to remember that Canberra is the one city in Australia for which this Parliament is responsible. Funding arrangements for the Territory's Federal, State and Local Government responsibilities must be made through the Parliamentary Budgetary process. In the context of its Territorial role and having in mind the schemes operating in the surrounding region the Government adopted a rebate scheme for the ACT.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 29 April 1981 (Hansard, page 1454) Senator Young asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, a question without notice, concerning proposals to introduce aircraft movement charges for general aviation at major Commonwealth airports.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Transport has provided me with the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The proposal to introduce aircraft movement charges for general aviation at major Commonwealth airports is one of a number of recommendations contained in the report of the General Aviation Study, which was recently released by the Government. The Government has no commitment at this stage to any of its recommendations, and industry has been invited to submit comments on the proposals before they are considered by Government.

For some time the Government has been concerned about the low level of recovery of the costs of airport and airway facilities used by general aviation. Although the Government has had a long standing objective of full recovery of costs attributable to civil aviation, it recognises that any rapid move towards full recovery would cause severe disruption to the industry.

Thus the charges proposed in the Study are aimed at recovering some one third of facility costs attributable to general aviation, and specific account was taken of operators' ability to pay in recommending charging levels.

The recommended charging levels range from $20 per aircraft movement at primary capital city airports such as Sydney or Adelaide, to $4 per aircraft movement at major general aviation aerodromes such as Bankstown or Parafield. In all some 27 capital city and regional airports would be affected if the proposal is adopted.

It was recognised that flying training operations at these aerodromes could be particularly affected by the movement charges. While it is not suggested that trainee pilots would be exempt from paying the charges, the Committee considered some measure of relief through the treatment of 'touch and go' operations as a single movement.

The Study report identifies the extent to which flying training and other general aviation activities would be suppressed by the cost recovery proposals. Of course the implications of such suppression in general aviation activity will be considered by Government when it addresses the Study's recommendations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 7 May 1981 (Hansard, page 1727) Senator Lajovic asked me as the Minister representing the Minister for Transport a question without notice, concerning Australian participation in the Conference which drew up International Labour Organisation Merchant Shipping (Minimum Standards) Convention 147 and whether it is intended that Australia become a party to that Convention.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Transport has provided me with the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Australia was represented at the 62nd (Maritime) session of the International Labour Conference, 1976 where International Labour Organisation Convention No. 147-Merchant Shipping (Minimum Standards) 1976 was adopted.

It is established Australian policy that ILO Conventions are ratified only when the law and practice in all relevant Australian jurisdictions comply with the provisions of a particular Convention. While Australian law and practice do not, at present, comply fully with the provisions of Convention No. 147, the question of compliance, and hence ratification of the instrument is subject to periodic examination.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 28 May 1981 (Hansard, page 2246) Senator Townley asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, a question without notice, concerning the minting of commemorative coins.

ANSWER.PARA: I undertook to refer the question to the Treasurer who has provided the following answer:

The amendments to the Currency Act 1965 effected by the Currency Amendment Act 1981 provide, inter alia, for the issue of coins without the need for additional legislation. The Act now provides for new denominations of coins and their standard compositions to be prescribed by regulation and authorises the Treasurer to cause any such coins to be made and issued. The Act currently empowers the Treasurer to issue a $10 silver coin to commemorate the 1982 Commonwealth Games in Brisbane. In respect of other possible issues, it has been longstanding policy that commemorative coin issues should be confined to occasions of national interest and importance.

There is no present intention to alter the size of Australian coins. The scope for such alteration is in any case limited by the need to retain an adequate differentiation in surface area between coins of the same metal for identification purposes.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 28 April 1981 (Hansard, page 1383) Senator Sibraa asked me a question, without notice, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Defence in the Senate. His question concerned the presence of Soviet bombers at Cam Ranh Bay in Vietnam.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Defence has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

I am aware of newspaper articles which make a number of claims about an intelligence report on Soviet 'Backfire' Bombers at Cam Ranh Bay in Vietnam. These articles are speculative and I am not prepared to confirm or deny the existence of such a report. When asked over a weekend about the presence of Soviet aircraft at Cam Ranh Bay I based my answer on my knowledge of the Soviet aircraft that I knew to be there, knowledge shared by many of the public. If on this occasion confusion between Tu95 'Bears' and Tu22m 'Backfires' arose from an informal telephone query, then so be it.

What is indisputable is the fact that the USSR is using military bases in Vietnam and that Soviet aircraft are based there. The USSR has used military facilities in Vietnam-including Cam Ranh Bay-since the Sino-Vietnamese conflict of early 1979, and usage of Cam Ranh Bay in particular by Soviet naval and air forces continues. What is therefore of importance regarding this issue is not what specific aircraft types the USSR has stationed in Vietnam, but rather the fact that the USSR is developing its strength and influence there. This continuing and increasing presence in Vietnam provides a factor of uncertainty in the East and South East Asian regions and as such is a matter of concern to the Government. It continues to be monitored carefully by our intelligence agencies.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 31 March 1981 (Senate Hansard, page 883) Senator MacGibbon asked me the following question, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: My question to the Attorney-General follows on Senator Evans's question expressing his great concern about the proper use of funds for legal aid. I ask: Is it a fact that the Australian Labor Party so engineered its High Court challenge to the results in New South Wales after the recent 1980 Federal elections that the person or persons who appealed the result were funded by legal aid? Is this a proper use of those funds?
The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:
No person has received financial assistance from the Commonwealth for a challenge to a result in New South Wales at the 1980 Federal elections.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 5 May 1981 (Hansard, page 1566) Senator Walsh asked me a question, without notice, as the Minister representing the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs. It arose from the report of the Review of Commonwealth Functions. Decision No. 3 under the heading of 'Business and Consumer Affairs'. He asked.

ANSWER.PARA: What proportion of the Prices Justification Tribunal staff does the Government intend to absorb into the proposed new bureaucracy for what the report calls 'the maintenance of the Government's petroleum product pricing policy'? What will the net savings, if any, be? Has the cost of the new bureaucracy been deducted from the assumed ultimate $560m savings?
The Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

In my second reading speech on the Petroleum Products Pricing Bill which I introduced into Parliament on 27 May 1981, I stated that the Authority would have substantially fewer staff than the PJT. Staffing arrangements for the new Authority, including the proportion of PJT staff that will be absorbed into it, are among matters which are currently under discussion with the Public Service Board.
I would expect the savings to the budget that will result from the new pricing arrangements to be commensurate with the staff savings and the reduction in the cost of public inquiries.

In his statement of 30 April 1981 the Prime Minister indicated that the figure of $560 million was an estimate of the eventual ongoing saving in Budget outlays which would result from the Review of Commonwealth Functions, compared with the cost of continuing programs on the basis of existing policies and arrangements. The Government's decisions in relation to prices surveillance were taken into account in arriving at that figure.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Telephone Calls between Melbourne and Hobart

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 12 May 1981, (Hansard, page 1809) Senator Townley asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Communications, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and refers to an advertisement that appeared in several newspapers last week headed 'Long distance for less'. The advertisement suggests that there will be a 20 to 25 per cent reduction in long distance telephone call rates over certain distances. Is the Minister aware that this large reduction in rates will apply between Melbourne and Sydney, Sydney and Brisbane and Melbourne and Adelaide, amongst other places, but not between Melbourne and Hobart? In other words, the reduction will apply between all adjacent capital cities in the east of Australia, except between Melbourne and Hobart. Obviously I ask: Will the Government examine or ask Telecom Australia to examine the situation to see whether the reduction can apply between Melbourne and Hobart?
The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

I am advised by Telecom Australia that the advertisement referred to was in connection with the introduction on 26 April 1981 of a new STD rate (day rate of $2.16 for three minutes) for calls made over distances between 645 km and 1,145 km. Previously, all calls over 645 km were charged at the day rate of $2.70 for three minutes. As well as the examples quoted by the honourable senator, the new rate also applies to calls between Hobart and Sydney. The new rate represents a further stage in Telecom's program of reducing long distance trunk rates. The honourable senator would be aware that Hobart callers to Melbourne have already benefited from an earlier step in this program under which calls between Hobart and Melbourne-which fall in the 325 km to 645 km distance charging category-were reduced from $2.02 to $1.80 for three minutes as from May 1980.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 5 June 1981 (Hansard, page 1460), Senator Teague asked me a question, without notice, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry in the Senate. His question concerned the prawn fishing industry in South Australia. The Minister for Primary Industry has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: On 27 March 1981 the Minister for Primary Industry and the Honourable W. A. Rodda, South Australian Minister of Fisheries, made a joint statement about management of prawn fishing in South Australia. The Ministers pointed out that a downward trend in catch rates in the Gulf St Vincent and Investigator Strait prawn fishery warranted consideration of a reduction in fishing effort. The Minister for Primary Industry stated that the Commonwealth was considering a partial or total closure of the prawn fishery in Commonwealth waters of Investigator Strait but first invited comments from interested people.

Numerous submissions, including some from the organisations to which Senator Teague referred, sought restructions, either partial or total, on prawn fishing in the area concerned. These submissions and other comments received are being examined by South Australian and Commonwealth officers. The Minister and the South Australian Minister of Fisheries expect to make a joint announcement on the matter in the near future.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 26 November 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are applicants for legal aid now required to apply for such aid in the city where their case is to be heard; if so, does this situation cause hardship for applicants in certain situations, for example, where the proceedings in a case are subsequently transferred to a different city, or where residents of Victoria have a motor accident in New South Wales.
(2) Will the Attorney-General consider relaxing this requirement to enable legal aid applications to be made, where desirable, in cities other than those in which each particular case is to be heard.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answers to the honourable senator's questions are as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: There have been difficulties in establishing a common approach to the general matter raised in this question between the Australian Legal Aid Office (ALAO) and State and Territory legal aid commissions that have absorbed the ALAO.

A person seeking legal aid from the Australian Legal Aid Office may obtain assistance from the Office, subject to the Office means and needs test guidelines, provided the assistance relates to a proceeding in a court or tribunal in a State or Territory in which the Office is located.

Where an applicant resident in a State or Territory where the ALAO still operates seeks legal aid in relation to proceedings in that State or Territory, he may apply at any ALAO Office in that State or Territory.

Where an applicant seeks legal aid in relation to proceedings in another State or Territory where the ALAO operates, he may apply to any ALAO Office in his State or Territory of residence or in the State or Territory where the proceedings are to be heard.

If a person resident in a State or Territory where the ALAO still operates requires legal aid for proceedings in a State or Territory where a legal aid commission has commenced operations and has absorbed the functions of the ALAO, he should apply to the appropriate commission in that State or Territory. If that person attends the ALAO in his State or Territory of residence, the office will endeavour to assist him to establish his eligibility for legal aid from the Commission in the other State or Territory.

The practical effect of the above arrangements is, for example, that a resident of Victoria suffering a motor vehicle accident in New South Wales may apply for legal aid to the ALAO Office most convenient to him in Victoria or to an Office in New South Wales.

I am informed that an agreement has been entered into between the commissions in Western Australia, South Australia and Victoria covering the general matter raised in the question. I am informed that a person may obtain legal aid from a commission in New South Wales, Queensland or the Australian Capital Territory only in relation to a proceeding in a court or tribunal in the State or Territory in which the commission is located.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 24 February 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Which of the following documents, which were included in 'An Inside Dopester's Index of One Hundred Examples of Secrecy', an appendix to the book Secrecy: Political Censorship in Australia by Jim Spigelman (Angus and Robertson, Sydney, 1972), have now been published: (a) No. 18-Number of applications for public service employment rejected on security grounds; (b) No. 18-Number of cases where promotion for public servants has been adversely affected by a security report; (c) No. 70-Legal opinions received on the lowering of the voting age to 18; (d) No. 78-Report on Law Council of Australia recommendation in regard to the Territories Criminal Code; (e) No. 79-Departmental reports on abortion and homosexuality; (f) No. 99-Statistics on mail interception for security reasons; and (g) No. 100-'Protective Security Handbook'.
(2) Which of the abovementioned documents have now otherwise been made available?
(3) Which of the documents so far not made available would the Government not be prepared to make available either unconditionally or on any, and if so, what conditions?
(4) Which of the documents does the Government continue to refuse to make available, and why?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's questions are as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) As to information described in (a) and (b), I am advised that the Public Service Board does not keep records of the number of persons refused appointments or affected by adverse or qualified security assessments. At paragraph 85 and Appendix 2 (b) of the Second Report of the Royal Commission on Security and Intelligence (Parliamentary Paper 247/1979), Mr Justice Hope set out certain information regarding the number of security checks for access to classified matter in the years 1970-1974.

As to the opinions described in (c), this is understood to refer to opinions by the law officers. Those opinions have not been published. Legal advice given to the Government is not generally made available to the public during the closed archives period. Access to such advice may be given for particular reasons or in particular circumstances.

The 'reports' referred to in (d) and (e) appear to be parts of a paper prepared by the First Assistant Secretary of the Attorney-General's Department to assist the then Attorney-General's Department to assist the then Attorney-General in his consideration of the Law Council of Australia's Draft Criminal Code for the Australian Territories (Parliamentary Paper 44/1969). The purpose of the paper was to set out the then current position of the law in the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory and the changes that would be involved if the Law Council's recommendations were adopted. I am advised that the paper has not been published nor has it otherwise been made available. I would be prepared to make the paper available if requested to do so.

As to the information in (f), I refer the honourable senator to my remarks during the debate on the Australian Security Intelligence Bill 1979 setting out the Government's policy on this matter (Hansard, Senate, 10 May 1979, page 1876). This policy is consistent with long-standing practice.

As to the documents in (g), the document which in 1972 was known as the 'Protective Security Handbook' has not been officially published or otherwise officially made available to the public. The Handbook consists of 11 chapters and 2 appendices and I consider that Chapters 1, 2, 3, 4, 8 and 11 may be made available upon request. The remaining chapters and the 2 appendices deal with measures for the protection of information relating to the national security. To make this information available publicly could reasonably be expected to cause damage to the national security in that it would provide an officially confirmed insight into the protective measures adopted to protect sensitive material and provide organisations or persons hostile to Australia's national interests with material which could assist their circumvention of those protective measures. The current Protective Security Handbook has been made available publicly and is published as Appendix 3 to the Report on the Freedom of Information Bill 1978 by the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs (Parliamentary Paper 272/1979).

In his answer to Question No. 257 (Senate Hansard, 27 May 1981, page 2222), the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs indicated that I would provide an answer in respect of document No. 19-Commonwealth Solicitor-General's report on Aboriginal land rights. The reference appears to be to a paper entitled 'Recognition of Aboriginal Land Claims on Reserves in the Northern Territory', prepared by the then Solicitor-General, Mr R. J. Ellicott, Q.C. (now Mr Justice Ellicott), and submitted to the then Prime Minister, Sir William McMahon. The paper was subsequently made available by the Solicitor-General to Mr Whitlam after he became Prime Minister. The paper has not been made available publicly. Any request for access to the paper made to myself or my Department would be dealt with in accordance with the principles of the Freedom of Information Bill 1981.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 5 December 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Which of the following documents, which were included in 'An Inside Dopester's Index of One Hundred Examples of Secrecy', an appendix to the book Secrecy : Political Censorship in Australia by Jim Spigelman (Angus and Robertson, Sydney, 1972), have now been published: (a) No. 2-1971 Interdepartmental committee report on the state of the economy; (b) No. 3-Proceedings of Commonwealth/ State Ministers and officials meetings; (c) No. 4-Proceedings of the Loan Council; (d) No. 62-Structure and membership of interdepartmental committees; (e) No. 72-Interdepartmental report on national superannuation; (f) No. 85-Committee report on requests for troops from South Vietnam; and (g) No. 61-Membership of Cabinet Committees.
(2) Which of the above-mentioned documents have now otherwise been made available.
(3) Which of the documents so far not made available would the Government now be prepared to make available either unconditionally or on any, and if so, what conditions.
(4) Which of the documents does the Government continue to refuse to make available, and why.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) Item No. 2-'1971 interdepartmental committee report on the state of the economy'.
Committee reports of this type are not generally published. The Government's consideration of advice relating to the economy is reflected in the Budget Speech and associated papers.
(b) Item No. 3-'Proceedings of Commonwealth/State Ministers and officials meetings.'
Consistent with longstanding practice, the proceedings of Commonwealth/State Ministers and officials meetings are not normally published.
The Commonwealth and all States have consistently required the confidentiality of Loan Council proceedings.
(d) Item No. 62-'Structure and membership of interdepartmental committees.'
It has been the practice of successive governments not to authorise the expenditure of the considerable time and effort required to collate and provide such information.
(e) Item No. 72-'Interdepartmental report on national superannuation.'

The present Leader of the Opposition explained the reason for not releasing this document in response to an earlier question. (Question No. 2280, House of Representatives, Hansard, 5 June 1975, pages 3506-7).
(f) Item No. 85-'Committee report on requests for troops from South Vietnam.'
I am advised that officials reported orally on this matter to the then Prime Minister, and that no written report was prepared.
This Government's practice has been to make public the membership of its Cabinet Committees.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 25 February 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Attorney-General aware of a submission from the Queensland branch of the Special Libraries Section concerning amendments to the Copyright Act?
(2) What steps have been taken to investigate and correct problems highlighted by the submission?

(3) Will the Act be amended, or regulations passed which will: (a) permit the greater circulation of title pages and table of contents pages of publications; (b) permit a speedier transmission of photocopies to those who are at present disadvantaged by their distance from a library; (c) protect the confidentiality of information gained by a copyright owner from any inspection of declarations; (d) remove the present ambiguity in the Act relating to the photocopying of publications of less than 10 pages and what may be a 'reasonable portion' of such a document for the purposes of photocopying?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's questions are as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) and (3) The submission to which reference is made has been considered and replied to. The submission alleged deficiencies in the Copyright Amendment Act 1980 along the lines referred to in part (3). It is not considered that any of the objections taken in the submission warrant further amendment of the legislation at this stage. However, the operation of the Act, after it comes into force, will be kept under review.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 4 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Were persons whose conspiracy charges were withdrawn in the alleged social security fraud case required to complete a form when they were paid compensation.
(2) What were the terms of that form.
(3) Do the terms preclude those persons taking legal action against the Commonwealth in respect of its actions in the affair.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Amounts in settlement of claims for costs were offered to a number of defendants against whom conspiracy charges did not proceed. These defendants were legally represented but were not awarded costs by the Magistrate when they were discharged. They were asked to sign a form of release which recorded an 'agreement to accept the sum of $ in full settlement of any right to costs which I may have against the Informant in respect of the charge laid against me for an alleged offence under Section 86 (1) (e) of the Crimes Act 1914.' QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 3 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) On how many days have the members of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal sat on social security cases from its inception to 28 February 1981?
(2) What payment has been received by each member?
(3) How many cases have been decided in that time?
(4) In how many cases were the decisions in the appellant's favour?
(5) How many appeals were being considered or were waiting to be considered by the Tribunal as at 28 February 1981?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's questions are as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) From 1 April 1980 (when the social security jurisdiction conferred by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (Social Services Act) Regulations came into force) to 28 February 1981, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal sat on 16 days hearing applications for the review of social security decisions. The Tribunal was constituted in each case by three members. In addition, 8 preliminary conferences, presided over by a single member of the Tribunal, were held during that period.

(2) Payment received by each member in respect of social security cases alone is not readily available. Presidential members of the Tribunal are all Judges of the Federal Court of Australia and are remunerated in that capacity.Full time senior non-presidential members are paid on annual salary, at present $45,899. Part time members of the Tribunal are paid sitting fees as follows:
Senior members $200 per day Members $180 per day

Part time members of the Tribunal who sit on social security cases may also sit on other cases, and may be involved in both social security and other matters in any one day. Consequently the fees paid to part time members who sit on social security cases do not always relate solely to the work on these cases.
(3) Three cases were decided by the Tribunal after a hearing. Fifty-four cases were disposed of by directions of the President without the Tribunal proceeding to make a decision.
(4) Of the three applications decided after a hearing:
in one case the Tribunal set aside the decision of the Director-General of Social Services and granted a widow's pension
in one case the Tribunal affirmed the Director-General's decision
in one case the Tribunal held that there was no reviewable decision.
Of the 54 applications disposed of by directions of the President:
in 11 cases the applicants' claims were conceded by the Director-General
38 cases were not within the jurisdiction of the Tribunal
in five cases the applications were withdrawn.

(5) Seventy-six applications remained to be determined by the Tribunal at 28 February 1981. Of these applications, three had been heard and were awaiting decision, 11 cases were listed for hearing and in 62 cases either relevant documentation had yet to be furnished to the Tribunal or the parties were otherwise not ready for hearing.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 10 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What applications were made by the Education Centre for legal aid in relation to the legal action between WEA Records and the West Gippsland and La Trobe Valley Community Education Centre Ltd.
(2) What action was taken by Australian Legal Aid as a result of those applications.
(3) What was the justification of that action.
(4) Does the Attorney-General believe that Legal Aid receives sufficient funds from this Parliament to carry out its charter in the light of the answers to (1), (2) and (3).

(5) Is any action being taken to amend existing copyright law to ensure that institutions like the West Gippsland and La Trobe Valley Community Education Centre are not subjected to the possibility of potentially crippling legal actions in future.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1), (2) and (3) I am not prepared to provide the information sought by these parts of the question because to do so would involve a breach of the confidential relationship which exists between the Australian Legal Aid Office and applicants for legal aid.
(4) In general the funds are sufficient for the Australian Legal Aid Office to carry out its charter.

(5) I understand that the legal actions referred to relate to audio and visual copyright. I have received a report on 'Audio and Visual Reproduction and Copyright' which has been prepared by a non-government specialist review committee. I have asked officers of my Department to examine that report, which highlights the difficulty of striking a balance between the need to encourage the creation of works by protecting the interests of copyright owners on the one hand and the requirements of the community to have reasonable access to creative works and information on the other. It will be some time before the Government is in a position to indicate what, if any, changes it proposes to make to the Copyright Act 1968 in so far as it relates to audio and visual reproduction.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice on 10 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In the High Court case of McInnis v R. did the High Court uphold a rape conviction against an accused where the accused was too poor to afford legal counsel and, in the circumstances, legal aid was unavailable to provide counsel.
(2) Does Article 14 (3) (b), (c) and (d) of the United Nations International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights provide that an accused person should have access to counsel.
(3) Will the existing state of Australia's law as disclosed in McInnis v R. be reported in Australia's report to the United Nations on the implementation of this convention.
(4) What steps are being taken to make Australian law compatible with the U.N. convention in this regard.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answers to the honourable senator's questions are as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The case to which the honourable member refers was one in which special leave was sought to appeal against conviction on two counts of rape and unlawful deprivation of liberty, on the ground that the trial judge had refused to grant an adjournment to enable the accused to take additional steps to obtain legal assistance. The case is reported at 27 Australian Law Reports 449. In refusing the adjournment, the trial judge had taken into account other considerations including the interests of the prosecutrix, the witnesses and the Crown. The majority of the High Court concluded that in all the circumstances of the case a miscarriage of justice had not occurred. Three of the four judges constituting the majority also held that it could not be said the trial judge had wrongly refused the adjournment.
(2) Sub-Article 14 (3) of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights provides:
'3. In the determination of any criminal charge against him, everyone shall be entitled to the following minimum guarantees, in full equality:
(b) To have adequate time and facilities for the preparation of his defence and to communicate with counsel of his own choosing;
(c) To be tried without undue delay;

(d) To be tried in his presence, and to defend himself in person or through legal assistance of his own choosing; to be informed, if he does not have legal assistance, of this right; and to have legal assistance assigned to him, in any case where the interests of justice so require, and without payment by him in any case if he does not have sufficient means to pay for it...'
(3) The contents of the Report to be made under Article 40 of the Covenant will be a matter for consideration by the Meeting of Ministers on Human Rights.

(4) I have asked my Department to examine the judgments of the High Court with a view to determining if there may be any inconsistency between Commonwealth laws and practices and Sub-Article 14(3) of the Covenant.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 10 March 1981:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: No. It would not be in the national interest for me to publicise in the Parliament a document providing details of the arrangements agreed for the exportation of uranium when there is still a potential for its use in foreign proceedings. I might add that, on application by a company pursuant to the Foreign Proceedings (Prohibition of Certain Evidence) Act, I would refuse my consent to the production of that document or any document containing similar detail of the arrangements.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 25 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Were two Royal Australian Air Force drivers hospitalised in Darwin in November 1980, following an incident involving the leaking of Malathion from corroded drums being transported to Darwin.

(2) Did Group Captain L. D. Wilkinson on 4 March 1981, advise (a) that Malathion is extremely toxic in vapour mist form and can be lethal; and (b) that proper precautions were not taken in handling this consignment.
(3) What chemicals are currently being used by service personnel for what purposes, and what precautions are taken.
(4) What investigation has the Minister for Defence made of the Darwin incident last November.
(5) Has the Minister for Defence advised the Commonwealth Department of Health of this incident.
(6) What is the condition of the two drivers hospitalised at present.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. Two RAAF drivers were held overnight at Mt Isa hospital on 7 November 1980 for observation after exposure to Malathion. They were subsequently treated as out-patients at the Base Medical Flight, RAAF Base Darwin between 13 and 16 November 1980, during which time blood specimens were taken for analysis. When last seen by the Senior Medical Officer RAAF Darwin on 16 November 1980, the drivers were free from any symptoms of effects from the exposure.

(2) (a) Yes. This statement was made by Group Captain L. D. Wilkinson in the interest of reminding RAAF personnel of the requirement for the correct handling procedures for insecticides. However, I am advised that although Malathion is capable of causing mortality through ingestion or long periods of inhalation of vapours in confined areas it is one of the least toxic of the organophosphate pesticides. The Time-Weighted Average (TWA) value used by the National Health and Medical Research Council is 10 milligrams per cubic metre for occupational exposure. That is, a person is not likely to suffer ill effect if breathing 10 milligrams per cubic metre of Malathion for eight hours a day, forty hours per week. For comparison purposes the TWA for Diazinon (another approved pesticide for use by the RAAF) is only 0.1 milligrams per cubic metre.

(b) Yes. Although the drivers were briefed on the load they were carrying, no specific briefing was given on the properties of the insecticide that formed part of the load. The RAAF Headquarters Support Command investigation into the incident determined that the Dangerous Cargo Handling Data and Preparation Certificate was not prepared for this consignment; nor was it separately manifested. However, 'Toxic' labels were affixed to the drums.

(3) As the incident in question involved RAAF personnel and because there are over 4,000 chemical compounds in use by the RAAF alone, the information provided will be confined to the subject of pesticides currently approved for use in the RAAF. They are as follows:
These pesticides are used for the specific purposes of the control of insects, rodents, fungal growths and weeds on RAAF bases. The repellents are used by individuals as required.

The RAAF limits the use of all pesticides (except repellents) to Hygiene Inspectors who receive specific training in the handling and application of these chemicals. These officers have available to them a wide range of personal protective and safety equipment for wear during pesticide use. The general matter of pesticide use in the Defence Force is monitored by the Pesticides Sub-Committee of the Medical Services Advisory Committee. A comprehensive Joint Service Manual on the handling and use of pesticides is being produced by the Sub-Committee.

(4) Following the incident, a Faulty Packaging Report was raised by RAAF Base Darwin and this was investigated by specialist officers at RAAF Headquarters Support Command. As a result all RAAF personnel involved with the handling of dangerous and toxic substances have been reminded to observe the appropriate regulations for the storage, handling, packaging and transport of dangerous goods. Additionally, drums of Malathion of similar age to those involved in the incident are being further inspected for possible corrosion.

(5) No. Incidents of this nature are not normally reported to the Commonwealth Department of Health. However, full details of the incident are recorded on each serving member's RAAF medical documents.
(6) Both drivers are presently employed in their normal service duties. Neither of the drivers has any symptoms of ill effects resulting from this incident.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Staging of United States Air Force B52 Aircraft

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 26 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: What costs to the Australian Government have been estimated to accrue regarding the staging of United States Air Force B52 aircraft through Darwin.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Clause (V) of the Notes exchanged between the Australian and the United States governments on 11 March 1981 relating to the use of Royal Australian Air Force Base Darwin by USAF B52 aircraft, refers to agreed financial arrangements.
It has been agreed that capital and operating costs including construction costs associated with changes to the airfield at Darwin will be met by the US.
There will also be some additional minor support costs, arrangements for which are still to be finalised, but in the main these will be met by the US.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 31 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When was the last time the Prime Minister held a Press conference of which all members of the Press were notified in advance;
(2) How is the frequency of Press conferences reconciled with the previously expressed commitment to open Government.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) It is the Government's objective that the public be provided with comprehensive information on Government policies and programs. Press conferences are only one means of achieving that objective.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 1 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Did the Attorney-General or any officer of his department receive written communication through the Department of Foreign Affairs or any other Department detailing the names of the people charged in Athens for offences under the Australian Social Services Act and the nature of the charges; if so what was the date of this communication (see answer to Question on Notice No. 76 Hansard page 457 dated 10 March 1981).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The newspaper report dated 27 May 1980 to which I referred in my answer to Question No. 76 contained the name of the nine persons said to have been charged in Athens.

A cable from the Australian Embassy in Athens dated 28 May 1980 to my Department confirmed that the names listed in the newspaper report were (except for 'Kotsogas' being spelt 'Kotsonas') the names of the nine persons involved. That cable was received by officers of my Department, through the Department of Foreign Affairs.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 1 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Attorney-General aware of the recent guidelines for the provision of legal or financial assistance by the Commonwealth Government published by the Attorney-General's Department; if so, do they represent a reduction of the availability of legal aid since 1980 and in what ways.
(2) Will the Attorney-General provide Senator Button with details of how and when guidelines on the provision of legal aid have been altered since 1975.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) On 12 March 1981 I tabled guidelines dealing with various forms of legal and financial assistance. Prior to 12 March 1981 there were no formal guidelines for the provision of legal and financial assistance other than the Guidelines for Legal Aid in Environmental Cases issued by the Australian Legal Aid Office and incorporated in the Hansard record of Senate Estimates Committee B (see Senate Hansard dated 13 October 1978, p. 320). I am sending Senator Button a copy of all sets of guidelines.
Except in relation to environmental cases, the guidelines tabled in March 1981 are a consolidation of principles that had been applied previously

The new guidelines for environmental cases are similar to the earlier ones except that eligibility is confined ordinarily to cases where the environmental issue arises in relation to Commonwealth activity or under a law of the Commonwealth.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 1 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the late Senator John Knight write to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on 28 September 1977 drawing the Minister's attention to an appeal lodged on 1 September 1975, by Dr F. E. Peters, then Australian Government Analyst against an instruction restricting Dr Peters' access to the Minister and the Minister's staff.

(2) Did the Minister, the Hon. Ian Viner, say in a letter to the late Senator John Knight, dated 13 January 1981, '. . . that the second part of the appeal which related to Dr Peters' right of access to his Minister was not determined at the time of Dr Peters' retirement, and therefore lapsed'.

(3) Why was the appeal not resolved before Dr Peters' retirement, and why has it taken four and a half years to inform the late Senator John Knight of this, despite many requests from the late Senator for information.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Acting Minister Assisting the Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The late Senator Knight wrote to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on 20 September 1977 mentioning representations from an unnamed constituent who had made an appeal under regulation 33 of the Public Service Regulations. Senator Knight made a general inquiry about the operation of the regulation to which the Minister responded by letter on 3 November 1977.

(2) and (3) Dr Peters' appeal was in two parts. The first part was resolved in November 1977. Mr Viner replied on 3 August 1978 to Senator Knight's letter of 16 February 1978 advising that Dr Peters had informed the Board that he did not want the second part of the appeal pursued. Mr Viner's subsequent letter of 13 January 1981 to Senator Knight was simply to inform him of the formal disposition of the appeal.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 7 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What was the purpose of the visit to Athens of Mr H. F. Woltring.
(2) Did he take with him papers related to charges against the persons arrested in Athens for fraud against the Social Services Act.
(3) Did he meet with officials of the Greek Government concerned with the court case involving charges under the Social Services Act of Australia.
(4) Did he receive information concerning the evidence for this case required by the Greek Government.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Mr H. F. Woltring travelled to Athens in February 1980 in order to accompany a prosecution witness to Australia. The magistrate hearing committal proceedings in Sydney concerned with charges of conspiracy to defraud the Commonwealth against the then group of 21 defendants had required that this witness be recalled. The witness set, as a condition of his return, that he be accompanied by an Australian Officer.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 7 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) To what extent will the recent ruling in the Westinghouse Case in the United States involve the recovery of damages from Australian companies, by seizure of their United States based assets.

(2) Does the government intend to implement 'recovery-back' legislation allowing for reciprocity of treatment by seizure of Westinghouse's Australian-based assets, as was floated by the Government last year and as enacted in the United Kingdom, if such action is not proposed, why not.
(3) Does government inaction in this matter amount to 'de facto recognition' of the United States courts' jurisdiction in Australia.
(4) Does the government continue to hold the view, expressed by the Attorney-General in October 1980, that Australia's national interest is jeopardised by Westinghouse proceedings.
(5) Has the Attorney-General or the Foreign Minister explored the possiblility of resisting the United States actions jointly with other nations.
(6) Did the Australian Government raise any of the implications of the Westinghouse Case with French, British or United States authorities negotiating agreements to sell their Australian uranium.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The settlement of the Westinghouse proceedings means that none of the United States based assets of the Australian defendants are at risk of seizure.

(2) I have introduced into the Senate the Foreign Antitrust Judgments (Restriction of Enforcement) Amendment Bill 1981 which provides for a right of recovery back in the specific circumstances set out in the Bill.

(3) The Government has not been inactive in this matter; reference is made to my press releases of 21 October 1979, 5 June and 5 October 1980 and 18 March 1981. The second reading speech to the abovementioned Bill makes very clear the Government's opposition to the mode in which United States antitrust laws are enforced extraterritorially.
(4) Those proceedings have been settled but the Government continues to regard the matters the subject of those proceedings as of concern to the national interest.

(6) No. On 1 June 1978 the Minister for Trade and Resources made a statement to the Parliament outlining the Governments' uranium export policy. The administration of that policy takes into account the extraterritorial application of United States antitrust laws.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 8 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Has United States Navy style khaki working clothing proved to be more practicable in the environment in which Royal Australian Navy personnel are working; if so, why does the Defence Department not provide this clothing free of charge to those RAN personnel (See Senate Hansard page 325, dated 31 March 1981).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Khaki working clothing is considered to be a very practical uniform in the circumstances of FFG personnel in United States of America but it is not regarded as being essential.

The approved scale of Service uniform for the RAN has been determined having regard to the wide range of working situations encountered during service, accepting that it may not be the ideal uniform for every situation.

The working environment of FFG personnel serving in USA does not differ markedly from a number of situations in Australia, notably in dockyards or the Naval Air Station, Nowra, at which the normal Service uniform is considered to be adequate.
It is not appropriate therefore that khaki clothing be adopted as official uniform for FFG personnel serving in USA and paid for at public expense.

(b) credibility and potential of the proposals in terms of providing a low risk solution within the planned three year implementation period for the first phase of DISCON;
(c) flexibility and potential for future development;
(f) consideration in respect of Foreign Ownership, Control and Influence.

(3) I refer the honourable senator to the answer provided to Question 643 (5).
(4) When a civilian employee of the Defence Department leaves for employment elsewhere in the Public Service, a record of his subsequent movement is not maintained by my Department.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 28 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has there been any examination, either by the Government, the National Disasters Organisation, to see if the procedure for preparation for emergencies such as cyclones was adequate, following the passing of Cyclone Max through Darwin.
(2) Were Telecom communications so overloaded during that time that authorities were unable to maintain telephone contact.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The primary responsibility for coping with disasters in the Northern Territory rests with the Government of the Northern Territory. This includes local counter-disaster planning and management.

The Natural Disasters Organisation has not sought advice regarding the adequacy or otherwise of the procedures adopted in Darwin to prepare for Cyclone Max, for those reasons and I am unaware of any examination by any other Commonwealth Government authority.
(2) I understand that some difficulties with telephone communications were experienced in Darwin because of the numerous calls from relatives and friends in other areas.
I also understand that Telecom was appraised of the problem.
The Natural Disasters Organisation had contact with the Northern Territory Emergency Service at all times.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Who ordered the Establishment Review conducted at the Joint Tropical Trials and Research Establishment (JTTRE) in September 1980.
(2) Is a copy of the Establishment Review available for the Parliament or for the public.
(3) What was the highest number of service personnel involved with JTTRE at any one time.
(4) How many civilians were employed at the unit during the time that service people were also there.
(5) Who will be responsible for the future administration of the unit.
(6) How many persons will be employed and what will be their qualifications.
(7) Is it proposed to retain the unit as a permanent establishment or does the Government propose to phase it out.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) JTTRE was a combined Civilian/Service Establishment from 1977 to early 1981. The Establishment Review was requested by the Controller of the Services Laboratories and Trials Division of the Defence Science and Technology Organisation, of which JTTRE forms a part.
(2) Yes-a copy of the document is available on request.
(5) The Officer-in-charge is a Senior Third Division professional Officer of the Australian Public Service (Experimental Officer Class 4).
(6) In the revised establishment there are 26 positions as follows:
2 Professional Officers (the OIC and an Experimental Officer Class 3)
In addition there are three United Kingdom scientific officers assigned to the Establishment.
(7) On present planning, JTTRE is to be retained as a permanent establishment.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 28 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: What is the estimated cost in 1980-81 of raising the minimum rate of pension under the Compensation (Commonwealth Employees) Act to 84 per cent of the minimum wage, and adjusting other payments under the Act accordingly.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The cost of raising compensation payments to 84 per cent of the minimum wage for the year 1980-81 is estimated at $3.5m.

This figure is a projection of actual expenditure figures for 1979-80 taken from that year's Report of the Commissioner for Employees Compensation, having regard to the statutory increase in benefits payable under the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act 1971 effective from 1 September 1980, and Adult Minimum Wage (Six Capital Cities) figures of $134.90 at 14 July 1980 and $139.90 at 9 January 1981.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 12 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the cost breakdown of the money which will be saved by the cuts announced in the Review of Commonwealth Functions.
(2) Why was that cost breakdown not made available to the Parliament at the earliest occasion possible, i.e. in the Ministerial Statement itself.
(3) Will the government make a breakdown available which will indicate the money saved by the implementation of each of the Review's recommendations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (3) In my statement to the Parliament of 30 April 1981 on the outcome of the Review of Commonwealth Functions I indicated that compared with the costs of continuing programs on the basis of existing policies and arrangements, the estimated overall effect of all RCF measures would be an eventual on-going saving in Budget outlays of the order of $560 million. Government revenue would also be boosted from the sale of assets and from a broad ranging reduction in various forms of assistance to industry through the tax system, saving some $130 million.

In reaching its decisions on individual items the Government took into account the financial, staffing and other implications for each measure. However, the Review was not primarily an exercise in cutting costs or containing expenditure programs, although this has been one desirable outcome of the Review.

Many of the decisions, while clearly leading to savings, were not of a kind where the savings could be stated at that time. In many cases precise amounts saved will only become clear as implementation proceeds. Other measures are of a general kind designed to contribute over time to efficiency of government and to provide increased opportunity for the private sector. These will lead to diffuse but widespread savings or benefits which, even if not directly measurable, will still be quite significant.
The Review was concerned with streamlining Commonwealth operations to create a smaller, more efficient government sector. In that task the Review has succeeded admirably.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 14 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Why is the Mandata project to computerise Public Service personnel records to be scrapped, in view of the Government's acceptance of the Myers Committee recommendations on introducing new technology?
(2) Will the task now revert to manual methods, if so what are the relative efficiencies of the two methods?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister Assisting the Prime Minister in Public Service matters has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government's attitude towards the Myers Committee recommendations is not in conflict with its decisions to terminate Mandata, a project which has not achieved the favourable direct cost/benefit outcome predicted earlier.

(2) Users of the Mandata system propose either reverting fully to manual methods or reverting to manual methods supplemented by the use of ADP or word processing techniques. It is expected that all but the very smallest departments will adopt some form of automation.
It is not possible to directly compare the efficiency of the decentralised alternatives which might be adopted with the current centralised system.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.
