QUESTION.SPEAKER: Neal Sen L.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 26 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the Commonwealth's past and present involvement in nuclear civil defence in Australia.

(2) What is: (a) the current state of nuclear civil defence in each State; (b) the extent of co-ordination between the States and between the States and the Commonwealth on nuclear civil defence matters.
(3) What advice and other assistance is available to individuals wishing to take their own precautions.
(4) How does Australia keep abreast of overseas developments in nuclear civil defence.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Since 1974 the Natural Disasters Organisation (NDO), which absorbed the functions of the earlier Directorate of Civil Defence, together with that State and Territory Emergency Service organisations have made up a core civil defence structure. Their main role in peacetime is that of counter disaster preparedness to mitigate the effect of disasters on the Australian community. The organisation and capabilities so established have general value to disasters in peace and war and it is not practicable to seperate activities having nuclear or non-nuclear relevance.

(2) (a) The States and Territories have the primary counter disaster responsibility including civil defence, planning and operations. The Commonwealth's role is to support the States through policy guidance, equipment, training and other financial support programs. For 1980-81 the cost of Commonwealth counter disaster support programs is $4.5m. State counter disaster arrangements involve all professional resources available such as police, medical and hospital, fire fighting and ambulance as well as State Emergency Service volunteer units.

(b) Close liaison is maintained between Commonwealth and State authorities for counter disaster planning and operations through the NDO. Commonwealth programs specifically directed to nuclear civil defence are the fall-out shelter survey which identifies available public fall-out shelter accommodation in existing buildings in the various State cities, and the production of public information pamphlets on nuclear fall-out protection.
(3) The NDO has published a Domestic Fall-out Shelter Guide which is available to the public from the State and Territory Emergency Service organisations. Some States provide additional information.

(4) Regular contact is maintained with counter disaster/civil defence organisations overseas on all aspects of developments including nuclear civil defence. A library of information from overseas sources is maintained at the Australian Counter Disaster College, Mt Macedon and is available to State and Territory authorities.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 26 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What steps have been taken to publicise the incentive payment of $2000 made available to encourage employers to make modifications to the workplace to assist disabled employees.
(2) How many applications had been received for this grant to 30 April 1981.
(3) How many applications had been approved and how much had been spent to 30 April 1981.
(4) Will the incentive payment scheme continue in 1981-82.

(5) Has the Government considered the possiblility of introducing a scheme whereby employers are subsidised for the costs of training disabled people in specific jobs, similar to the present provisions for unemployed school leavers.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The incentive payment of $2000 is available to employers who take on disabled trainees under the National Employment and Training System (NEAT). This incentive payment has been publicised in the press and in job training pamphlets distributed by, and freely available in, offices of the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES). It has also been mentioned in promotional material used by CES offices when contacting employers and disabled jobseekers. Mention has as well been made in literature prepared by the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs for the Commonwealth Employment Promotion Committee for the Disabled, which has been set up to promote the employment of the disabled during the International Year of Disabled Persons.
Further publicity has been given to this matter in Ministerial Press Release No 57/81 of 22 May 1981 and in ministerial speeches.
(3) Five applications have been approved and $3,110.44 has been spent.

(5) This is already provided under the National Employment and Training system (NEAT). Under NEAT unemployed disabled persons attract subsides for on-the-job training for specific jobs. These employer subsidies are at higher rates for a longer time than those for able job seekers.

individuals providing family based care not through a scheme; and

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 27 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: What are the reasons why all Government departments and all statutory authorities do not conduct all their banking business with Government-owned banks, that is, the Reserve Bank and the Commonwealth Bank.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Finance Direction 2/1 which applies to all Government departments and those statutory authorities operating through the Commonwealth Public Account states:

'Accounts shall be kept with the Reserve Bank or, where that is not practicable, with the most convenient Bank. Where it is practicable to use a branch of the Reserve Bank but nevertheless a Department desires to open or retain an official account with another bank, the full circumstances shall be reported to the Department of Finance for decision'.
My Department can find no record of a need to make a decision required by the latter part of that Direction.

Some statutory authorities not required to keep their accounts in accordance with commercial practice are required by their enabling legislation to open and maintain one or more bank accounts with an 'approved bank' or 'approved banks'. In these cases an approved bank is generally defined to mean the Reserve Bank of Australia or another bank approved by the Treasurer.

The Reserve Bank has a limited number of branches at which departments and statutory authorities can conduct their banking business and those branches are not always conveniently located. In most cases where departments and statutory authorities do not conduct their banking business with the Reserve Bank, they conduct it with the Commonwealth Trading Bank. In the bulk of the remaining cases they have accounts with branches of other Australian banks in localities where neither the Reserve Bank nor the Commonwealth Trading Bank has a branch, or with foreign banks in overseas countries in which they need to make transactions.

Statutory authorities required by their enabling legislation to keep their accounts in accordance with commercial practice are required by that legislation to open and maintain one or more bank accounts with an 'approved bank' or 'approved banks'. An approved bank in this regard means a trading bank as defined in sub-section 5 (1) of the Banking Act 1959 or another bank approved by the Treasurer. The choice of the bank or banks with which accounts are held is a matter for the authority's commercial judgement (subject to the Treasurer's approval in respect of banks other than those subject to the Banking Act) in the light of, for example, location and service considerations.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 2 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) As a result of the review of Commonwealth Functions will the Townsville College of Advanced Education no longer exist as an autonomous body.
(2) Will many North Queenslanders not have access to advanced education courses if the CAE is not maintained as a separate Body.

(3) Will the Minister for Education consider that this particular CAE continue to operate as an autonomous body in the field of education in view of the unique position that the Townsville CAE holds in the Higher education system in the North and far North Queensland.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Education has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question.

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (3) The Tertiary Education Commission Guidlines for 1982-84 announced on 4 June 1981 reiterated the Government's decision that it would promote a major rationalisation and reallocation of resources in higher education. This will involve the consolidation into larger units of 30 CAEs for which teacher education is the main activity. The Townsville CAE is one of these institutions. It is the Government's intention to reach agreement with each State by the end of 1981. If this cannot be done, the Commonwealth will not be prepared to continue recurrent funding for the colleges concerned after the end of 1981. The Commission has been asked to report on progress made on an interim basis by 30 June 1981 and finally in its Volume II Report by 31 August 1981.

The Minister for Trade and Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
I refer the honouralbe senator to my reply to Question No. 1004.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 28 April 1981 (Hansard, page 1390) Senator Hearn asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Education, a question, without notice concerning the effect upon Tasmania of the proposed closing ot the national Curriculm Development Centre.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Education has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

In the context of the Review of Commonwealth Functions, the Government announced that the Curriculum Development Centre would be abolished unless the States agreed to contribute 50 per cent of the total operating costs. The States have already been approached on this issue.

Until the results of discussions with all States are known, I am not in a position to comment on the future of specific projects which are currently being undertaken by the CDC in conjunction with the States, and in the case of the Southern Ocean and Antarctica project, with the New Zealand authorities.

Whatever future action is taken in relation to CDC, the Government has made clear that it is prepared to continue its active involvement on a shared funding basis in curriculm projects which have the endorsement of the Australian Education Council, and also to support projects which the Government considers are of national significance.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 29 April 1981 (Hansard page 1451) Senator Button asked me, as Minister representing the Prime Minister, a question without notice, concerning circumstances by which the former Wages Policy Committee of the Cabinet was discontinued.

ANSWER.PARA: The Prime Minister has supplied the following information for answer to the honourable senator's question:

The structure and operation of Cabinet committees is examined from time to time and as I indicated in the Parliament on 28 April 1981, (House of Representatives Hansard page 1614), when the new Government was formed after the election, in October 1980 it was determined that the Wages Policy Committee would not be re-established because it had met infrequently and it was considered that the proper forum for the discussion of wages policy matters should be Cabinet itself rather than a committee of Cabinet.

Rather than reducing the effective administration of the industrial relations portfolio it is a measure of the importance the Government attaches to wages policy and industrial relations generally that those matters are considered by the Cabinet.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 30 April 1981 (Hansard, page 1548) Senator Button addressed the following question to the Minister for Finance:

ANSWER.PARA: Is the Government planning later this year to sell 15 per cent of the quotas controlling the import into Australia of textiles, clothing and footwear? Will the sale of 15 per cent of the quotas give a few importers, notably the larger retail chains, the chance to tie up quotas? Will it also enable these importers to determine the real tariff level that the market will bear and to mark up their imported goods to that level at a potential profit of millions of dollars?
The Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's questions:

On 15 August 1980, the Government announced that the import quota available on a range of textile, clothing and footwear products will be allocated annually in the following manner from 1 January 1982:
85 per cent of the initially established quota ceiling in each category will be allocated to importers based on their import performance in the relevant categories during 1 July 1978 to 30 June 1980;
the remaining 15 per cent of the quota plus any increase to the total quota ceiling due to a predetermined liberalisation factor and assessed market growth, will be allocated by tender.
The allocation of a proportion of quota by tender will provide easier access to quota by new importers and importers wishing to expand their market shares.

Under a tender scheme, quota will be offered to the highest tenderers until the quota available is exhausted. All successful tenderers will pay the lowest tender rate at which quota is allocated in that particular category. The scheme as envisaged is not seen as favouring any one section of the importing community.

Legislation given royal assent on 14 May 1981 to give effect to the Government's decision to allocate quota by tender, provides penalties for importers who have been allocated tender quota and have not fully utilised their allocation. This should discourage speculators or persons lodging frivolous bids and ensure that the quota is available to people who have a genuine need for it.

The sale of some quota will provide an indication of the tariff level equivalent to the assistance afforded by the quota. However, it will not provide an incentive for importers to mark-up goods by a greater amount than they would, if the quota were allocated by some other means. Ultimately, the goods imported against tender quota must compete with domestically produced goods and goods imported by base quota holders.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 6 May 1981 (Hansard, page 1641), Senator Robertson asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Has his attention been drawn to an article in today's Australian concerning the use of Darwin Airport by American B52 bombers? I ask the Minister whether he noted one sentence which reads:
'Two of the planes will fly continuous missions above the Indian Ocean while one remains in Darwin.'

Will the Minister not agree that this marks the first contravention of the agreement which speaks of the bombers staging in Darwin and of the accompanying statement which suggests that the bombers will remain in Darwin overnight to allow crews to rest? Is it a fact that there will be a total of 34 landings a month, again contrary to the Minister's statement which implied much less usage and interference?
The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

I have noted the sentence referred to by the honourable senator. I do not agree with Senator Robertson's assertion that the sentence, which reflects accurately the planned concept of operations, marks a contravention of the Exchange of Notes of 11 March 1981 or the Prime Minister's accompanying statement of the same date.

All three B52s will stage through Darwin and the requirement for crew rest is the predominant requirement and applies to crews of all the B52s. It is a standard and well understood practice for the US to have one of the three B52 aircraft on standby ready to take over if one of the other two were to develop a mechanical problem early in the sea surveillance mission.

It is obvious that the standby crew would need to be fully rested and prepared for a long surveillance flight. If it does not need to take over the surveillance mission the standby aircraft will take off for the return flight to Guam within a few hours of the take off of the sea surveillance mission B52s.

I reject the honourable senator's contention that any particular level of usage was implied in Ministerial statements on the agreement. The Prime Minister's statement and the diplomatic note of 11 March 1981 refer to 'periodic deployments'. For Senator Robertson's information, the number of B52 landings in the first few months at least of operations will be five each month.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 12 May 1981 (Hansard, page 1813) Senator Hearn asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice, concerning the appointment of women as members of the Medical Benefits Advisory Committee.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Health has provided the following information:
No women are members of the Medical Benefits Advisory Committee. I am unable to say if and when a woman will be appointed.

The Health Insurance Act provides that the Committee consist of eight members, including at least five medical practitioners. Four of those five members may be appointed only after consultation between the Minister and the Australian Medical Association (AMA). The AMA has yet to nominate a woman to the Committee. Nominees of the Commonwealth have always been selected because of their expertise in the medical benefits area.

Currently there are no women occupying senior positions in that area. I would add that there is a majority of medically qualified persons on the Committee including a specialist obstetrician and gynaecologist. Such expertise would ensure that medical matters considered by the Committee, including those peculiar to females, are adequately represented.
However, I appreciate the thrust of the question and will keep the matter in mind and take it up with those who nominate persons for my consideration as members.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 13 May 1981 (Hansard, page 1879) Senator Chipp asked the Leader of the Government in the Senate the following question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Is it true that no adequate Federal plans exist to meet a nuclear attack and that State schemes are patchy and ineffective?
(2) Is it also true that civil defence against a nuclear attack has been downgraded in Australia over the past several years compared with defence against natural disasters?

(3) Does he accept the assessment of the Department of Defence that the possibility of a nuclear attack against Australia cannot be ruled out, and is he satisfied that our capacity to cope with a nuclear attack is adequate?
Senator Carrick undertook to seek the information from the relevant Minister. The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

(1) It is not true that no adequate plans exist to meet a nuclear attack. The Australian Government's policy is that basic civil defence capabilities should be maintained which can be readily enhanced if necessary. Australia's current and prospective strategic situation does not call for a high level of readiness to meet an imminent nuclear attack. It is this government's policy that defence resources should be directed primarily to the development of defence capabilities to deter and, if need be, to deal with a range of more realistic contingencies of conventional conflict in which Australia might need to defend itself.

(2) It is not true that civil defence against a nuclear attack has been downgraded. The basis of our civil defence capabilities resides in the various counter disasters resources in each State and Territory, in the Commonwealth's own resources, and in the Natural Disasters Organisation, and their civil defence capabilities have been enhanced over the last few years. The total active membership of State and Territory organisations is some 35,000 people, although relatively few permanent staff are employed at present. The Commonwealth support programs recognise that there are many similarities between organisations, techniques and equipment required for civil defence purposes and those necessary for mitigating the effects of natural disasters.

(3) The Government has endorsed the consolidated judgment of its advisers that the prospect of global nuclear conflict is remote so long as the United States and Union of Soviet Socialist Republics continue to be deterred by the enormous risks of nuclear warfare. Should nuclear war between the super-powers occur-and it is recognised that potential for miscalculation remains-the possibility that Australia, along with a lot of other countries, might be subject to nuclear attack cannot be discounted. But-and I emphasise this-the risk is remote and it is this Goverment's policy to support those elements of US deterrent capabilities that ensure it remains so.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 May 1981 (Hansard, page 2057) Senator Robertson asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Has the attention of the Minister been drawn to reports of a recent defence seminar in Darwin at which leading citizens, including the Police Commissioner, claimed that northern coastal surveillance was inadequate? Has he been told that illegal landings, drug running and illegal fishing were claimed to be the major problems and that the introduction of pastoral and agricultural diseases was a real threat? What action does the Government intend to take? Will the Minister not accept that defence of our country in peacetime is a proper role for his Department and not a civilian or coastguard activity?
The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

I am aware of the reports referred to by the honourable senator. A major review of the arrangements for civil coastal surveillance is now being undertaken by the standing inter-departmental committee on coastal surveillance, chaired by the Department of Transport and on which Defence is represented. The report of that review is expected to be submitted to the Government shortly. The review will be comprehensive, addressing amongst other issues, the concerns expressed about arrangements for surveillance of the northern Australian coastline, and also the appropriate level of participation by the Defence Force in future civil coastal surveillance operations.
The Minister for Transport is the Government spokesman on coastal surveillance arrangements, and the comments made at the recent Defence Seminar have been drawn to the attention of his Department.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 9 June 1981, (Hansard, page 2795), Senator Melzer asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources, the following question, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources. The Melbourne Age of 5 June carried an item stating that Energy Resources of Australia had signed a contract to sell 1,429 tonnes of uranium to a private Belgian company, Synatom. When did Australia sign a safeguards agreement with Belgium? What guarantees has this Government that this material will not be used to produce weapons grade uranium or plutonium or will not be sold to other people who are not a party to any safeguards agreement?
The Acting Minister for Trade and Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Negotiations between Australia and the European Atomic Energy Community (EURATOM) on a nuclear safeguards agreement concluded on 27 March 1981. The results of the negotiations were approved by the Council of Ministers of the European Community on 19 May. A statement issued by the Ministers for Trade and Resources and Foreign Affairs on 21 May welcomed this development and said that the agreement will be signed as soon as the necessary formal procedures on both sides have been completed.

Entry into force of the Australia/EURATOM agreement will open the way for exports of Australian uranium under new contracts to Member States of the European Community, including Belgium. The uranium to be supplied to the Belgian company SYNATOM by Energy Resources of Australia will be subject to the Australian/EURATOM agreement. No deliveries of Australian uranium to the European Community under the Energy Resources of Australia/SYNATOM contract approved on 27 May 1981, or any other new contract, can take place until that agreement has entered into force.

The Australia/EURATOM agreement meets all the requirements of the Government's stringent nuclear safeguards policy announceed by the Prime Minister on 24 May 1977. The agreement provides that Australian uranium which may be sold to Member States of the European Community for peaceful purposes will not be retransferred for end-use to any country which does not itself have a safeguards agreement in force with Australia. The agreement also provides that Australian uranium may not be enriched beyond 20 per cent in the isotope U235 without the prior consent of Australia. It also incorporates agreed conditions on reprocessing of spent fuel of Australian origin, in accordance with the Government's policy on conditions for Australian consent for reprocessing, as announced in Parliament by the Minister for Foreign Affairs on 27 November 1980.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 23 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Department of Industrial Relations or any of its predecessors ever engaged the commercial reporting firm Dun and Bradstreet; if so (a) when; (b) what service was it engaged to provide; and (c) what payments have been made since the arrangement commenced.
(2) Was any information supplied by the Department of Industrial Relations on a reciprocal basis to Dun and Bradstreet.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There is no record in the Department of Industrial Relations of any dealings with the firm Dun and Bradstreet.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 26 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Has ex-Detective Inspector Donald Thomas been engaged in investigations related to the social security 'conspiracy' case on behalf of the Crown Solicitor's Office or any other section of the Australian Government since his retirement on invalidity grounds.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 5 June 1981 (Hansard, page 2196) Senator Robertson asked me a question, without notice, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry in the Senate. His question concerned export of live cattle from Australia and the closure of abattoirs.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Primary Industry has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question.

In 1979-80 72,933 head of cattle were exported from Australia and 80,830 head were exported for the 10 months to 30 April 1981. The composition of those exports, by port, is set out in Tables 1 and 2 attached.

I draw the honourable senator's attention to the fact that 73 per cent in 1979-80 and 68 per cent in 1980-81 of slaughter cattle exports were exported from the northern Australian ports of Townsville, Darwin and Wyndham.

In the past 18 months abattoir operators have advised the Department of Primary Industry of the closure of 12 export registered abattoirs; a further 4 were closed during the period but have re-opened again. The Department has no information on closure of domestic only registered abattoirs and smaller slaughterhouses.
Source: Department of Primary Industry Records.
